Colony of mealybugs attacking stem (Thaumaturgist).
Cluster of mealybugs sucking juice from fruits (Thaumaturgist).

Authors.Surname: Moses, E (CSIR-Crops Research Institute) and  Woode, R (Ministry of Food and Agriculture)

Sections.Value:
- This disease is spread by infected stem cuttings, so use healthy planting materials obtained from plants without symptoms of the disease (cankers, stems with insect holes and stem dieback).
- Stem cuttings can be treated with a fungicide before planting to protect against the disease (see yellow direct control)
- Plant resistant varieties (Bankyehemaa and Esam bankye) available from MoFA District Directorates or approved multiplications sites across the country
- Avoid planting on the same piece of land for more than 3 seasons, rotate with grains
- Remove old cassava plant debris after harvest and burn
- The pathogen infects through wounds and insect damage - so avoid wounding plants. Late planting (second half of rainy season) can restrict disease associated with insect damage.

- Monitor cassava fields at weekly interval after sprouting through to plant maturity. Look for symptoms such as wilting, dieback and cankers especially in the wet season.
- When symptoms are observed take action
- Rogue out any infected plants as soon as symptoms can be seen to prevent the spread of the disease. Rogueing should not be extensive.

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Treat cutting for planting with Cuprofix 30 Disperss (mancozeb (30%) + metallic copper (12%)). General Restrictions: WHO Class II (moderately hazardous) Mix 20-30g/15litres and dip cuttings in the mixture for 3-5 minutes and allow to dry before planting

Images.Caption: Cassava stem showing cankers  (E. Moses, CSIR-Crops Research Institute Kumasi)
Cassava plant infected with anthracnose disease (IITA)

Authors.Surname: Moses, E (CSIR-Crops Research Institute) and  Woode, R (Ministry of Food and Agriculture)

Sections.Value:
- When planting new crops in a disease hot spot area consider using resistant FHIA hybrids (e.g. FHIA 02) or use planting materials from healthy plants
- Use large planting spacing (3m x 2m) to ensure good air circulation between the plants. This reduces humidity and promotes dry leaf surfaces making conditions unfavourable for the disease
- Remove suckers to avoid clustering
- Ensure good drainage in the fields and weed frequently as this reduces the humidity and the disease
- Avoid transporting infected plants into disease-free regions

- Monitor the field regularly looking for symptoms of the disease:
- The early symptoms include reddish brown specks on lower leaf surfaces. As the disease develops the specks become larger and wider running parallel with the leaf veins and eventually overlap. They turn dark brown to black in colour and can be visible on the upper side of the leaf.
- Take necessary action when the early symptoms are observed
- The symptoms of black Sigatoka are very similar to yellow Sigatoka but the disease management method is the same

- Rogue out young infected plants that have just shown symptoms and burn
- Remove older infected leaves regularly and burn or stack them in heaps, keeping the lower leaf surface facing the ground to help prevent disease spread

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- According to the Fungicide Resistance Action Committee (FRAC) Mycospharella fijiensis has a high risk of developing resistance to fungicides. General Restrictions: Where there is a high risk of the pathogen developing fungicide resistance it is advisable to change the type of fungicide used every year or use a mixture incorporating a broad spectrum protectant fungicide such as a copper compound
- Spray with Thiophanate methyl (400g/l) (Callis 400 OL) Apply at a rate of Apply 31-41g/15litre knapsack. Methyl benzimidazole carbamate (MBC) fungicide with systemic action (FRAC group: B1). General Restrictions: WHO Class U (unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use). Start application when disease first appears, ensure spray reaches the youngest leaves on the top of the plant. Repeat every 7-14 days observe REI of 24hrs.
- Propiconazole 250EC (Tilt). Apply at a rate of 15mls / 15ltr knapsack as a full-coverage spray to the point of drip. Triazoles fungicide with systemic action (FRAC group: G1). General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous) Apply as soon as disease is seen or when the wet season begins, ensure spray reaches the youngest leaves on the top of the plant. Repeat at 21-28 days interval. Do not enter treated areas within 24 hours after spray.

Images.Caption: Developing symtpoms on a leaf with necrotic patches (Neil Palmer, CIAT)
Collapse of the older leaves showing symptoms of black sigatoka (Neil Palmer, CIAT)

Authors.Surname: Moses, E (CSIR-Crops Research Institute) and  Woode, R (Ministry of Food and Agriculture)

Sections.Value:
- When planting new crop in a disease hot spot area consider using resistant FHIA hybrids or use planting materials from healthy plants
- Use large spacing or planting distances (3m x 3m) to ensure good air circulation between the plants. This reduces humidity and promotes dry leaf surfaces making conditions unfavourable for the disease
- Remove suckers to avoid clustering
- Ensure good drainage in the fields and weed frequently as this reduces the humidity and the disease
- Avoid transporting infected plants into disease-free regions

- Monitor field regularly looking for symptoms of the disease:
- The early symptoms include light green/yellow specks on the upper surface of leaves. As the disease develops the specks develop into red/brown streaks running parallel with the leaf veins. The streaks become larger and the surrounding leaf tissue turns yellow
- Take necessary action when the early symptoms are observed
- The symptoms of yellow sigatoka are very similar to black sigatoka but the disease management method is the same

- Rogue out young infected plants that have just shown symptoms of Sigatoka and burn
- Remove older infected leaves regularly and burn or stack on top of each other to reduce the disease spread

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana
- According to the Fungicide Resistance Action Committee (FRAC) Mycospharella musicola has a medium risk of developing resistance to fungicides

- Spray with Thiophanate methyl (400g/l) (Callis 400 OL) Apply at a rate of Apply 31-41g/15litre knapsack. Methyl benzimidazole carbamate (MBC) fungicide with systemic action (FRAC group: B1). General Restrictions: WHO Class U (unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use). Start application when diseases first appears, ensure spray reaches the youngest leaves on the top of the plant. Repeat every 7-14 days observe REI of 24hrs. Follow other safety and first aid instructions on the label
- Propiconazole 250EC (Tilt). Apply at a rate of 15mls / 15ltr knapsack as a full-coverage spray to the point of drip. Triazoles fungicide with systemic action (FRAC group: G1). General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous) Apply as soon as disease is first seen within the crop or when the wet season begins, ensure spray reaches the youngest leaves on the top of the plant. Repeat at 21-28 days interval. Do not enter treated areas during the within 24 hours after spray.

Images.Caption: Infected leaf showing brown streaked lesions and yellow discolouration (Steve Nelson, www.flickr.com)
Close up of symptoms on a leaf (E Moses, CSIR-Crops Research Institute)

Authors.Surname: Ken Okwae Fening (University of Ghana), Francis Collison Brentu (University of Ghana) and Adam Iddrisu Alidu (PPRSD-MOFA)

Sections.Value:
- Use clean planting materials from tissue culture, or plant vigorous healthy suckers from weevil free plants
- Pare (trim) dead parts from the corm and remove outer leafsheaths. Immerse suckers in hot water (54C) for 20 minutes or dip suckers in 20% neem solution overnight and plant as soon as possible
- Deep plant suckers (45-60cm) in fertile soils at recommended spacing to delay infestation
- Dig out and remove old corms, weeds and trash around banana stools to reduce weevil sheltering sites
- Cut up fallen and harvested pseudostems to reduce breeding sites.
- Remove alternative hosts (Ensente and Musa spp.) and destroy
- Spread mulch away from banana stool leaving about 60 cm ring from the stool to prevent the roots growing towards the surface where they can be attacked by weevils

- Visit banana plantation weekly from seedling to fruiting stage to observe any infestation
- Look for larvae (grubs) and adults inside the corm, stem and nearby soil
- Monitor plants for weevil signs that the weevils are present: gummy exudates and irregular circular tunnels or cavities in the base of banana stem just above ground
- Scout regularly for banana weevil borer activity by trapping adults with cut banana split discs (20x60cm) covered by leaves or using corm damage rating. About 4 weevils per cut banana stem disc indicates the need for control.
- A single plant with clear signs of weevil infestation may warrant a control action

- Cut slices of banana trunk 7-10 cm thick, place them around the stool on the ground covered by banana leaves to trap and then kill banana weevils mechanically
- Apply 50-100g neem seed powder around each stool at 4 months interval (applying higher rates will harm the plant)
- Apply neem leaf mulch around the base of the plant (1Kg per plant).

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana
- Application of insecticides should be directed at areas where the pest is present e.g. around the base of the plant

- Thiamethoxam (e.g. Devaxam 25WG, Raintham 350 SC, Wonderex, Okumakate SC). Applied at 80g/acre. Neonicotinoid with systemic, contact and stomach activity. . General Restrictions: WHO class III (slightly hazardous), Apply as soon as weevil infestation is observed and repeat 21 days after monitoring.Observe REI of 12 hours PHI of 4 days
- Chlorpyrifos (Dursban or Sunpyrifos 480g/L EC). Apply 30mls per 15l knapsack. Non-systemic insecticide with contact, stomach, and respiratory activity. General Restrictions: WHO class III (Slightly hazardous). After first application repeat after 14 days. DO NOT allow entry into treated crops until spray deposits have dried. Pre-harvest interval is 14-21 days

Images.Caption: Banana weevil, adult and juvenile (Scot Nelson, www.flickr.com)
Adult banana weevil damage in rhizome and pseudostem (A Nkakwa Attey, Musarama).

Authors.Surname: Moses, E (CSIR-Crops Research Institute), Woode, R (MOFA) & Jeremiah Nuetey Teye (MOFA)

Sections.Value:
- Use healthy seedlings/grafting material from sources free from the disease
- Avoid transport of infected material to areas free from the disease
- Prune and burn infected plant parts and old mango fruits and fruit stalk after harvest
- Prune trees regularly to improve sunlight penetration and air movement by removing internal part of canopy and disease branches
- Pruning equipment should surface sterilized with 5% bleach or sodium hypochlorite as pruners move from one trees to another
- Avoid all cultivation activities when the trees are wet as the disease spreads more quickly when conditions are wet

- Monitor weekly for symptoms of the disease
- On leaves the infection starts as small brown oily spots that turn necrotic, black, angular raised spots sometimes surrounded by a yellow halo
- Branches, petioles and perduncles show cracks, raised spots and cankers. A sticky exudate (gum) exudes from the cankers mainly in the rainy season
- On fruits small black raised spots form often teardrop shaped. These spots enlarge, crack and sticky gum ooze from the cracks
- Act when the first symptoms are seen or copper fungicides can be used as a preventative measure
- Lesions of black spot are more angular and raised than anthracnose but very similar

- Prune and burn all infected branches to reduce the spread of the disease
- Destroy infected fruit both on the tree and ground regulary to avoid spread
- Remove seriously disease trees, when cankers are present on the main trunk

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Mancozeb (30%) + metallic copper (12%) (Cuprofix 40 Disperse) Apply at a rate of 40g/15l knapsack. Preventative, contact fungicide. Multisite activity, FRAC groups M3 & M1. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous). Apply at monthly intervals after fruit set until harvest and after pruning. Observe REI of 48hrs.
-  Copper Oxychloride (50%) (Curenox 50WP) Apply at a rate of 30-60g/15l knapsack. Multisite Preventative activity, FRAC groups M1. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous) Apply at monthly interval after fruit set until harvest and after pruning. Observe REI of 48hrs and a PHI of 1 day

Images.Caption: Symptoms on mango fruits (Jeremiah Nuetey Teye, MOFA)
Symptoms on mango leaves (Jeremiah Nuetey Teye, MOFA)

Authors.Surname: John Lovelace Kpodoviah (DAES, MOFA), Birgitta Oppong-Mensah (CABI), Claud Kwadwo Mintah (PPRSD, MOFA)

Sections.Value:
- Plant in the raining season since beetles develop a fungal disease that can reduce their population
- Clean farm tools after use to reduce the spread of the eggs and larvae
- Remove crop debris after harvesting and burn because adults shelter under plant debris
- Practice crop rotation with cereals (maize, sorghum, millet)

- Inspect every part of the plant for different stages of the pest and symptoms from germination to harvest:
- Observe many small short round holes on leaves at seedling stage
- Look for perforated and skeletized (sievelike) leaves
- Look for tiny shiny, dark brown or black beetles on the plants
- Uproot the plant and observe the roots for larvae and root feeding
- Control when 5-10% leaf area for young crop or 20-40% for older crop is damaged

- Ensure good agricultural practices (fertilization, irrigation, soil management) to allow plant to out grow the damage
- Weed and lightly stir soil around plants to exposed eggs and grub in the soil to predators (e.g. birds, ants) because flea beetles lay eggs in the soil cracks around the base of the plant

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Thiamethoxam 350g/l (e.g Raintham) Apply at a rate of 10-13 mls / 15L knapsack. Broad spectrum systemic neonicotinoid, IRAC group 4A. General Restrictions: WHO class III (Slightly hazardous) Neonicotinoid. For optimum control, apply when pest populations are first observed. Repeat at 7 days after monitoring when pest pesist. REI is 12 hours.
- Fenvelerate 200g/l (e.g.Shoker 20EC or Sanitox 20EC) Apply at a rate of 2-4mls per 15L knapsack. Pyrethroid with contact and stomach action. IRAC group 3A. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous). Apply at 7 days interval. PHI is 2days and REI is 12hours.
-  Alpha-cypermephrin (eg Fastrack 10SC). Apply at a rate of 8-15mls / 15L knapsack. Pyrethroid with contact and stomach action, IRAC group 3A. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous). Apply to seedlings and vegetative stage. Repeat application after 7-10 days if the pest persist. PHI is one day. Do not enter the field until spray droplets are dry.

Images.Caption: Flea beetle feeding damage on an okra leaf (K.O. Fening, University of Ghana)

Authors.Surname: Moses, E (CSIR-Crops Research Institute) and  Woode, R (Ministry of Food and Agriculture)

Sections.Value:
- Use certified disease free seeds for planting or consider using tolerant varieties (eg. Amankwatia, Jasmine and AGRA rice)
- Avoid excessive use of nitrogen fertilizer as this can increase the severity of the disease
- Avoid drought stress to plants and extended drainage period as this makes the plants more susceptible to the disease
- Practice continuous flooding to limit blast development

- Monitor plants by observing leaves for appearance of major symptom - diamond shaped lesions with grey centre and brown or reddish borders and start post planting control measures
- Presence of blast lesions just before booting often dictates decisions for chemical treatment
- Remove leaves with lesions or symptoms if they are not many during monitoring

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Apply Maneb (80%) (Trimangol 80WP) Apply 70g/knapsack; Broad spectrum protectant fungicide with a multi-site mode of action (FRAC group M3) . General Restrictions: WHO Class U (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use) Start application when lesions first appear and just before booting to prevent neck blast. Repeat application at 10days interval.Observe PHI of 14 days and : DO NOT enter into treated areas until the spray has dried unless wearing cotton overall.
- Apply Kingstar WG (Azoxystrobin (60%)+Cyproconazole (24%) ) Apply at a rate of 75ml/15l knapsack; FRAC groups: azoxystrobin C3 & cyproconazole G1. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous), Apply at first sign of disease attack, usually from tillering to early flowering. Ensure thorough coverage of application. Repeat application upon monitoring at early booting stage. PHI is 15 days. DO NOT enter into treated areas until the spray has dried unless wearing cotton overalls

Images.Caption: Rice field with blast symptoms on the leaves (E. Moses, Crops Research Institute)
Blast lesions on leaves (Donald Groth, Louisiana State University AgCenter, Bugwood.org)
Rice stem nodes showing symtoms of rice blast (Donald Groth, Louisiana State University AgCenter, Bugwood.org)

Sections.Value:
- Don't use varieties susceptible to the disease
- Plant trees with sufficient space between them to allow air circulation in the orchard
- Remove dead branches, twigs and leaves from the tree on a regular basis if they are entwined, as the fungus lives on them
- The fungus also lives on rotten fallen fruits and dead or dying leaves; remove fallen fruits and leaves from the orchard
- Balance nutrients; apply composted manures
- To improve ventilation in the tree canopy, prune branches and low limbs to at least 60 cm off the ground at the start of the dry season
- Control insect pests such as fruitspotting bugs and fruit flies to reduce the incidence of the disease, as wounds created by insects enhance the damage
- Handle fruit carefully during and after harvest to avoid causing injuries that increase the risk of infection

- Monitor 10 marked trees/ha per week during rainy season for symptoms
- Fruits:
Symptoms develop after harvest and during ripening
Small, light-brown circular lesions first appear on fruits. Eventually the lesions enlarge and become dark-brown or black and slightly sunken in the centre
In wet weather, salmon-coloured spore masses may be produced in the centre of the lesions
Infected young fruits may drop from trees
- Leaves:
Symptoms rarely develop on leaves but if affected, small black spots are formed
- The disease is favoured by high humid conditions (> 95%) and temperatures between 10 C and 30C (optimal at 25C)

- Cool fruits to 5C as soon as possible after harvest (within 6 hours) and control post-harvest temperature and conditions (cold and dry)
- Collect and destroy affected fruits

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Fruit affected by anthracnose (Scot Nelson)
Fruit affected by anthracnose (Florida Division of Plant Industry Archive, Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services, Bugwood.org)
Late stage of anthracnose showing the fungal spore mass in the centre of the lesion (A.A. Seif, icipe)

Sections.Value:
- Before storing new maize, clean and disinfect the storage area, removing and burning all residues
- To eliminate residual infestation, immerse used sacks in boiling water or use new bags to store maize
- Harvest early (when the black layer has formed between the tip of the maize and the cob) before the larger grain borer infests the grain
- When harvesting and storing, check that maize is free of pests, and store only clean cobs
- Shell and dry the maize until it is very dry (less than 12% moisture)
- Store maize with dried lantana or eucalyptus leaves to repel the larger grain borer
- Use airtight, sealed containers
- Do not store grains for a long period. Infestation is usually low if grains are sold or used within three months

- Monitor weekly the stored produce for damage (e.g. holes in the grains, frass and dust) and adults or larva. Infestation at low levels is not obvious, so it is important to sample and carefully examine the grains.
- Inspect holes and cracks where adults can hide.
- Use a box sieve with a mesh of 1 to 2 mm to separate the insects and the grains
- Bags can be emptied in a thin layer onto a sheet in the shade to examine the content
- If any adults or larva are found, the infested produce has to be removed from the storage and destroyed
- Use pheromone traps:
Flight traps e.g. funnel, delta or wing traps
Place at 100 m away from the storage area or the standing maize crop
Position 1 to 2 m from the ground

- Use natural enemies, e.g. the beetle Teretriosoma nigrescens, a specific predator
- Apply an ash-chili mixture to protect maize. Mix 2 kg of wood ash with 1 tablespoon of fine chili powder. Mix 1 part of ash-chili mixture with 4 parts of dried maize grain
- Mix 1 kg of diatomite powder per bag of maize or grain
- Mix finely crushed laterite (common red soil of the arid tropics) with grains in grain stores or sealed clay pots

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Adult Prostephanus truncatus (Pest and Diseases Image Library-University of Georgia, Bugwood.org)
Damage made by the larger grain borer (CABI)

Sections.Value:
- Use certified disease-free seeds
- Plant resistant or tolerant varieties
- To reduce initial inoculum, use tillage methods that promote decomposition of crop debris, as the fungus survives in and on plant debris
- Practise crop rotation with non-grass crops and eliminate weedy grass hosts
- On sorghum, increased levels of nitrogen increase the development of the disease. Avoid high levels of nitrogen fertilization
- Crop rotation for 1-2 years with soybeans, beans and sunflower. Do not practise crop rotation with maize

- Monitor regularly for symptoms during optimal conditions of high humidity and moderate temperatures (18-27 C)
- Leaves:
Initially slightly oval, small, water-soaked spots appear. The spots grow into elliptical (with pointed ends) brown lesions until nearly as wide as the leaf
The margin is red-purple and during warm, humid weather, greenish black fungal sporulation is produced in the centre of the lesions
In the final stages, lesions are tan to grey, may merge and lead to complete burning of the foliage
Lesions develop first on lower leaves and progress upwards
- Seedlings: small reddish-purple or yellowish-brown spots usually develop on the leaves
- Under warm, humid conditions the disease may cause serious damage by killing all leaves before plants have matured
- Symptoms on resistant cultivars are reduced to small chlorotic or necrotic spots
- S. turcica on sorghum forms larger and fewer lesions than Cochliobolus heterostrophus (southern leaf spot), mostly on the leaves but also on the stalks. Cercospora, Colletorichum, Ascochyta can also cause similar leaf disease symptoms
- Act when the first lesions appear on the leaves
- There are no direct control measures for this disease

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Large elliptical leaf blight lesions on sorghum (Courtesy EcoPort: David C. Nowell)
Typical shape and colour of a S. turcica lesion on a sorghum leaf (Courtesy EcoPort: David C. Nowell)
Early water-soaked lesion near the base of the leaf without a pigmented margin (Courtesy EcoPort: David C. Nowell)

Sections.Value:
- Sow early (before the onset of rains) so that ears appear before the peak period of aphid populations
- Provide adequate nutrients to soil with manure to grow healthy plants
- Provide adequate irrigation during the silk stage to reduce or eliminate aphid damage
- Eliminate weeds and host plants, such as Johnson grass, from around the farm
- Practise crop rotation with non-cereal crops e.g. beans, cowpeas, etc.
- Encourage natural enemies such as parasitic wasps, lady beetles, syrphid fly larvae and lacewings by reducing the amount of chemicals used in the field

- Monitor protected locations on the plant (i.e. within the whorl, in the curl of the leaves, upper part of the cornstalk) during whorl stage for dark green to bluish-green nymphs and adults
- Infestation usually starts on the leaf whorls, unemerged heads and tassels. The most severe damage occurs between late-whorl and pollination stages
- In heavy infestation, feeding may cause leaf curling, wilting and yellow mottling, and stunting of the whole plant
- Abundant production of honeydew by aphids results in sooty mould growth, and tassels and upper leaves may become completely covered preventing pollen release
- Ants are attracted by honeydew secretions; monitor ant activity at the base of the plants
- R. maidis is not of major importance and often doesn't need control, unless transmitting viruses (it is a vector of maize dwarf mosaic virus and maize leaf-fleck virus)
- Act only if 50 % of the plants monitored have more than 100 aphids/plant, and plants are under drought stress
- If available, release biological control agents such as Aphelinus varipes, Lysiphlebus testaceipes and L. mirzai

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Adult R.maidis (H. Banziger)
Maize aphid infestation (Department of Plant Pathology Archive, North Carolina State University, Bugwood.org)
Maize aphid infestation in tassel (Eric Burkness, Bugwood.org)

Sections.Value:
- Use certified disease-free seeds
- Use resistant cultivars
- As the disease is seed borne, avoid harvesting diseased grain and contaminating grain used for seed with spores

- Seedling infection occurs between seed germination and seedling emergence, but the disease is apparent only after heading
- Severity of infection is influenced by soil temperature and soil moisture. Severe smut infection generally occurs when soil temperature ranges from 18-23 C and soil moisture is 15-20 % during the infection period
- Monitor after heading for symptoms
Individual grains of sorghum become misshapen as they develop and are filled with dark smut spores on maturity. The smut sori (cone-shaped gall) is inside the seed coat
The panicle may be reduced to a few twisted, distorted branches covered with large, superficial smut sori. In some cases, the panicle branches may be completely destroyed, leaving only the distorted central rachis covered with sori
Infected plants are generally the same height and size as healthy plants
- Remove the smutted heads and bury in soil or burn

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Sorghum smut (Courtesy EcoPort (http://www.ecoport.org): Jrgen Kranz)
Sorghum smut (Courtesy EcoPort (http://www.ecoport.org): Jrgen Kranz)

Authors.Surname: John Lovelace Kpodoviah (DAES, MoFA), Birgitta Oppong-Mensah (CABI) and Claud Kwadwo Mintah (PPRSD, MOFA )

Sections.Value:
- Use disease-free or certified seed for planting
- Rotate tomato with cereals (e.g maize) or legumes (cowpea or groundnut) every two seasons. Observe good agricultural practice (no new plants alongside old ones) to prevent the spread of the disease
- Disinfect hands and tools with detergent or household bleach after working on the infected plants
- Practice staking and mulching to prevent the fruit from touching the soil and to improve aeration
- Remove and destroy crop debris after harvest and solanaceous weeds that may act as hosts
- Promote good air circulation in the field by proper spacing (e.g. 70-80cm between rows and 40-60cm between plants)

- This disease is also found on potato, pepper and egg plant
- Regularly monitor fields for presence of lesions with chlorotic margins on the leaves
- Dark brown to black circular or angular spots on leaflets with concentric zones
- Black or brown sunken lesions on fruits
- When the first symptoms appear implement control measures or next season consider applying a protectant fungicide to protect against the disease. All of these recommended fungicides can also be used to manage late blight

- Remove and burn infected plant detected early
- Carry diseased materials to be destroyed away in a closed container to prevent spread of the disease

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Mancozeb (e.g. Sarozeb 80WP, Rain mancoz 80WP) Apply at a rate of 24-32g/15l knapsack. Broad spectrum protectant fungicide with a multi-site mode of action (FRAC group M3). General Restrictions: WHO Class U (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use). Apply at 7-10 days interval PHI: 2 days; REI: Do not enter treated areas until spray has dried unless wearing protective clothing
- Azoxystrobin 500g/kg (e.g.Skyrobin) Apply at a rate of 6-10 mls/15l knapsack. Systemic and protectant action, FRAC group C3. General Restrictions: WHO Class U. Commence application soon after transplanting and repeat application at 7-14days interval till fruit maturity. Observe a PHI of 1 day and REI of 4hrs. Ensure complete coverage for effective control.
- Azoxystrobin 200g/l and Difenconazole 125g/l (Amistar Top 325SC) Apply 7.5-10ml/ knapsack. Broad spectrum fungide mixture, FRAC groups C3 & G1. General Restrictions: WHO Class III. Commence application soon after transplanting and repeat application at 7-14days interval till fruit maturity. Observe PHI of 3 days

Images.Caption: Tomato fruit with early blight showing the concentric rings in the lesion (AVRDC - The World Vegetable Center)
Leaf with early blight, lesions are dark brown surrounded by a yellow colouration (AVRDC - The World Vegetable Center)

Authors.Surname: John Lovelace Kpodoviah (DAES, MoFA), Birgitta Oppong-Mensah (CABI) and Claud Kwadwo Mintah (PPRSD, MOFA )

Sections.Value:
- Keep wide plant spacing (80cm X 50cm) to reduce the spread of disease
- Support the plants with sticks and prune for better aeration. Avoid wetting the plants for long periods of time and water in the morning so the leaves can dry in the sun as wet conditions favour the disease
- Disinfect hands and tools after working on the infected plants to prevent the spread of the disease to healthy plants. Use household bleach or 5% sodium hypochloride
- Remove and burn debris from tomatoes and other solanaceous crops (potato, peppers and eggplant) after harvest
- Do not plant solaneceous crops on land that suffered from the disease in the previous season
- Practice crop rotation with non-solanaceous crops such as cereals for 2 growing seasons (e.g. maize)

- This disease also affects potato, pepper and egg plant
- Late blight is fungi-like mould disease which can affect the leaves, stems and fruits
- Early symptoms look like green water soaked spots which turn into irregular brown necrotic lesions on leaves. Brown lesions develop on the fruits and stems in the later stage of the disease
- Regularly observe the plants particularly during the raining season when the disease is more likely to occur. When the first symptoms appear implement control measures. Consider applying protectant fungicides before the wet season starts to protect against the disease
- Remove and burn infected plants showing early symptoms carrying diseased materials away in a closed container to prevent spreading the disease

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Mancozeb (e.g. Sarozeb 80WP, Rain mancoz 80WP) Apply at a rate of 24-32g/15l knapsack. Broad spectrum protectant fungicide with a multi-site mode of action (FRAC group M3). General Restrictions: WHO Class U (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use). Apply at 7-10 days interval PHI: 2 days; REI: Do not enter treated areas until spray has dried unless wearing protective clothing
- Maneb (Trimaneb 80WP or Kadmaneb 80WP) Apply at a rate of 35-65ml/15l knapsack. Broad spectrum protectant fungicide with a multi-site mode of action (FRAC group M3) . General Restrictions: WHO Class U. Begin spraying at first fruit cluster, repeat at 10days interval. PHI: Do not apply within five days of harvest REI: Do not enter treated areas until spray has dried unless wearing protective clothing
- Azoxystrobin 500g/kg (e.g.Skyrobin) Apply at a rate of 12mls/15l knapsack. Systemic and protectant action, FRAC group C3. General Restrictions: WHO Class U. Commence application soon after transplanting and repeat application at 7-14days interval till fruit maturity. Observe a PHI of 1 day and REI of 4hrs.
- Azoxystrobin 200g/l and Difenconazole 125g/l (Amistar Top 325SC) Apply 12ml/15l knapsack. Broad spectrum fungide mixture, FRAC groups C3 & G1. General Restrictions: WHO Class III. Commence application soon after transplanting and repeat application at 7-14days interval till fruit maturity. Observe PHI of 3 days

Brown lesions on the stems of tomato (SC Nelson, www.flickr.com)

Authors.Surname: Ebenezer Aboagye (PPRSD/MOFA), Zippora Appiah -Kubi (CSIR-CRI), Veronica Nipaah Foster (PPRSD/MOFA), Patrick Beseh (PPRSD/MOFA)

Sections.Value:
- Collect and destroy all leftover seeds, fruits and debris in the orchard after havest, bury 50cm befow the soil
- Avoid planting in a field with previous pest history of weevil damage
- Avoid planting seeds from infested fields because weevils develop in them and emerge from seeds left on the ground
- Avoid the movement of infested fruits for propagaton or consumption.
- Establish orchards with weevil-free nursery stock
- Remove non-commercial mango trees or treat them with insecticide

- Visit to the field weekly and look for the adult at their hiding sites. The adults can be black, greyish, reddish or yellowish, 7.5-9.5 mm long with a long 'nose', hiding under loose barks, around the base of mango trees or in the fork of branches or leaf litter
- Check for feeding damage on new growth prior to flowering
- Look for presence of eggs in the fruits at the marble size
- Look for sap flow on the immature fruits
- Cut fruits and seeds at harvest to look for larvae and adult
- Act two weeks after flowering

- Clean by brushing using old broom at junctions of branches on the trunk and crushing adult.
- Use sticky bands placed on tree trunck below the branches just before flowering to trap migrating weevils
- Collect and destroy all fallen fruits by chopping and burying more than 50cm deep at weekly interval during the growing season until after harvest
- Control adult stone weevil withthe biocontrol agent Oecophylla smaragdina(ant) if available. Integrate with orchard sanitation for effective control

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Alpha cypermethrin (e.g. Fastrack 10SC, Fendona 5SC). Apply at 40 ml /15L of water. Contact pyrethroid, IRAC group 3A. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately Hazardous), Apply at flowering, early fruit set or when first eggs are noticed (Feb-April). Apply early morning and late evening, Apply at most two times per palnting season. Re-entry period 24 hours.
- Acetamiprid (e.g Golan 20SP). Apply at 50 ml /15L of water. Systemic neonicotinoid, IRAC group 4A. General Restrictions: WHO class Il (Caution). Apply at flowering,early fruit set or when first eggs are noticed (Feb-April). Apply early morning and late evening, Apply at most two times per planting season. Re-entry period 24 hours .
- Fenitrothion+fenvalerate (e.g. Hockli Combi 40EC). Apply at 50 ml /15L of water. Fenitrothion is a non-systemic organophosphate, IRAC groug 1B; Fenvalerate Systemic is a contact pyrethroid, IRAC group 3A. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately Hazards). Spray at flowering, early fruit set or when first eggs are noticed. Apply early morning or late evening. Apply at most two times per planting season. Re-entry period 24 hours.

Authors.Surname: Ebenezer Aboagye ( PPRSD) , Veronica Nipaah Foster ( PPRSD/MOFA), Patrick Beseh ( PPRSD/MOFA),  Zippora Appiah Kubi (CSIR-CRI)

Sections.Value:
- Do not crop on the same piece of land for more than two seasons (rotate cowpea with maize)
- Deep plough and harrow to kill larvae/pupae or expose them to direct sunlight and predators
- Remove and destroy volunteer cowpea plants because they may harbor the borer
- Intercrop cowpea with non-host plant like maize
- Remove and destroy alternate host e.g. soybean plants and wild legumenous plants (e.g mucuna)
- Practise good farm sanitation (e.g keep field free from weeds)

- Visit the field every day after flowering to look for signs of damage
- Check for eggs on flower buds, flowers and terminal shoots
- Look for presence of young caterpillars among flowers and foliage
- Also look for fecal remains of adults and larvae, frass of the larvae and malformed pods
- Damaged flowers and newly formed pods with holes
- Inspect fields to look for the precence of more natural enemies such as lady bird beetle and preying mantis
- Take action when 5 plant are damaged and the presence of sooty mould on the leaf surface

- Hand-pick eggs and larvae from plants and crush them (wear hand gloves)
- Prune some leaves (older leaves) to expose larvae to natural enemies and allow direct penetration of sunlight into the canopy
- Remove and destroy leaves with white silk threads where larvae hide
- Create conducive environment for natural enemies (e.g. lady bird beetles, spiders. praying mantis etc.) to multiply, e.g. by minimizing spraying and by mulching
- Plant varieties that display the pods above the plant canopy such as Asontem

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Apply Cypermethrin (Caweperthrin, Cypercan, Fastrack 10SC). General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous). Apply at a rate of 40ml/15litres of water. Observe a PHI of 7 days and REI of 24 hours. Apply at early infestation period and repeat if pest persist. Apply early morning and late evening. Apply at most two times per planting season.
- Lambda-cyhalothrin 25g/l (e.g. Conquer Super 2.5EC, Bonlambda 2.5EC, Contihalothrin 2.5EC) apply at 100ml per 15litres of water. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous). Apply at a rate of 40ml/15litres of water. Observe a PHI of 7 days and REI of 24 hours. Apply during early infestation aand at early morning or late evening, maximum two times per planting season
-

Larva of pod borer feeding inside the pod showing fecal remains (E. Aboagye, PPRSD, Ghana)

Sections.Value:
- Use disease-free planting material available from FOHCREC Kade or a certified nursery
- Timely and complete harvesting of ripe fruit to reduce disease inoculum
- Removal and burial of fallen fruit from the orchrd floor helps to reduce disease inoculum. and burning of leaves from the orchard floor reduces the source of inoculum and therefore the disease
- Prune to remove unproductive and diseased branches after harvest to reduce humidity and increase air circulation in the orchard to reduce the disease
- Encourage other citrus farmers in the area to have a routine management programme

- In areas where the disease is present, start a preventative fungicide regime after petal drop. Infection occurs when the fruits are young but symptoms don't appear until maturity
- To detect symptoms of the disease, look at the underside of fallen decomposing leaves every month for the presence of minute black spots using a hand lens. These are the fruiting bodies which produce the infective spores
- Monitor fruit for symptoms close to maturity, including small hard sunken brown/black spots
- There are no green direct controls for this disease

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- In organic farms / systems apply a copper based fungicide such as copper hydroxide (eg Funguran OH 50WP) Rate: 60g/12L of water using a motorised mist blower Protectant fungicide with a multi-site mode of action (FRAC group M1/2). General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous) Apply at 14 day intervals after petal fall. Repeat the application the next day if it rains immediately after the spraying programme. Stop application 7 months after the appearance of new leaves and resume application at the appearance of the next season's fruit
- Apply carbendazim and mancozeb at a rate of 40ml of carbendazim (eg Goldazim WP or Carbendazim 50WP) and 30g of mancozeb (eg Manzeb 800WP or Ivory 80WP) in 12L of water using a motorised mist blower. Carbendazim is a broad spectrum systemic fungicide belonging to FRAC group B1. Mancozeb is a protectant fungicide with multi-site mode of action (FRAC group M3). General Restrictions: Both fungicides are WHO Class III (slightly hazardous). Apply at 28 day intervals starting from petal fall. Stop application 7 months after petal fall and resume at the appearance of the next season's fruit

Authors.Surname: Asante K. Fred (MoFA-Brong Ahafo, Ghana),  phone no. 00233207638415,  email: fredasante@ymail.com

Sections.Value:
- Weed to prevent insect hideout:
- Wrap fruits when about golf size with paper bag to prevent fly attack.
- Harvest fruits early before ripening to reduce late infestation (reduce attraction by scent).
- Plough the soil under the tree to about 10-20cm deep to expose the pupae to sunlight and kill them. However, if there is not fruit fly infestation, then do not plough to reduce water loss.
- Frequently collect an infested fruits and bury (50-60cm) deep or feed to animals.

- For early detection hang Tephri Trap with (trimedlure or methyleugenol + DDVP) from March onwards
- Monitor orchard from April with traps made from a mineral water plastic bottle with two created openings on opposite sides for fly entry filled with a solution of sugar, orange juice, vinegar and water in the ratio of 2:1:1:10.
- Put grease on the trap holder to prevent ants from eating the catches. Consider action when 5-10 adult flies per trap per week.
- Inspect fruits in the orchard during the fruiting period every week Inspect fruits for soft black spotted ovi-punctures on the fruits weekly Dissect few infested fruits to confirm larvae at least once every month
- Consider action when 4-10 punctured or dropped fruits are found per pruned, trimmed tree.
- Or control measures might be considered when 5 to 15% of the plants in the orchard show signs of attack

- Mass bait flies using area-wide: traps with brewers yeast dissolved in water and placed in troughs around the plantation. 1 trap every 40m.
- Mass trap males flies using (parapheromone) methyl eugenol block + contact insecticide (commercially available)
- Hang sticky board traps every 20m for killing flies (change traps weekly)
- Apply bait spray such as GF120 at a ratio of 1:6 as spot application 1m2 to the underside of leaves. Repeat at 1-2 weeks interval
- Spray with fungal under trees with fungal pathogen Metarhizium anisopliae (isolate ICIPE 20) to control adults and the pre-pupal and pupal stages of the fly.

- Chemical sprays on tree canopies should be avoided because the pesticide cloud is dangerous to you. Wear protective clothing and spray with wind
- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains and water sources.
- Always consult the recent registered pesticide list from Environmental Protection Agency Accra, Ghana

- Use Hymlure, Nulure, Nasimen or Buminal at 90mls/15l of water. Start 6 weeks before expected harvest however, start earlier if traps indicate so. Use Dimethoate base product such as Dimex, 400EC per recommendations on the label. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class III (slightly acute hazardous). Toxic to bees; Pre-harvest interval p.h.i. 7 days. Dont spray in rainy days. Restricted re-entry interval r.e.i. day
- Use Novaluron + Deltamethrin- based products (such as Deltapaz; Rimon; Deltapaz; Lebaycid and others) as contact/broad spectrum spray against adult fruit fly during fruit development period until 30 days before harvesting. . General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class U+II (moderately acute hazardous); p.h.i. 14 days; RHI. 1 day; maximum two sprays per season. Spray far away from fishes, poultry and honey bees. Never spray flowering trees.

Sections.Value:
- Use resistant rice cultivars
- Before transplanting, cut the leaf-top to reduce carry-over of eggs from the seedbed to the field
- Practise early and synchronised planting to avoid damage at the most susceptible stages (tiller elongation and panicle extensions), and maintain proper crop spacing
- Avoid excess use of nitrogenous fertilizers as high rates favour population build-up
- Avoid water stagnation in the field
- Conserve natural enemies such as dragonflies, spiders, carabids beetles, parasitic wasps by reducing the amount of insecticides used
- Remove stubble, volunteer rice and wild grasses around nurseries and planting areas
- Harvest crops at ground level to remove the larvae in stubble
- After harvest, burn crop residues or feed to livestock
- Practise crop rotation (e.g. legumes/vegetables)

- Monitor weekly from seedling to harvest for the presence of the insect and damage symptoms:
Look for egg masses on the leaf tips and on the underside of the leaves
During vegetative stage, larvae bore at the base of the plants, killing growing points and resulting in deadheart (central tiller dries up and is easily pulled from the base)
During reproductive stage, larvae bore through the upper nodes and feed toward the base resulting in whiteheads (emerging panicles are whitish and empty)
Larvae leave tiny holes on the stems and tillers, and frass inside the damaged stems
- Damage may be confused with that caused by rats, neck blast or black bug diseases. To confirm stem borer damage, pull and dissected stems to find larvae or pupae
- Take control measures when 10-15% of plants/m2 show damage 40 days after planting

- Handpick and destroy egg masses at seedbed and transplanting stages
- After transplanting seedlings, place pheromone traps (@3/acre) or light traps (@12/acre) between 7-9pm to control adult moths in the field
- Raise level of irrigation water periodically to submerge the eggs deposited on the lower parts of the plant
- Spread or release natural enemies if available in your country such as the parasitoids Cotesiaspp., Trichogrammaspp., and Pediobius furvus
- Remove and destroy deadhearts and whiteheads
- Plough and flood after harvest to destroy dormant stem borer caterpillars
- Attacks result from infestation by more than one species and IPM programmes should be adapted according to differences in biology and ecology, and local conditions

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Authors.Surname: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies), Hannah Nuamah (PPRSD, MOFA)  Harunah Braimah (Council for Scientific and Industrial Research) and Maxwell Awuku (Chemico, Limited, Accra)

Sections.Value:
- Avoid termite-infested fields when selecting sites for field establisment
- Destroy termite hill in and around production site before planting
- Keep soil moist during the dry spells to distrupt termite activities
- Practice farm sanitation. Collect, burn, bury or compost plant debris. Do not import termite infested materials into fields
- Plant clean (termite-free) planting materials
- Avoid mulching in sites with potential termite infestation

- Additional relevant crops: maize, rice, sorghum, tomato, peppers
- Monitor fields regularly to check for termite infestation especially plants growing close to termite hills
- Look for damage signs: for example, mud and trails on stems
- Uproot young plants that fail to sprout to check for presence of termites
- Take action when you observe the presence of termites in field
- Dig up termite mounds to expose and kill the reproductives and destroy colonies

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
-  Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance, always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Spray Fipronil (Fipro 50 EC) at the rate of 100mls/15L). It is a Phenylprazole/Fiproles (IRAC, 2B). It is contact and stomach action. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Spray around the edges of the field to prevent termites from entering the crop, or spot treat infestations within the crop. Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 14 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and aquatic organisms.
- Sppray with Deltamethrin based product (e.g. Deltacan at 175-100mls/L. It is a pyrethroid - IRAC, 3A). General Restrictions: Slightly hazardous (WHO Class III); Maximum 2 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 14 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non target arthropods.Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near water ways

Sections.Value:
- Site selection; avoid termite-infested fields
- Destroy termitarium before planting
- Keep soil moist in the dry spell to discourage termite activities
- Inter-plant with termite repellent plants e.g basil (Ocimum spp.)
- Practice farm sanitation. Collect and burn/bury plant debrisafter harvest. Avoid importing termite infested materials into fields
- Avoid muching in termite infested fields

- Additional relevant crops: cassava, yam, rice, sorghum,tomato, peppers
- Visit farm regularly during off-season to check for termite colonies/mounds
- During cropping season, plants growing close to termite mounds should be given close attention for protection
- Look for damage signs: for example, mud on stems or lodging of plants
- Uproot young plants that show poor growth or stunting to check for termites
- Take action when you observe the presence of termites in field

- Dig up termite mounds to expose and kill the reproductives and destroy colonies
- Spread 1kg crushed neem leaves and/ water. 1 match box/1Lof water

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label. Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance. Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Spray Fipronil (Fipro 50 EC) at the rate of 100mls/15L) . It is a Phenylprazole /Fiproles (IRAC, 2B). Sections.Value:
- Use of clean, nematode-free planting material:
Before planting, inspect carefully each planting piece for dry rot symptoms by scraping away the skin
Use hot water treatment to reduce or eliminate nematodes from tubers (water temperature of 50-55C for up to 40 min)
Seed tubers showing symptoms of dry rot (cracking and flaking) should not be used for planting
- Coating the setts in wood ash may help to reduce nematode numbers
- Some crops should be avoided prior to planting yams or as yam intercrops, i.e. cowpea, sesame, green gram, pigeon pea, kenaf, okra, tomato and melon. Preference should be given to maize, groundnut, chilli, indian spinach or sorghum
- Add cow dung into the mound to reduce nematode populations (as do applications of NPK fertilizer and phosphorus alone, but nitrogen alone increases populations)
- Use legume cover crops as restorative fallows to reduce nematode populations (Aeschynomene histrix, Puerariaphas eoloides, Mucuna puriens and Centrosema spp.)
- Keep weeds to a minimum, especially those that are hosts of yam nematode, e.g. Eupatorium, Synedrella and Chromolaena
- Treat tubers after harvesting to prevent storage losses
- Removal of crop debris reduces soil populations nematode

- Monitor for symptoms:
- The feeding of the nematodes produces cavities
- The cavities become darker as the rot progresses (normally less than 2 cm)
- Externally, cracks appear in the skin, which becomes crinkly, and parts flake off revealing the dark rot beneath
- Rots continue in storage and can lead to complete decay of the tuber as other rot-causing organisms take over
- Extensive rots can develop without cracking and flaking of the skin, and are only seen when the skin is scraped away
- Sometimes external symptoms are not obvious on the tubers
- There are no above ground symptoms
- After harvest, all undersized and rotten tubers should be collected and buried deeply or burnt.

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Dry rot beneath the skin of white yam tubers (IITA, Flickr)

Sections.Value:
- Use resistant varieties if they are available in the region
- Select varieties that flower early or all flower at the same time as a long flowering period can significantly increase the midge population in an area
- Uniform planting (i.e. planting on the same day and at the same depth) to ensure even flowering, and early planting will reduce the damage caused
- Remove alternative hosts, such as wild sorghum, Johnson grass and Sudan grass, from in and around the field to prevent midge population build-up early in the season
- Plant at a high density to reduce the number of insects per plant or area
- Intercropping sorghum with a legume
- Destroy crop residues after harvest to prevent the pest from carrying over to the following season
- Rotate sorghum with non-host crops or leave the field fallow the next season to break the build-up of the pest in the field
- Conserve habitat (e.g. flowering plants on the borders of field) to build-up populations of natural enemies (parasitic wasps of the Eupelmus, Eupelmidae, Tetrastichus and Aprostocetus families)

- Monitor field weekly during the production season and daily during flowering as populations of midge begin to build-up during that period
Adult: mosquito-like appearance insect of about 3 mm long with a bright orange body, transparent wings and very long antennae. Count adult on flowering heads at about mid-morning
Eggs: very small, cylindrical and transparent light-red colour, and are deposited into the flowering spikelets
Young larvae: colourless, but turn dark-orange as they develop
- Larvae: feed on developing seeds causing malformation of the grain and empty or chaffy heads and blighted or blasted looking panicles (or heads)
Pupa: a small empty, clear or white pupa casing (or skin) is left attached to the tip of the spikelet and can be seen with the naked eye.
- Squeeze damaged spikelets between fingers to monitor the presence of larvae (they will produce red ooze as the larva or pupa being crushed)
- Take control measures when an average of one adult midge per head is observed after 20-30% of the heads begin to bloom
- Remove and destroy chaffy spikelets to stop the spread of the pest

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Severe S. sorghicola damage (above) (Keith M. Harris)

Sections.Value:
- Sources of infection are spores from other crops, weeds, infected tubers (sharing varieties between countries) spread via wind and rain. To prevent the disease:
- Use tolerant varieties
- Before planting, check each planting piece and discard parts with rots
- Plant early, ahead of the heaviest seasonal rains
- Early staking
- Plant maize around the crop
- Remove weeds that might be alternative hosts during the growth
- Avoid damaging tubers at harvest
- Avoid moving through the crop when the foliage is wet as this might spread the fungus
- If case of wind, avoid sprinkler irrigation
- Balance nitrogen fertilization
- Crop rotation; leave several years between two yam crops

- Monitor regularly for the disease, especially after several days of heavy rains, from 3 weeks after planting
- Symptoms vary according to the age of the leaf, the variety and the amount of rain:
Young leaf: small dark brown spots appear with yellow margins that expand rapidly and may merge to form large irregular blotches
Older leaf: presence of pinpoint spots that do not expand
New shoots: leaves and stems are infected and killed
Defoliation and stem dieback of young shoots
Blackening of older foliage and stems exposed to sunlight on susceptible varieties
Reduced tuber yields
On resistant varieties, only the young leaf veins are infected
- Take control measures when symptoms start to appear

- After harvest, collect the vines and burn or bury
- Destroy creepers after infections

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Symptoms on leaves (IITA, flickr.com)
Symptoms on leaves (IITA, flickr.com)

Sections.Value:
- The virus is spread by aphids and vegetative propagation:
Keep weeds to a minimum to avoid aphid population to build up and migrate to the crop
On farm, use yams for propagation only from the healthiest plants producing the largest tubers
- Only transfer yams in between countries following if necessary under official guidelines

- Monitor regularly for symptoms. If symptoms are detected, laboratory analyses are needed to confirm the disease
- A variety of symptoms are produced depending on the species and variety of yam:
Yellow and green patterns (mosaic) mostly between the veins or in narrow green strips bordering them (vein-banding)
In more severe case, distortion and strap-like leaves and the plants may also be stunted
Poor growth and smaller tubers than those from healthy plants

- After harvest, collect and destroy all plant debris. Do not use undersized tubers for planting
- Chemical control is not efficient for the control of this disease, as insecticide don't act quick enough to stop the aphids to transmit the virus

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Yellow and green patterns, distorted margin, and backward curling of a leaf infected with yam mosaic virus (IITA, Flickr)

Authors.Surname: Andrews Y. Akrofi (Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana)

Sections.Value:
- Avoid the wounding of cherelles (young pods) and pods during farm operations such as weeding and harvesting. Wounding makes pods susceptible
- Use improved planting materials from COCOBOD Seed Production Division
- Ensure proper farm husbandary practices, weeding, pruning etc.
- Ensure proper nutrition of cacao trees through fertilization (Conact COCOBOD for approved fertlizer list)
- Avoid transporting infected pods to uninfected areas

- Look out for pods with sooty black powdery substance (fungal spores). When infected pods are touched, a black charcoal-like substance is left on the fingers.
- Infected pods shrivel over time
- Monitor field all year round, but very conspicuous when trees are stressed in the dry season
- Remove or harvest infected pods as soon as observed
- This disease is of low economic importance and no chemical control measures are advised for its management

Factsheets.Title: Charcoal pod rot (Diplodia pod rot) of Cocoa

Authors.Surname: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies, Ghana), Antony Cudjoe (Private Consultant), Andrews Y. Akrofi (Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana)

Sections.Value:
- It is important to try and manage populations of mealybugs as they can damage cocoa plants as well as spread cocoa swollen shoot virus disease
- Remove chupons on a regular basis as these are succulent and attractive for mealybugs
- Remove or avoid planting trees which are known to harbour ants such as Canthium glabriflorum (Nteteadupon, gyapam).
- Mealybugs have a close relationship with attendant ants. The ants protect them from natural enemies and can also spread the mealybugs by carrying them from tree to tree. Ants feed on a sugary substance (honeydew) in this simbyotic relationship in return for their protection.

- Additional relevant crops: Kola, mango, avocado
- Mealybugs occur in colonies and cause damage to seedling, cherelles and shoots by sucking the sap from their tissues.
- Monitoring for mealy bugs should be done throughout the year but especially during August to April. Inspect trees twice a week when there are pods and when there are new shoots
- Check the entire plant for any white powdery or waxy material which are indicators of presence of mealybugs
- Also look out for sooty mould on the upper surfaces of leaves - a black powdery fungus which grows on the honeydew excreted by the mealybugs
- Take action when at least one plant is infested

- Reduce the number of ants in the field by destroying their nests
- Apply a potassium based soap such as alata samina in a solution with water to kill mealybugs. This can be applied using a knapsack sprayer.

- COCOBOD do not recommend using chemical insecticides for controlling mealybugs. Their waxy waterproof coating makes the use of contact pesticides ineffective - systemics can be used but create the risk of leaving residues

Images.Caption: Cocoa pod with mealybug infestation (E. Hidalgo, CABI)
Close up of adult female mealybugs (E. Hidalgo, CABI)

Authors.Surname: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies, Ghana), Antony Cudjoe (Private Consultant), Andrews Y. Akrofi (Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana)

Sections.Value:
- Select and use only borer-free seedlings and young plants for planting
- Alternative host plants of the Anacardiaceae (mango, cashew, etc.) family should be removed from the farm and surrounding fields, since they act as harbouring sites for borers.
- If planting cocoa consider using none hosts for fruit and shade trees
- Uproot and completely destroy damaged trees which serve as diapausing sites

- Monitoring should be carried out throughout the year on aweekly basis
- Inspect tree stems for entry holes and check for frass at the base of the tree or gum oozing out of the bore holes. Also look for discolouration on stems and shoots
- If in doubt, plants showing discolouration should be cut open to observe a white larva with a brown head and tunnels in the stem or branches
- When any bore holes are observed carry out control measures

- Plug bore holes with a stick to stop adult emerging
- Heavily infested (4-5 bore holes) branches can be removed and burned. Trees with higher infestation can be copiced. If the infestation is low in the stem the tree should be cut. If holes extend into the roots remove the roots too
- Chemical pesticides are not recommended by COCOBOD for management of this insect pest

Images.Caption: Bore hole created by the borer larva (Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana)
Bore holes can be plugge with a stick to stop the adults emerging (Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana)
An adult stem borer moth (Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana)

Authors.Surname: Andrews Y. Akrofi (Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana)

Sections.Value:
- Use improved planting materials from COCOBOD Seed Production Division
- Ensure proper nutrition of cacao trees through fertilization (contact COCOBOD for approved list and rates fertlizers)
- Ensure proper farm husbandary practices, weeding, pruning, etc.

- Look out for protrusions (lumps) on pods of all ages. Protrusions are of different sizes, ages and shapes on pods. Protrusions increase in size with the age of pod, turn yellow and then to dark brown lesions on ripened pods.
- Unlike Phythophthora infection on pods, the lesions are soft and are also without spores

- Remove infected pods as soon as observed
- Remove or harvest infected pods as soon as observed
- This disease is of low economic importance and no chemical control measures are advised for its management

Images.Caption: Ripe cocoa pod showing brown soft protrusions (A.Y. Akrofi, Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana)

Authors.Surname: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies), Hannah Nuamah (PPRSD, MOFA), Harunah Braimah (CSIR), Antony Cudjoe (Private Consultant), Maxwell Awuku (Chemico Ltd, Accra)

Sections.Value:
- Collect and burn all crop debris of previous seasons
- Use maize as a barrier crop around egg plant fields (establish 15 days before transplanting of eggplant)
- Use tolerant varieties round-shaped fruit bearing varieties have higher tolerance to this pest, e.g. Pusa purple round
- Plough harrow the field to expose dipausing pupae to sunlight to kill them

- Additional relevant crops: tomato, cotton
- Start monitoring for borers at the vegetative stage, look for drooping tender shoots and wilting;
- Observe for small holes below the calyx of fruits, presence of frass and larva inside the damaged shoots and fruits
- At the fruiting stage look for holes on fruits filled with insect excreta
- Take control action if 2% of plants or a minimum of 1% of fruit show symptoms

- Practice farm sanitation. Collect and burn infested shoots, twigs, fruits, fallen leaves and fallen fruits
- Spray Azadirachtin (0.03% EC) (neem-based insecticide) at 5ml / 1 litre water
- Sort out infested fruits and bury deep (3 ft) or burn them to kill the larvae
- Separate damaged pods at harvest and deep bury (3 ft) or destroy them to kill larvae
- Use light traps to capture adult moths

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label.
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance.
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Bt based product; Bypel 1 at arate of 55-550g/Ha (IRAC, 11A). General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 7-14 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non target arthropods.Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near water ways.
- Lamda-cyhalothrin based product (e.g Pawa) 35-40mls/ 15L of water. It is a sysnthetic pyrethroid (IRAC, 3A). It acts by contact. . General Restrictions: Slightly hazardous (WHO Class III); Maximum 2 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 14 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non target arthropods.Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near water ways.

Authors.Surname: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies), Hannah Nuamah (PPRSD, MOFA) and Harunah Braimah (CSIR)

Sections.Value:
- Plant resistant varieties
- Avoid planting close to Chromolaena odorata pickets
- Before planting, deep plough fields that are suspected to be infested to expose eggs to predators and heat of sun to dry out
- Clear the surroundings of weeds especially C. odorata to eliminate breeding sites
- Dig deep trenches around fields to trap and kill hoppers (e.g. by crushing)
- Planting materials chould be clean and from reliable source

- Additional relevant crops: maize, rice, cowpeas, peppers, potatoes, tomatoes, eggplants, Brassicas
- Conduct survey in the field for the presence of the grasshoppers as soon as planted cuttings start developing foliage
- During mating period (March to April), look for adults on Chromolaena plants in shady areas at the edge of cassava field.
- During hatching period (September- November), look for cream-coloured oval-shapes eggs and nymphs on Chromolaena and Calapogonium plants at edge of cassava field
- Best to control the pest in the early stage of their life cycle (nymph stage)
- When you see more than 20 to 30 grasshoppers per acre, or 1 egg mass per 5 plant stands, you may consider action.

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label.
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance.
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Spray with Cymethoate(Cypermethrin (36g/l) + Dimethoate (400g/l). 1-1.5Lit/Ha.Cpermethrin is a synthetic Pyrethroid (IRAC,3A). It is contact. Dimethoate is an Organophosphate (IRAC,1B). It is. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 7-14 days. REI 24 hours.Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non target arthropods.Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near water ways.
- Apply Dursban 4E at the rate of 75-100ml per 15L of water. It is an Organophosphate(IRAC, 1B). It is contact with stomach and respiratory action. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 14 days. REI 24 hours.Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non target arthropods.Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near water ways.
- Spray with Deltamethrin base product ( eg. Deltacan at175-100mls/L. It is a pyrethroid (IRAC, 3A). General Restrictions: Slightly hazardous (WHO Class III); Maximum 2 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 14 days. REI 24 hours.Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non target arthropods.Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near water ways.
