Authors.Surname: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies),  Antony Cudjoe (Private Consultant) and Maxwell Awuku (Chemico, Limited, Accra)

Sections.Value:
- Remove weeds, heavy mulches, and dense vegetative cover which provide rodents food and protection from predators and environmental stresses.
- Use weed-free strips to serve as buffers around areas requiring protection.
- Wire fences at least 12 inches above ground with a mesh size of 1/4 inch or smaller will help to exclude voles from the field
- Put metal guards around stands of storage structures to prevent rodents from climbing and entering stores

- Additional relevant crops: maize, rice, sorghum, yam, cassava, sweet potato
- Be alert for the presence of rats and mice both in production field and during storage. Look for fresh trails in the grass, burrows, droppings, furs and evidence of feeding in the field and stores
- Pay particular attention to adjacent areas that have heavy vegetation, because such areas are likely sources of invasions.
- Frequently check protective devices to make sure meadow mice havent gnawed through or dug beneath the cylinders and are hiding inside the tree guard while they feed on the tree.
- Take action when evidence of rodent presence as outlined above is clear

- Trap and destroy rodents using locally made traps baited with peanut butter-fish meal mixture. Place traps at right angles to runaways with the trigger end on the runaway.
- Use predators such as dogs and cats to to reduce rodent population in the area
- Rodents can also be killed by hunting using catapults, and bows and arrows
- Rodenticides are available but are classed as highly hazardous by WHO and so are not recommended here.

Images.Caption: Adult mouse (IRRI)

Authors.Surname: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies), Hannah Nuamah (PPRSD, MOFA) and  Harunah Braimah (Council for Scientific and Industrial Research)

Sections.Value:
- Plant yam later in the seson (March-April) instead of earlier (Nov-Dec) to avoid beetle outbreak period
- Yam farms should not be sited near swampy areas which serve as breeding sites for the beetles
- Do not stotre infested tubers for next season as this will serve as source of infestation, sort them out for sale or consumption
- Ensure sufficiently long fallow period between yam croppings
- Remove alternative host plants such as false yam, nutgrass and water lilies from the site
- Remove alternative host plants such as false yam and other edible root crops

- Additional relevant crops: sweet potato, water lilies, nutgrass, cocoyam
- Yam beetles usually migrate from the breeding sites (swampy areas) to the yam farms where both adults and larvae feed on tubers
- Monitor the movement of adult beetles from June to October by installing light traps in yam farm (1 traps/100m2)
- Take direct control action when an average of 2 beetles are found using the light trap

- Use light traps hunged in a tripod and container with water placed below them to trap and kill the migrating beetles
- Dust yam setts with ash during storage to repel and reduce population of beetles in barns

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label.
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance. Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Treat yam setts with neem seed extract Rate: 1 match box of dry seed/1litre of water. General Restrictions: See general pesticide restrictions
- Dip yam setts in insecticide solution (Deltamethrin + Pyrethroid) Rate: 66ml/11 litres. IRAC 3A,Contact. Treated setts can only be used as planting materials . General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 14 days. REI 24 hours.Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non target arthropods.Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near water ways.

Images.Caption: An adult yam beetle (G. Georgen, IITA)
Beetle damage on yam tubers (Dr Stephen Kwaku Asante, CSIR-Savanna Agricultural Research Institute)

Sections.Value: - Use mesh or net barriers to keep the pest out of the crop when possible

- Start monitoring when the chilli fruits start developing as the larvae only attack the fruits
- Insect:
Eggs are less than 1 mm long, oval, flattened and difficult to see. They are laid singly or in group on the developing fruits
Larvae are yellowish-white when young with dark spots. The full grown larva is about 15 mm long, bright red or pink, with a yellow-brown head. The young larvae mine fruit just beneath the surface, or bore into the skin causing premature ripening of the fruit
The pupa (5-7 mm long) is contained within a tough silken cocoon and can be seen in the soil or amongst plant debris
Adult moths are 15-16 mm (males) and 19-20 mm (female) in length. Forewings have grey, brown, black and orange-brown markings. False codling moth can look similar to other moths but can be distinguished by the triangular marking near the edges of the wings
- Open fallen fruits to detect the presence of the larvae. It is important to destroy the fruits after inspection by burning or burying to a depth of 60-90 cm
- Monitor adults with traps baited with a pheromone attractant and inspect the traps each week. If any moths are detected once the fruits are developing, take control measures immediately

- Control is difficult because the moth has many alternative hosts so reinfestation is likely to occur
- Hand pick the mature larvae from the crop
- If available, spray a mating disruption pheromone into the crop to stop the males and females from mating
- Destroy fruits that are infested and have fallen to the ground to reduce the build-up cycle and avoid carrying over the pest to the next season. Put the fruits in plastic bags and expose them to the sunlight, or burn and bury to a depth of 60-90 cm

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Larva T. leucotreta (Tertia Grov, Institute for Tropical and Subtropical Crops, Bugwood.org)
Pupa T. leucotreta (J.H. Hofmeyr, Citrus Research International, Bugwood.org)
Adult T. leucotreta (Todd M. Gilligan and Marc E. Epstein, TortAI: Tortricids of Agricultural Importance, USDA APHIS ITP, Bugwood.org)

Sections.Value:
- Use resistant and open pollinated varieties
- Use certified/disease free seed
- Sow seed early as this tends to result in less downy mildew than seed sown late in the season
- Practice crop rotation to avoid infection from soil-borne resting spores
- Avoid watering in the evening to avoid leaf wetness and humidity which encourages fungal growth
- Leave as much space as possible between crop plants and weed regularly to avoid dense growth and resulting transfer of spores
- Transplant the crop rather than direct sow, both in rainy and post-rainy seasons

- Hosts also include Setaria italica (foxtail millet) and wild grasses
- Crops should be monitored carefully, particularly during the first month after sowing
- Monitor for symptoms. Symptoms first appear on the first or second leaf that forms:
Leaves: yellow at base and green above ('half-leaf' symptom). Yellow area becomes larger as new leaves develop and can have a downy appearance, particularly on the lower surface
Whole plant: stunted and lacks flowers, or parts of the flower head become leaf-like ('green ear' symptom)
- Severe infection can cause plant death
- Control infestation as soon as it is identified to limit the number of oospores (resistant spores produced by S. graminicola) left in the soil. These can survive from a few months up to 10 years

- Promptly burn plants with symptoms to reduce accumulation of spores in soil
- Plow the field deeply (to at least 20 cm) to bury the infected plant material

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Sporulation on underside of infected pearl millet leaf produces a downy white growth (Rob Williams, CABI)
Deformed flower head of pearl millet caused by internal infection by downy mildew (Rikhab Raj-Bhansali, CAZRI, www.bugwood.org)
Typical symptoms of systemic downy mildew  (Rob Williams, CABI)

Sections.Value:
- Use resistant varieties if available
- Use certified/clean seed to reduce the risk of contamination
- Delay planting until seasonal rains have set in to reduce host plant water loss
- Intercropping can shade and surpress Striga e.g. use Desmodium, beans, cowpeas, groundnuts or green grams for maize
- Grow trap crops, such as cotton, cowpea, pearl millet and soyabean for S. asiatica. These stimulate Striga seed germination, but do not become infected, causing Striga to die
- Improve soil fertility and therefore crop stand using organic, inorganic, or green manure fertilizer for long-term control
- Irrigate crop during dry periods so plants do not get stressed, but prevent runoff water from infested land to avoid seed introduction as they are transported by water
- Keep farm tools, machinery and feet clean to prevent spread of seed
- Limit movement of livestock in infested areas as seed can spread via their hooves and gut

- Affected crops include: maize, sorghum, millets, upland rice, cowpea and sugarcane
- Most species of Striga have bright green leaves and stems 30-100 cm high, with bright (purple, pink, red, orange, yellow, white) flowers and poorly developed roots
S. gesnerioides is totally parasitic, with small, unexpanded leaves and a cluster of fleshy, pale-green or yellow shoots, 10-20 cm high
- Symptoms appear before the appearance of Striga above the ground
- Look out for crop plants which are stunted, yellow, scorched and wilted even when the soil is moist. These symptoms are similar to nutritional deficiencies or drought
- Regularly (at least every two weeks) check for Striga flowers and seed development to prevent seed set, spread and build up of seed bank in the field. Take action as soon as one Striga plant is seen

- Continously uproot and burn crop stubble and Striga, before flowering and seed setting to reduce seed bank
- Hand pull the larger species, such as S. hermonthica, if populations are low, but not S. asiatica, which is much smaller and has seeds that mature and shed faster
-

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Striga hermonthica flowering on maize (USDA APHIS PPQ Archive, www.bugwood.org)
Striga gesnerioides parasitizing roots of cowpea (Rob Williams, CABI)
Flowers of Striga hermonthica (International Institute of Tropical Agriculture, Flickr)

Sections.Value:
- Before planting, check if resistant varieties are available locally
- Plant early, as soon as weather conditions allow; this will minimize yield and grain quality losses as the crop will have matured before maximum disease development
- Rotate with non-host crops such as sorghum and legumes
- During crop growth, remove volunteer plants and weeds - grasses in particular; do not plant near eggplant or its weed relatives, e.g. Solanum torvum (turkey berry). These plants are hosts of P. substriata
- After harvest, collect and bury crop remains

- Additional relevant crops: Solanum hosts (eggplant, turkey berry). Wild grasses are also hosts
- Look out for:
Small green to yellow, slightly raised spots that develop over the leaf surface, with more on the topside than the underside
The spots growing larger, up to 2 mm, and rising further from the surface of the leaf, developing into reddish-orange pustules, round to elliptical, with yellow halos
Masses of spores (urediniospores) that form in the pustules and spread the rust within and between crops
Later, as the pustules age they become darker as another spore type (teliospores) appears; the leaves start to die from the tips towards the base. The teliospores have thick walls and this helps them survive in the soil
Spots on the stems, indicating that the infection is severe. The plants may fall over (lodge)
- The disease is favoured by cool nights (15-20C) and warm days (25-34C) as this promotes abundant dew on the foliage, thus the development of the disease

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Reddish-brown (rust coloured) spots, with yellow halos, producing masses of spores which spread between pearl millet plants (Vivek Gupta)

Sections.Value:
- Obtain healthy, disease-free seedlings from nurseries. If possible, use material produced in registered nurseries
- Avoid the establishment of nurseries in humid places with poor ventilation. The substratum should have been physically treated to eliminate soil-borne pathogens, for example through solarisation
- Maintain a thick layer of mulch (straw) at the base of the tree under the canopy to improve soil structure, plant nutrition, and reduce phytosanitary problems
- Keep trees healthy by avoiding stress such as high salt levels or a lack of water or nutrients
- Prune trees and remove dead leaves and wood in the canopy. Prune and harvest only during the dry season (avoid harvesting during the rainy season or shortly thereafter)
- Harvest the fruits to a level of optimum maturity as the unripe fruits develop rots easily
- Disinfection of cutting tools, knives and scissors during pruning (10% bleach)
- Control other diseases or insects that injure the trunk, leaves and fruits

- Monitor regularly during the development of fruits for symptoms
Fruits: light decay begins as slight shrivelling around the stem button and spreads until everything inside the fruit rots
Brown necrosis at grafting union, which advances downwards and results in dead tops to the trees

- Dispose of old wood and fruits away from trees
- Minimize the time between harvest and storage (less than 6 hours). To reduce the incidence of the disease, store rapidly at 5C and control the temperature and postharvest conditions (hot and dry)

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Decayed fruit (David Rosen, UC Statewide IPM Program, University of California)

Sections.Value:
- Sow the new crops as far away as possible from, and upwind of, older ones, especially if they are infected by leaf spots, in order to avoid disease spread
- Use resistant, early yielding varieties which yield in the shortest time to avoid the disease
- Remove volunteer plants and weeds to reduce humidity and chances of infection
- Deeply bury or burn plant debris after harvest, or feed it to animals
- Leave at least one year between crops planted on the same land

- Early leaf spot is more common at first. This is gradually overtaken by late leaf spot, which produces more spots and more loss of leaves as the crop matures. (A hand lens or microscope is required to differentiate the diseases)
- Look out for:
Oval spots on leaves, particularly the older leaves (this is the first symptom that appears, usually 45-60 days after sowing):
Early leaf spots are reddish-brown on the upper surface surrounded by a yellow halo and brown on the lower leaf surface
Late leaf spots are dark brown to black, usually with a smaller halo or without one. Dense spores form ring patterns on the undersurface
Spots also appear on the stems and petioles
Leaf and pod loss
- Temperatures of 25-30C and 6-8 hours of high humidity are needed for infection and disease development
- If plants are infected, remove and bury or burn deep in the soil. Do not compost

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Early leaf spot (left) and late leaf spot (right) on lower surfaces of leaves (Jill M. Lenn/ICRISAT)

Authors.Surname: Dr J .E. Sarfo, Cocoa Research Institute Ghana (CRIG). Reviewed and modified by Dr R. Adu-Acheampong (CRIG) August 2015

Sections.Value:
- Plant tolerant hybrids from COCOBOD authorised seed gardens (commonly called mixed hybrids)
- Remove chupons (green basal/side growths) as these are succulent and attractive both as feeding and egg-laying sites
- Remove alternative host plants such as young silk cotton trees and kola (Cola spp.)

- Mirids are found throughout the year especially duning August to April. They cause damage to seedling, cherelles and shoots by sucking the sap from their tissues
- Feeding puncture marks appear as water-soaked patches that turn black after 2-3 days. On young pods these are usually black round lesions near the stalk facing the trunk and the pods wilt. Feeding on shoots and stems can cause splits (cankers) and die back.
- Inspect cocoa plants up to hand height monthly for the presence of mirids and feeding lesions on pods and shoots
- Monthly examinations of whole plants for lesions on fan branches and die back (browning of leaves on branches from the tip down)
- Monthly inspection of broken cocoa canopies for mirids and lesions on fresh chupons
- Damage on mature pods over three months old is not important but spray when average numbers reach 6 mirids per 10 trees

- Maintain continuous but well pruned canopy as broken canopy allows sunlight to reach the forest floor and promotes fresh chupon (new shoots) growth which attracts mirids.
- If the canopy is broken replace dead trees or plant plantain as it grows quickly and closes the canopy

- Wear protective clothing, hat, overall, gloves, goggles, nose mask, boots
- Do not eat, drink or smoke during application
- Do not spray near streams or rivers or wash spray equipment in running/drinking water

- The pesticides listed below can be used to manage mirids on cocoa. Other approved pesticide options are available please contact staff from COCOBOD or CRIG. . General Restrictions: Apply using a motorised mistblower on monthly basis beginning from August to December omitting November (to avoid contamination of beans at peak harvest). Spraying can be carried out in Jan-July when mirid numbers and damage is high - 2 applications at monthly intervals. For infested areas/pockets spot spraying can be carried out.
- Actara 240 SC (Thiamethoxam) Rate: 17ml/11litres or 85ml/ha. . General Restrictions: WHO Class III (slightly hazardous) Systemic, IRAC group 4 neonicotinoid
- Confidor 200 SL (Imidacloprid) Rate: 30ml/11litres or 150ml/ha. . General Restrictions: WHO Class II (moderately hazardous) Systemic, IRAC group 4 neonicotinoids
- Akate Master (Bifenthrin) Rate: 100ml/11litres or 500ml/ha. . General Restrictions: WHO Class II (moderately hazardous) Contact, IRAC group 3 pyrethroids
- Miricon EC (Deltamethrin + Pyrethrum) Rate: 66ml/11 litres or 330ml/ha. . General Restrictions: WHO Class II (moderately hazardous) Both contact, IRAC group 3 pyrethroids

Images.Caption: Adult black capsid, D. theobroma (Nick Jessops, courtesy of CRIG)
Feeding damange caused to pods by mirids (Courtesy of CRIG)
Mirid feeding lesions on cocoa stems (Courtesy of CRIG)

Sections.Value:
- Plant on land not previously cropped to plantain
- Use pest-free planting material from a reliable source e.g. tissue culture bananas from a certified institute or farm
- To ensure pest free suckers are used, pare suckers by trimming off excess roots and washing off soil with clean water or dip in hot water (53-55C) for approximatey 15-20 minutes
- Reduce movement of infested planting material and soil from one point to another
- Till and harrow land to expose soil to solar energy to kill nematodes
- Rotate with maize or cassava for at least one season to reduce populations
- Remove alternative hosts/weeds

- Monitor frequently starting from when suckers get established. Look for symptoms such as:
Necrosis on corms and roots 6 months after planting, toppling of plantain
Slow plant growth, reduced size and number of leaves and delayed fruiting
Reduced productive life of the plantation
- Sample soil and roots and extract nematodes using water or take soils to a laboratory for soil analysis
- Take action when 300 nematodes are counted per 1g of root (Do not rely on the ratoon crops, uproot suckers)

- Support plantain plants stakes from flowering up to harvesting to prevent toppling
- Highly infested plantain should be removed and destroyed by chopping and burn or bury in a deep pit
- Use soil amendments such as manure and compost to increase the water and nutrient holding capacity of the soil to make plants more tolerant to nematodes
- Mulch heavily with organic waste e.g. cocoa pod husk
- Nematicides are not recommended for smallholder farmers as they are generally very toxic and often require specilist equipment for application

Images.Caption: Symptoms of nematode damage to the root system (Scot Nelson, www.flickr.com)

Factsheets.Title: Nematodes on plantain
ScientificNames: Pratylenchus spp., Helicotylenchus spp., Meliodogyne spp., Rotylenchulus spp., Radopholus spp.

Authors.Surname: Benjamin K. Badii ( University for Development Studies, Ghana) and  Antony Cudjoe (Private Consultant)

Sections.Value:
- Use clean planting materials: transplant only healthy, vigorous insect-free seedlings
- Dispose off crop residues: uproot and burn tomato stalks after harvest
- Crop rotate or intercrop with non-host crops (e.g mustard, onion, carrot) to reduce field populations by webworms
- Avoid use of chemical insecticides to help conserve natural enemies of webworm such as spiders, parasitic wasps, lacewings, praying mantis, ants, and birds
- Till soil to remove tomato stubbles and dispose out of field before planting

- Additional relevant crops: okro, eggplant, cabbage
- Start monitoring at seedling stage or shortly after transplanting into the field
-  Inspect plants for egg masses, eggs are usually laid in plant buds, upon hatching, the larvae feed on the underside of the leaves and cover themselves with webs, which become covered with dirt and excrement
- Check plants for adults and caterpillars twice a week as soon as seedling emergence begins
- Normally, spraying should occur when there is more than 1 caterpillar per 5 plants.

- Hand pick and destroy caterpilars which are usually found underside leaves at initial (lower) infestations
- Webworm populations can be reduced by ploughing under weeds at least one month prior to planting
- Use botanical pesticide (e.g. fresh neem, lemongrass, ginger) at rate of 1 litre/15 litres of water

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label.
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance, always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Spray with Emamectin benzoate product ( eg Control 5% WDG, Protect 1.9 EC) at the rate of 0.5 ml/l water, Avermectin family group. General Restrictions: WHO class II (moderately hazardous) Yellow colour band; REI- when spray dries; PHI-3 days.
- Spray with Imidacloprid product (eg Consider super 200 SL, Condifor Super) at 200g/l . General Restrictions: WHO class II (moderately hazardous). Contact systemic pesticide, Maximum number of treatments: one per season . Treated plants are harmful to humans and wildlife. PHI is 10 days
- Spray with Lambda-cyhalothrin product (eg. Frankocylon 2.5 EC, Karate 5 EC, K-Lambda 2.5 EC, Lambdacot EC, K-Optimal EC) at rate of 20-50g/l. General Restrictions: WHO class II (moderately hazardous). Contact systemic. Yellow colour band; REI- when spray dries; PHI-3 days.

Webworm adult (David Agassiz)

Authors.Surname: Benjamin K. Badii ( University for Development Studies, Ghana) and  Antony Cudjoe (Private Consultant)

Sections.Value:
- Disposal of crop residues; uproot and burn cabbage stalks after harvest
- Crop rotation or intercropping with non-host crops (e.g mustard, onion, carrot) to reduce field populations of webworm
- Avoid use of chemical insecticides to help conserve natural enemies of the cabbage webworm including spiders, parasitic wasps, lacewings, praying mantis, ants, and birds
- Till soil to remove cabbage stubbles and and dispose out of field before planting

- Additional relevant crops: okro, eggplant
- Field monitoring should begin 2 weeks after planting tomato.
- Inspect plants for egg masses, eggs are usually laid in plant buds, which upon hatching, the larvae feed on the underside of the leaves and cover themselves with webs, which become covered with dirt and excrement.
- Check plants for adults and caterpillars twice a week once seedling emergence begins, when populations appear to be increasing, check more often
- Normally, spraying should occur when there is more than 1 caterpillar per 5 plants.

- Hand pick and destroy caterpilars on the undersides of leaves at initial (lower) infestations
- Cutworm populations can be reduced by plowing under weeds at least one month prior to planting
- Use botanical pesticide (e.g. fresh neem, lemongrass, ginger) 1 litre/15 litres of water
- Use Spinosad bait spray, the maximum amount that can be used per crop is 0.45 lb ai/A at 2 day PHI

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label.
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance, always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Spray with Abamectin benzoate product ( eg Control 5% WDG, Protect 1.9 EC ) at the rate of 0.5 ml/l water, Avermectin family group. General Restrictions: WHO class II (moderately hazardous) Yellow colour band; REI- when spray dries; PHI-3 days.
- Spray with Imidacloprid product (eg Consider super 200 SL) at 200g/l . General Restrictions: WHO class II (moderately hazardous). Contact systemic pesticide, PHI-3 days
- Spray with Lambda-cyhalothrin product (eg. Frankocylon 2.5 EC, Karate 5 EC, K-Lambda 2.5 EC, Lambdacot EC, K-Optimal EC) at rate of 20-50g/l. General Restrictions: WHO class II (moderately hazardous) Yellow colour band; REI- when spray dries; PHI-3 days.

Images.Caption: Webworm larvae and damage on cabbage leaf (Judy Baxter, www.flickr.com)
Cabbage webworm adult (Ben Sale, www.flickr.com)

Sections.Value:
- The disease is spread by virus-infected budwood or plants; use only disease-free propagation material from certified nurseries. Use tolerant scions if available such as Mandarin and Valencia orange
- When using budwood, ensure that they are budded onto rootstocks that are resistant/tolerant to CTV such as sweet orange, Cleopatra mandarin, rough lemon, Rangpur lime and trifoliate orange
- It is also spread by several species of aphids, but the most efficient vector is Toxoptera citricidus, the brown citrus aphid:
In nurseries, maintain good aphid control and keep trees under a screen to help keep the vector out of the planting material
Control weeds under trees and in the field to eliminate host plants for the aphids

- The following three syndromes and the severity of their symptoms vary depending on the CTV isolate, environmental conditions and hosts:
Stem pitting (mostly grapefruit): it does not kill trees, but causes a thin canopy, fewer fruits of reduced size and quality, deep pits in the trunk and stem and, in severely affected trees, dieback
Seedling yellowing (inoculated grapefruit, lemon and sour orange seedlings): dwarfing and general chlorosis
Decline (sour orange rootstock): in slow decline, wilting and chlorosis of the canopy, an abnormal crop of small fruits persisting after death of the tree and many small conical pits on the face of the bark surface (honeycombing). Trees affected by quick decline lack honeycombing, but frequently show a yellow-brown stain at the bud union
- Roots: necrotic streak or lesions, deterioration
- Remove a patch of bark across the bud union from declining trees to look for small pits (honeycombing)
- Inspect the orchards regularly for symptoms if the area is susceptible or at risk to the CTV, and more often during high aphid population periods
- CTV can be confused with diseases such as citrus blight (no bud union symptoms) and citrus greening (no stem pitting)

- Control strategies for CTV differ according to the incidence and severity of the isolates in a particular area and with the cultivars and rootstocks used. No single strategy is applicable to all situations
- Remove infected trees immediately to avoid spreading the disease and maintain surveillance
- Chemical control of aphids in the field is not recommended as it is an unproven strategy for CTV control and insecticides may not act quickly enough to prevent infection
- There are no treatments available to reverse the decline in affected trees on sour orange rootstocks

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Dieback of sweet orange grafted on sour orange (L. Navarro, Instituto Valenciano de Investigaciones Agrarias, Bugwood.org)
Stem pitting (Florida Division of Plant Industry Archive, Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services, Bugwood.org)
Honeycombing on lemon rootstock (S.D. Sawant)

Sections.Value:
- Use resistant/tolerant varieties if available
- Use certified/disease-free seed
- Select a planting date which prevents flowering coinciding with periods of high humidity, which favours blast disease
- Plant at the same time as neighbouring farmers to avoid spread of blast from older infected crops to younger
- Do not plant crop downwind from an infected field. The disease can spread via wind
- Do not allow irrigation water from infected fields to run into uninfected/healthy fields since the disease can spread via water
- During crop growth, avoid any cultural practices that weaken the plants and make them more susceptible to disease:
If applying nitrogen, divide the application into two or three splits, rather than applying it all at once
Avoid water stress, or extended drain periods. Flood the field as often as possible

- Monitor regularly for symptoms when temperatures between day and night cause dew to form on the leaves and the overall temperatures are cooler
- Leaves: oval or diamond-shaped spots (5-15 mm long and 3-5 mm wide) with white centres and dark borders. Often the spots have yellow halos
As they age, the spots become longer, the centres turn whitish-grey and the borders become wider and red-brown
The spots join together and the leaves die
Spots develop quickly under moist conditions
- Seeds: may not be produced or have brown spots/blotches and occasionally the diamond-shaped lesions as seen on leaves
- Sheath, stem and panicle: rots may appear. There are several different types of rot:
Collar rot - appears at the junction of leaf base and leaf sheath; this can kill the leaf
Neck rot (rotten neck) - appears on the stem below the panicles (flower heads) and can destroy the stem or result in pale-coloured grains that are partly filled, known as whiteheads
Panicle rot - occurs on the branches of the panicle so that it appears brown or black
Node rot - occurs on the stem below the panicles, the rots become black-brown and dry and, if the stem breaks, the plant dies
- Severely infected fields have a scorched appearance
- Eliminate crop residues as soon as possible after harvest, to reduce the possibility of the fungus surviving to infect crops of the next seasons plantings

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Diamond-shaped lesions on the leaves of rice (IRRI Photos, Flickr)
Rice blast may attack the stem at the nodes (IRRI Photos, Flickr)

Sections.Value:
- Plant mixtures of cultivars with different levels of resistence and similar stage of maturity to minimise losses
- Sow early (7-10 days before the onset of monsoon rains) so that crop growth does not coincide with high shoot fly populations
- Encourage high density growth to reduce shoot fly damage:
Use a high seeding rate. Seedlings under high planting density have narrow leaves, which are less attractive for egg laying
Delay thinning of crop
- Grow a healthy crop to reduce shoot fly damage:
Grow seedlings in a nursery under high planting density before transplating
Apply nitrogenous and phosphatic fertlizers. Do not use cattle manure as the resulting odour may attract shoot flies
Maintain optimum irrigation
- Remove and burn weeds which act as hosts of shoot fly, such as grasses: Johnson grass, (Sorghum halepense), Brachiaria, Cynodon, Echinochloa, Eragrostis, Panicum, Pennisetum, Setaria
- Encourage natural enemies population (egg parasitoids and predators) by decreasing the amount of pesticides used in the fields
- Rotate or intercrop with cotton, groundnut, sunflower, sugarcane or legumes
- Collect and burn sorghum stubbles
- Let the land lie fallow for 2 months in the warmer part of the year. This reduces the carryover and build-up of pest populations from one season to the next
- Soil may contain pupae so should not be moved around

- Additional relevant crops: maize, finger millet, bullrush millet, rice, wheat
- Look out for symptoms:
Young plants: Damage at 5-30 days after seedling emergence. The central leaf dries up forming a deadheart - it becomes thin and papery, and wraps around the other leaves. The damaged leaf can be pulled out easily and produces a rotting smell
Older plants (>30 days after seedling emergence, >35 to 45 cm in height): Do not produce deadheart symptoms. They may have damaged leaf margins or partially damaged panicles with a portion which is rotting or dried up
Plants: Produce axillary tillers due to stress
- Insect:
Eggs: Laid on the underside of seedling leaves or on young tillers. 1-3 eggs are laid per leaf. They are white, elongated and measure 0.8 x 0.2 mm
Larva: 8-10 mm long when full grown, whitish/yellowish in colour. They crawl down inside the sheath and bore into the base of the young shoot, killing the growing point and youngest leaf (causing deadheart)
Pupa: Reddy-brown, 8-10 mm long. Found in the base of the dead shoot or in the soil
Adults: rest on the underside of leaves. About 4 mm long and look like small house flies
- Assess infestation level using yellow sticky traps or a fishmeal baited square pan/plastic jar to catch adults. Alternatively, count the number of infested "hearts" in young sorghum plants
- Shoot flies are abundant during the rainy season under moderate temperatures and high humidity
- Check crop for shoot fly damage while thinning and destroy damaged plants

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Sorghum shoot fly egg on the undersurface of the leaf; the damaged plant showing typical deadheart symptoms (H.C. Sharma/ICRISAT)
Atherigona soccata adult (Georg Goergen/IITA Insect Museum, Cotonou)
Atherigona soccata larvae (H.C. Sharma/ICRISAT)

Sections.Value:
- Plant early-maturing varieties and time harvesting so that harvests occur before maximum rat populations
- Encourage owls to hunt in the field by placing owl nesting boxes nearby
Before doing this, check with the local community
Cats are not very effective (they do not necessarily kill rats, just frighten them away)
- Remove weeds within and around sweet potato fields so rats cannot hide from predators
- Place cow dung and pepper in rat burrows to smoke out the rodents
- Pour one-week old fermented cattle urine into burrows to chase away mole rats
- Dig deep ditches around sweet potato plantings to stop rodents from tunnelling straight into the field
- After harvest of sweet potato crops, collect the debris and bury or burn it; importantly, do not leave immature or broken storage roots in the field for rats to eat
- Protect the harvest in storage from rat infestations

- Additional relevant crops: rice, maize, squash e.g. pumpkin, various root vegetables, stored fruits e.g. apples
- Look out for bite marks in sweet potato and missing chunks. Rats dig through mounds or ridges to eat crops, or attack crop when exposed above ground
- Rat outbreaks tend to occur when there is:
A long rainy season that provides more food and cover, allowing better survival
A reduction in competition from other rat species, predators and disease, when there is a return to rains after consecutive dry years
Early breeding, when unusually heavy rains occur during the rainy season and the offspring join the main breeding season population later in the year
- Rats live above ground and nest on or in the ground or in trees, depending on the species
- Mole rats burrow into the soil, eating storage roots from below. They live and breed in underground burrows
- Set traps (snap, snare or live), although care must be taken to protect livestock and children from being hurt by them

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Natal multimammate rat, Mastomys natalensis (William T. Stanley, Negaunee Collection Manager, Mammals, The Field Museum of Natural History)

Factsheets.Title: Rats and mole rats of sweet potato

Sections.Value:
- Plant early in the season, or use early-maturing varieties, so that harvest can be completed before the dry season when the soil dries and crack (weevils reside in cracks)
- Cuttings: vine-tips should be clean, especially the tender tips (the top 25-50 cm). Treat using a pre-plant dip to provide control for the first few months:
Dip the cuttings into a solution of the fungus Beauveria bassiana for 10-15 minutes prior to planting
- Avoid using tubers for planting as they may contain weevil larvae
- Use deep rooting varieties with long necks - adult weevils cannot burrow below 1 cm
- Maintain deep root depth; use a hoe to create a small hill or mound of soil around the base of the plant and re-ridge about 30 days after planting. Or use a ground cover such as straw or plastic
- Irrigate regularly to prevent the soil from drying and cracking
- Encourage generalist predators of the weevil e.g. ants, spiders, carabids, and earwigs by planting hedgerows
- Remove alternative host plants (e.g. morning glory, wild spinach, wild Ipomoea) and volunteer plants from in and around the field
- Plant new sweet potato crop at least 1 km away from infested fields (weevils cannot easily fly from field to field)
- Harvest as soon as crop is mature and avoid piecemeal harvesting
- Rotate with a non-host crop, such as sorghum, rice or legumes, for 2 or 3 seasons

- Additional relevant crops: coffee, morning glory, sesame, cowpea, maize
- Monitor for weevils early in the crop season:
Eggs: Yellowish-white, shiny and oval-shaped
Pupae: 5-6 mm long and initially creamy white but become grey as they get older
Larvae: chunky white legless grubs, about 5-10 mm long and slightly curved; the head is brown or light yellow
Adults: black and shiny blue with long slender bodies (6-8 mm long), and a long snout with antennas on both sides. Adults are mostly active at night and hide under leaves or in soil cracks during the day
- Look out for signs of the weevil:
Young plants (before storage roots form): small tunnels in lower base of stem where larvae feed. Also, adults can be found on the leaves and vines, leaving small round feeding holes
Storage root: tunnels which become brown, soft and spongy. The damaged tissue has a bad smell
Stems: turn yellow, crack, and wilt. This can cause seedlings to die. Look for feeding holes and larvae tunnels at the base (lower 10 cm) of the stems
If damage to the stems is detected, dig up the roots of a few plants and inspect the surface of the roots for deep feeding punctures and cavities plugged with frass, and inspect the tunnels for larvae
- Place pheromone traps in the field at a radius of 280 m to catch the weevils
- Dry and hot temperatures between 27-30C favour the development of weevils

- During crop growth, remove all infested sweet potato vines and storage roots and destroy by feeding to livestock or burning. Do not bury remains as weevils can still survive and do not store remains near fields
- After harvest, flood the field for 24 hours after harvest to drown and kill the weevils
- Destroy all remains of the old crop and volunteer plants, particularly infested vines and tubers
- Do not store roots that show symptoms with non-infested roots. Weevils can continue to cause damage during post-harvest storage

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Adult sweet potato weevil (Edwin M Escobar, Flickr)
A cut sweet potato showing larvae in tunnels (Scot Nelson, Flickr)
Sweet potato weevil larva (Peter A.C. Ooi/CABI BioScience)

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), F. C. Brentu (University of Ghana)

Sections.Value:
- Control of this bacterial disease relies on good cultural practices and other preventive methods
- Avoid planting cabbage on land with continuous history of cabbage for two years
- Remove and destroy by burning volunteer and leftover plants
- Avoid causing injuries to plants when working on plants to reduce mechanical transmission
-  Avoid clustered areas where farmers plant the same crucifers
- Practice rotations with corn and sorghum every two years
- Set up nurseries away from major production fields and plant in well drained soils

- Monitor fields looking for small, water-soaked pinpoint lesions with yellow halos on the leaves
- Look also for dark brown or purple lesions on leaves as spots merge together
- Look for chlorotic and dying leaves as the disease progesses
- Take action when the first symptoms are seen
- Similar symptoms can be caused by fungi such as Alternaria spp.
- Rogue and destroy infected plants in nurseries and production fields when disease density is low
- No chemical for control of this disease has been reported

Images.Caption: Cabbage leaf showing later stages of infection (Francis Nduati, Kenya)

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), F. C. Brentu (University of Ghana)

Sections.Value:
- Site nurseries away from production fields and transplant to well drained soils
- Avoid planting on land with continuous history of cabbage for 3 years
- Practice rotations with maize and sorghum every two years
- Destroy plant residues and volunteer crops by burying (1m deep) to decompose
- Fields should not be worked while plants are wet to avoid spreading the disease
- Avoid injuries to plants when working to reduce mechanical transmission of bacteria
- Control insect pests especially caterpillars as insect damage often provides an entry point for the bacteria
- Avoid damage during harvest, use clean implements and transport or store in clean containers as this is an important post-harvest disease

- Monitor field looking for small to large water-soaked lesions on the leaves
- Affected leaf tissues turn brown, become soft and mushy and has a foul smell
- Look for decaying leaves, stems and roots
- Inspect harvested cabbages for any rot symptoms and discard before transport or storage
- Take action as soon as the symptoms are seen
- Rogue and destroy infected plants in nurseries and fields by deep burying
- No effective chemical control methods has ever been reported for this disease. General Restrictions: Depend on good field hygiene and other cultural practices

Images.Caption: Soft rot of cabbage (Photo: PM Kodwaran, Kenya)

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), F. C. Brentu (University of Ghana)

Sections.Value:
- Solarisation of nursery beds before planting is effective in reducing bacteria population - cover the soil with a polythene cover and let the sun heat it for a week or so
- After harvest remove plant debris and burn to reduce inoculum pressure in the soil (do not compost diseased plants)
- Plant on raised beds or ridges to improve soil drainage
- Avoid physical damage to roots and stems, especially when planting and weeding
- If there is an outbreak rotate for 4-6 years with cereals or legumes (maize, millet or sorghum)
- Ensure land is free of solanaceous weeds especially during crop rotation periods
- Sterilize garden or farm tools (e.g. cutlasses, hoes) after working in infected soil using fire
- Wash hands after handling infected plants

- Additional relevant crops: eggplant, pepper
- Monitor field reguarly after transplanting as infection can occur at any stage of growth
- Look for wilting of young leaves at midday when temperatures are high, and the death of plants
- Uproot suspected infected plants during monitoring, cut through stem to look for vascular discoloration:
Put cut end of suspected infected plant in water and look for oozing of whitish fluid from the cut surface
- Rogue diseased plants and burn when first observed at very low disease incidence
- Chemical control is not recommended because they are generally not economical or not effective

Images.Caption: Advanced stage of bacterial wilt (Don Ferrin, Louisiana State University Agricultural Center, Bugwood.org)
Internal discolouration in the stam (Clemson University - USDA Cooperative Extension Slide Series, Bugwood.org)
Bacteria oozing from cut stem into water (Eric Boa, CABI)

Factsheets.Title: Bacterial wilt of tomato and other solanaceous crops

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), F. C. Brentu (University of Ghana)

Sections.Value:
- Avoid planting crucifers on a field with a history of black rot
- Also locate seedbeds away from main production fields
- This bacterial disease is seedborne so using clean seed is essential. It is also easily spread by splashing water and insects
- Plant on raised beds at a site with good drainage
- Control weeds and avoid irrigating early in the day when dew is present or late in the day
- Avoid injuries to plants when working at the nursery or field
- Sterilize cutlasses and hoes after work using fire or 10% bleach solution
- Remove crop debris after harvest and destroy

- Additional relevant crops: broccoli, brussel sprout, cabbage
- Monitor nursery and fields regularly looking for yellow areas along the leaf edge. These lessions expand from the edges to the leaf to the midrib giving a distinctive 'V' shaped lession with yellow margins and brown necrotic tissue in the centre
- The veins of the leaves can also appear brown/black
- Infected plants may be stunted and heads are smaller and outer leaves die

- Rogue infected plants and destroy them by burying outside production fields
- Begin application after transplants are set in

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
-  Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance, always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Apply cupric hydroxide (eg. Kocide 2000, Champion 80) at 1.5-2.0g/L of water immediately symptoms are observed. Multi-site contact activity. FRAC code: M1. General Restrictions: WHO Class III (slightly hazardous). REI-24hrs; PHI-14 days. Apply three times in a season at 7-10 day intervals. Do not use the same chemical group continuously on the same farm.

Images.Caption: Black rot of savoy cabbage (Gerald Holmes, Bugwood.org)
Cabbage leaf showing characteristic V shaped lesion spreading from the edge of leaves (CABI)

Authors.Surname: A.Y. Akrofi (Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana) and E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.)

Sections.Value:
- Remove alternative hosts (Cola chlamydantha (Kra-bise), Ceiba pentandra (Onyina), Adansonia digitata (Odadee), Cola gigantea (Watapuo) from cocoa farms
- Do not plant infected seelings
- Plant mixed hybrids available from COCOBOD Seed Production Divisions - as these offer some tolerance
- Avoid planting new seedlings under CSSVD infected cocoa trees
- Restrict movement of infected materials to disease-free areas
- Use oil palm and citrus as barrier crops to restrict movement of the vector and reduce infection of new plantings adjacent to infected farms

- CSSVD is vectored by mealybugs so monitor the field regularly for cocoa mealybugs (Planococcoides njalensis and P. citri)
- It is usually the adult female which can be seen on pods and shoots. These soft bodied and wingless insects produce a white waxy fluffy covering. They are also associated with the production of honey dew and the growth of powdery black sooty mold
- Monitor the cocoa trees regularly for symptoms of CSSVD which are swollen chupons and fan branches, fern patterns, green banding and vein clearing on the leaves and the presence of round pods
- If symptoms are observed on a single cocoa tree take immediate action

- Eradicate all infected trees and contacted trees from plantations as soon as the symptoms are seen
- Once removed, the infected plant should be burned. The tree can be cut into pieces and used as fuel/fire wood
- Remove the whole plant but do not cut it out, as this may result in rejuvenation of the old plant which may still carry the virus
- For management of mealybugs please refer to the Mealybug on Cocoa PMDG
- There are no chemical pesticides to control this disease and COCOBOD do not advise using pesticides to control mealybugs in cocoa

Images.Caption: Swollen symptom on stem, fan branches or chupons (Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana)
Fern leaf pattern symptom  (Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana)
Rounded pod symptom (Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana)

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), F. C. Brentu (University of Ghana), F.A. Nyarko (The Council for Scientific and Industrial Research)

Sections.Value:
- Plant rosette resistant or tolerant varieties such as 'Adepa' or 'Konkoma' released by CSRI (Crops Research Institute). Contact CSRI to see if they are available
- In the absence of resistant varieties the following can be practiced:
Remove volunteer groundnut or leftover plants immediately after harvest and destroy in the field by burning or burying
Intercrop groundnuts with cereals such as sorghum, millet or maize
Practice crop rotation ever 1-2 years with such as sorghum, millet or maize
Practice early planting and avoid wide spacing. Plants should form uniformly dense stands as aphids often land preferentially on widely spaced plants

- Monitor young plants weekly for aphids vectors. Examine leaf surfaces after germination particulary growing tips - aphids prefer feeding on young and soft tissue
- Look for glossy black or dark brown bodied aphids measuring about 2 mm in length on the plants
- Monitor young plants from 30-45 days after sowing for symptoms of rosette - stunted growth, chlorosis and reduced leaf sizes and leaf distortion
- Start control as soon as symptoms of the virus are observed or the presence aphids are detected
- Yellow direct control should not be delayed if susceptible cultivars or varieties are planted

- Rogue infected plants when observed to reduce source of infection and destroy by burning in the field
- Control aphids by spraying soap solution (1 tea spoonful of dishwashing soap in 4L of water) 2-3 times at 3-4 day intervals early or late in the day
- Spray neem seed water extract (5% concentration, w/v) to control aphids just after their appearance (second and third sprays must be applied at 14 days intervals). PHI: 24 hrs
- Position a number of sticky yellow traps or yellow sheets (A4 size) at different locations in the field to trap winged aphids

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana
- Application of chemical control may not be practiced by small scale farmers for economic reasons

- Spray imidacloprid (Confidor 200SL, Confidor 200 OD, Bastion Extra 3G, Akape 20 SC) at 5-8ml/15L of water to control aphids and other insect vectors. Systemic neonicotinoid, IRAC group:4A. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous). Apply 30 days after sowing and repeat 15 days after first application to contol population of aphids. PHI: 24 hrs & REI 24 hrs
- Spray lambda-cyhalothrin (Clear 2.5 EC, Conquer Super 2.5 EC, Ekuapa 2.5 EC) at 50ml/15L of water to control aphids. A quick-acting contact and stomach action pyrethroid, IRAC group: 3A. General Restrictions: WHO class II (moderately hazardous). Apply 30 days after sowing and repeat 15 days after first application. PHI: 24 hrs & REI 24 hrs

Images.Caption: Yellowing (chlorosis) and distortion of the leaves (Scottish Crop Research Institute)
Stunting of an infected plant on the right compared to a healthy plant on the left (Scottish Crop Research Institute)

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), F. C. Brentu (University of Ghana), F.A. Nyarko (The Council for Scientific and Industrial Research)

Sections.Value:
- Site nurseries away from chilli production fields to prevent early infections
- Extract seeds from virus-free plants with healthy fruits
- Whiteflies are the vectors of this virus so protect nursery plants with nylon nets or spray with insecticide (see yellow control column)
- Raise barrier crops such as maize, sorghum or pearl millet around chilli fields (at least two rows of barrier crops is requred)
- Control weeds and alternative host crops e.g. tomato and pepper
- Seedlings should be sprayed with insecticide before transplanting to the field (see yellow control column)

- Additional relevant crops: pepper, tomato
- Monitor field regularly to detect early infections by looking for symptoms of leaves curling and stunted growth of the plants
- Monitor fields regularly for signs of whiteflies on the under surfaces of leaves in nursery and production field
- Whiteflies are about 1.5mm long with waxy white wings and a pale yellow body usually found on the underside of leaves
- Start control as soon as the symptoms of the disease are first observed to avoid being overwhelmed by disease spread and severity

- Rougue early infected plants at very low disease incidence and destroy by burning
- Position a number of sticky yellow traps or yellow sheets (A4 size) at different locations in the field to attract whiteflies
- Spray with 5 tablespoons of dishwashing soap in 20 litres of water at 7-14 days intervals to control whiteflies
- Spray neem seed water extract (5% concentration, w/v) to control vectors just after their appearance (second and third sprays must be applied at 14 days intervals)

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana
- The virus can not be manged using pesticides but the insect vector can be controlled using insecticides:

- Spray field with imidacloprid at 5-7ml/15L of water to control the white fly population. Systemic neonicotinoid, IRAC group:4A. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). REI 24 hrs, PHI 7-14 days. Apply three times at intervals of 7-14 days depending on vector population. Alternate with other chemical group insecticide after three applications
- Spray with lambda-cyhalothrin at 50ml/15L of water. A quick-acting contact and stomach action pyrethroid, IRAC group: 3A. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). REI: 24 hrs, PHI 7-14 days. Apply three times at intervals of 7-14 days

Images.Caption: The vector, adult whiteflies (Bemisia tabaci) (Stephen Ausmus, USDA-ARS)

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), F. C. Brentu (University of Ghana), F.A. Nyarko (The Council for Scientific and Industrial Research)

Sections.Value:
- Do not plant cotton, tomato or other crops susceptible to whiteflies near okro farms
- Plough-under all plant debris after harvest or burn it before planting the next seasons crop
- Practice crop rotation with maize, millet or sorghum
- Control weeds especially those in the family malvaceae in and around farms to reduce transmission through secondary hosts sources

- Additional relevant crops: tomato, pepper, melons
- Monitor field regularly to detect early symptoms of the virus by looking for leaf curling and stunted growth. Infection is critical when plants are young
- Also monitor the field regularly after germination for signs of the whitefly vectors. The whiteflies are around 1.5 mm long with waxy white wings and pale yellow bodies. The are usually found on the underside of leaves
- Take action as soon as symptoms of the disease are first observed on the plants

- Rogue infected plants at very low disease incidence and destroy by burning or burying
- Place yellow sticky traps at different locations in the field to attract white flies
- Spray with 5 table spoons of dish washing soap in 20 litres of water at 7-14 days intervals
- Spray neem seed water extract (5% concentration, w/v) to control vectors just after their appearance (second and third sprays must be applied at 14 days intervals)

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana
- The virus can not be manged using pesticides but the insect vector can be controlled using insecticides

- Spray alpha-cypermethrin at 7.5ml/15L of water. A pyrethroid. IRAC code: 3A. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). REI: 24 hrs. PHI:14. Apply three times at 7-14 days intervals depending on vector situation. Alternate with other chemical group insecticide after three applications.
- Spray lambda-cyhalothrin at 50ml/15L of water. A pyrethroid. IRAC code: 3A. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). REI: 24 hrs. PHI:14 days. Apply three times at intervals of 7-14 days.
- Spray field with imidacloprid at 5-7ml/15L of water. Systemic neonicotinoid insecticide. IRAC code: 4A. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). REI: 24 hrs. PHI:7-14 days. Apply three times at intervals of 7-14 days depending on vector population.

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), F. C. Brentu (University of Ghana), F.A. Nyarko (The Council for Scientific and Industrial Research)

Sections.Value:
- PMMV has no known biological vector and is spread through seed, infected material and mechanical means
- Produce seed away from other pepper fields, extract seeds from healthy plants free of viral symptoms with healthy fruits
- In areas with pesence of PMMV use larger planting distances to avoid plant to plant transmission: space rows 24 to 36 inches apart
- Minimize mechanical damage to plants in the field
- Practice crop rotation (3 years or more) with maize, millet or cowpea
- Bury diseased plants outside field and avoid using this material for composting
- Remove weeds and volunteer crops (solanaceous crops)

- Additional relevant crops: chilli, tomato
- Monitor pepper fields regularly for symptoms of disease such as white or green mottled leaves and stunted growth
- Pepper fruits can show more pronounced symptoms such as small size, mottled, malformed, sunken or raised areas which can be discoloured or nectrotic
- Carry out direct controls as soon as symptoms of the disease are first observed

- Rogue out diseased plants and bury outside of the field to facilitate decomposition
- Do not burn rogue plants in or near the field
- This viral disease has no chemical control. Insecticides can not be used to control the vector as the virus has no known biological vectors

Symptoms on green fruits (Alan A. Brunt)
Necrosis on stem (Alan A. Brunt)

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), F. C. Brentu (University of Ghana), F.A. Nyarko (The Council for Scientific and Industrial Research)

Sections.Value:
- Reduce handling of and injuries to the plants as this virus is primarily spread through mechanical means
- Site nurseries away from older pepper fields and transplant disease free seedlings
- Wash hands after handling infected plants with soap and water. Disinfect farm tools with 10% bleach (sodium hypochlorite) solution after working in infected fields
- Remove weeds and alternative hosts (e.g. tomato and egg plant)
- Do not smoke and then handle plants before washing hands with soap as the virus can be present in cigarette tobacco
- Seedlings should be sprayed with an insectiside before transplanting from nursery (see yellow control column)

- Additional relevant crops: tomato, tobacco
- Look for symptoms of the disease - infected plant leaves show chlorotic mosaic and distrotion, fruits may be disfigured and plants stunted
- Infections can occur at any stage of growth so take action when the first symptoms are seen

- Rogue plants showing early symptoms of the disease and destroy in the field
- Yellow sticky traps placed at different locations in the field can be used to trap insects
- Spray with 5 tablespoons of dishwashing soap in 20 litres of water at 7-14 days intervals (avoid higher concentrations)
- Spray neem seed water extract (5% concentration, w/v) to control insects just after their appearance (second and third sprays must be applied at 14 days intervals)

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana
- This viral disease has no chemical control. Insecticides can be used to manage insect vectors

- Spray imidacloprid (200g/L) at 5-7ml/15L of water to control aphids and other insect vectors. Systemic neonicotinoid, IRAC group:4A. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). REI 24 hrs, PHI 7-14 days. Apply three times at intervals of 7-14 days depending on vector population. Alternate with other chemical group insecticide after three applications
- Spray lambda-cyhalothrin at 50ml/15L of water. A quick-acting contact and stomach action pyrethroid, IRAC group: 3A. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). REI 24 hrs, PHI 7-14 days. Apply three times at intervals of 7-14 days

Deformation and discoloration on pepper fruit (Pasquale Piccirillo)

Authors.Surname: Andrews Y. Akrofi (Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana)

Sections.Value:
- Use improved planting materials from COCOBOD Seed Production Division
- Plant at or thin out cocoa trees to recommended spacing of 3m x 3m
- Reduce humidity on the farm by weeding farm frequently (3-4 times/year), reduce overhead shade, prune trees judiciously in March/April to prevent infection
- Avoid wounding the trunk during farm operations (eg. weeding and harvesting)
- Remove infected pod immediately to prevent infection spreading onto the stem and branches through the peduncle (pod stalk)
- Also see PMDG for Phytophthora pod rot

- Monitor cocoa trees for symptoms of canker on trunk and branches on regular basis especially during the rainy season
- Look for diseased, discoloured areas on the trunk and branches with red/brown ooze or gummosis. Once the bark is removed the lesion with have a red/brown colour
- In P. megakarya infection areas look for canker symptoms mainly on lower parts of the cocoa tree trunk at the beginning of the black pod season (when rains have started). This is because the disease mainly lives in the soil
- In P. palmivora areas, look out for canker symptom on whole trunk and branches higher in the cocoa tree as infection can occur from the flower cushions
- Scrape the surface of canker with a sharp machette to expose the lesions on the wood and let them dry out

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- The scraped exposed may be sprayed or painted with COCOBOD recommended fungicides . General Restrictions: The fungicides below can be used to manage Phytophthora cankers. Other approved pesticide options may be available on COCOBOD's current list
- Metalaxyl/Mefenoxam & Copper hydroxide/oxide (Fungikill 50 WP, Ridomil Gold 66 WP, Metalm 72 WP, Metacide Super, Agro Commet 72 WP) Rate 50g/15L. General Restrictions: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous). REI-24 hrs. A mixture of systemic and protectant with multsite action FRAC Group 4 and M1
- Benalaxyl & Copper oxide (Fantic Plus 69WP) Rate 75ml/15L. General Restrictions: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous). REI-24 hrs. A mixture of systemic and protectant with multsite action FRAC Group 4 and M1
- Cuprous oxides (Nordox Super 75 WG) and copper hydroxides (Kocide 2000 DF, Funguran-OH, Champion, Kentan); FRAC Code M1, WHO Class II (Moderately harzadous). General Restrictions: Copper-based fungicides can be mixed with water and applied as a paste

Images.Caption: Canker lesion on trunk of cocoa tree with gummosis (ooze) of reddish brown liquid (CABI)
Canker on cocoa tree trunk scraped showing  cream to reddish brown coloured lesion (CABI)

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricutural Consultants, Impact Plus Company Limited) and F.C. Brentu (University of Ghana)

Sections.Value:
- Do not transfer nematodes into a clean area when transplanting - by reducing movement of soil from one place to another
- Expose ploughed land for 2-3 weeks before transplanting this may help to reduce nematode numbers
- Farm tools (e.g. cutlasses) should be washed of soil particles after use
- Control weeds and volunteer crops or other solanaceous plants
- Rotate for 2 years with non-host crops: sorghum, millet, broccoli or cauliflower
- Plant marigolds (e.g. Tagetes patula) on fields for two months after harvest, plough into soil before transplanting seedlings
- Destroy plant debris after harvest by burning
- When planning to grow high value crops it may be economical to have the soil tested for the presence of nematodes. Contact the Nematology Laboratory of CSIR (Crops Research Institute) for information

- Additional relevant crops: tomato, pepper, eggplant
- Monitor field regularly looking for wilted or yellowed plants
- Also look for stunted growth and zones of poor growth on the farm soon after transplanting
- Uproot affected plants to examine the root systems and check for galls and swellings
- As soon as the first symptoms are observed begin direct controls

- Rogue and burn affected plants with typical nematode symptoms at early stages of plant growth
- Remove galled roots as this may help to reduce nematode populations
- Application of poultry manure or cow dung at a rate of 5t/ha can boost crop vigour and reduce nematode infestation on the crop

- Nematicides (chemicals) used in controlling nematodes are generally poisnous and expensive. General Restrictions: Avoid recommending chemical control with nematicides. Encourage use of cultural practices and other preventive methods

Images.Caption: Roots of tomato plant with knots (Gerald Holmes, California Polytechnic State University at San Luis Obispo, Bugwood.org)
Tomato plant wilting due to nematode infestation (CABI)

Factsheets.Title: Root knot nematode of tomato, pepper and eggplant

Authors.Surname: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies, Ghana), Antony Cudjoe (Private Consultant), Andrews Y. Akrofi (Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana)

Sections.Value:
- Use resistant varieties (mixed hybrids) from COCOBOD authorised seed gardens which suffer less damage than Amazon hybrids
- Remove chupons (green basal/side growths) on cocoa trees as these are succulent and attractive both as feeding and egg-laying sites
- Remove alternative host plants such as young silk cotton trees and kola (Cola spp.) mango, cashew and avocado
- Inspect cocoa plants up to hand height monthly for the presence of stinkbugs and feeding lesions on pods and shoots
- Monthly examinations of whole plants for lesions on fan branches and die back (browning of leaves on branches from the tip down)

- Additional relevant crops: cashew, kola, mango, avocado
- Monitor for stinkbugs which occur throughout the year with peaks from March to June and August to September
- Carry out monthly inspection for stinkbugs in cocoa areas where the canopy is broken
- Stinkbugs use long mouthparts to penetrate through the pod husk to suck the contents of the beans. They do not leave feeding marks on the pods like those of mirids. Look out for premature ripening of the pods (turning yellow), clumping of beans inside pods, deformation of cherelles.
- Damage to pods is the main issue but stinkbugs can also attack new flushes and chupons
- When you see 2-3 stinkbugs per trees on at least 10 trees consider direct controls

- If the canopy is broken replace dead trees or plant plantain as it grows quickly and closes the canopy
- If stinkbug populations are below the threshold level natural enemy populations should be conserved by keeping insecticide use should be kept to a minimum

- Wear protective clothing, hat, overall, gloves, goggles, nose mask, boots
- Do not eat, drink or smoke during application
- Do not spray near streams or rivers or wash spray equipment in running/drinking water

- The pesticides listed below can be used to manage stinkbugs on cocoa. Other approved pesticide options are available please contact staff from COCOBOD or CRIG. General Restrictions: Apply using a motorised mistblower on monthly basis beginning from August to December omitting November (to avoid contamination of beans at peak harvest). Spraying can be carried out when stink bugs numbers and damage is high, 2 applications at monthly intervals. For infested areas/ pockets spot spraying can be carried out.
- Thiamethoxam (Actara 240 SC) Rate: 17ml/11litres or 85ml/ha. General Restrictions: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous) Systemic, IRAC group 4 neonicotinoid, PHI 5 days
- Apply imidacloprid (Confidor 200 SL) Rate: 30ml/11litres or 150ml/ha. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous) Systemic, IRAC group 4 neonicotinoids, PHI 5 days
- Deltamethrin + Pyrethrum (Miricon EC) Rate: 66ml/11 litres or 330ml/ha. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous) Contact, IRAC group 3 pyrethroids, PHI 5 days
- Bifenthrin (Akate Master) Rate: 100ml/11litres or 500ml/ha. . General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous) Contact, IRAC group 3 pyrethroids

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), F. C. Brentu (University of Ghana), F.A. Nyarko (The Council for Scientific and Industrial Research)

Sections.Value:
- Yam mosaic virus can be spread through infected planting material and by aphid vectors. Use seed yams produced from healthy plants - this can be obtained through tagging of healthy plants
- Avoid using small under-sized tubers for planting materials as these are likely to be infected by the virus
- Collect all old plant debris and volunteer crops from field and destroy by burning
- Effective control of weeds that are possible alternate hosts for aphid vectors
- Avoid intercropping with susceptible yam species
- Avoid injuries to plants when working in the field as YMV can also be transmitted mechanically

- Monitor plants weekly looking at the surfaces of leaves for the presence of aphids. The aphids are small (1-1.5 mm) soft bodied insects often yellow to very dark (almost black) green in colour
- Monitor young leaves as growth progresses for mosaic appearance, chlorosis, leaf distortions and stunted growth. Infection can occur at all stages of development
- Farmers should start action at first sign of disease to avoid being overwhelmed by spread and severity

- Rogue out infected plants showing symptoms at early stages of growth and destroy by burning
- Farmers generally will not rogue their yam plants so this activity should be limited to early stages of growth

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- There are no chemicals to control this viral disease but insecticides can help to control the insect vector. General Restrictions: Application of chemical control may not be practiced by small scale farmers for economic reasons
- Spray field and surrounding areas with imidacloprid at 5-7ml/15L of water to control aphids if vector population persists. A systemic neonicotinoid insecticide, IRAC group: 4A . General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). REI 24 hrs. PHI 7-14 days. Apply two times at intervals of 7-14 days
- Spray alpha-cypermethrin at 5-7.5ml/15L of water to control the aphids. A contact and ingested pyrethroid insecticide, IRAC group: 3A. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). REI: 24 hrs. PHI:14. Apply two times at 7-14 days interval depending on vector situation. Alternate with other chemical group insecticide after two applications.

Bleaching symptoms (Photo by J. d'A Hughes/IITA)

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), F. C. Brentu (University of Ghana), F.A. Nyarko (The Council for Scientific and Industrial Research)

Sections.Value:
- Avoid planting rice in areas where RYMV is already present
- Control insect vectors in the nursery with insecticides (see yellow control column)
- Control weeds on rice fields and around fields (particularly grasses)
- Reduce injuries to plants during transplanting and weeding
- Set traps to prevent rodents and other animals from causing injuries
- Plough under infected crop residues, volunteer rice, infected ratoons and weeds after harvest
- Wash hands with soap after working on infected plants so as not to transmit to healthy plants

- Monitor nursery weekly for yellowing of leaves, stunted growth and death of plants
- Young seedlings (3-4 leaf growth stage) are most susceptible to infection, newly formed leaves are twisted and have difficulty in emerging
- Monitor the fields after transplanting look for intense yellow/orange colouration of leaves, stunted growth, empty spikelets, death of plants
- Vectors: look for insects with shiny black bodies or others with brown heads and dark bodies and spined thorax. Hoppers with greenish-yellow bodies and others with greenish brown coloration
- RYMV is a dangerous disease and farmers are advised to start control action soon after observing symptoms
- Rogue and burn infected plants in the field when first seen to reduce spread of disease to healthy plants

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana
- The virus can not be manged using pesticides but the insect vector can be controlled using insecticides:

- Spray alpha-cypermethrin at 5-7.5ml/15L of water to control insect vectors in the nursery. A contact and ingested pyrethroid insecticide, IRAC group: 3A. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). REI: 24 hrs. PHI:14. Apply two times at 7-14 days interval depending on vector situation. Alternate with other chemical group insecticide after two applications.
- Spray with imidacloprid at 5-7ml/15L of water to control insect vectors in the nursery. A systemic neonicotinoid insecticide, IRAC group: 4A. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). REI 24 hrs. PHI 7-14 days. Apply two times at intervals of 7-14 days. Alternate with other chemical group insecticide after two applications.

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricutural Consultants, Impact Plus Company Limited) and F.C. Brentu (University of Ghana)

Sections.Value:
- Avoid planting on land with long history of growing okro
- Avoid moving infested soil into clean areas
- Farm tools (e.g. cutlasses) should be washed of soil particles after use
- Practice crop rotation (at least two years duration) with plants such as sorghum, maize and millet
- Plant marigolds (e.g.Targetes patula) on fields for two months after harvest, plough marigold into soil before transplanting seedlings
- Control weeds and volunteer crops in and around okro fields
- Destroy old plant debris by burning soon after harvest
- When planning to grow high value crops it may be economical to have the soil tested for the presence of nematodes. Contact the Nematology Laboratory of CSIR-Crops Research Institute for information

- Additional relevant crops: watermelon
- Monitor nursery and field regularly looking for wilted plants, stunted growth, leaf chlorosis (yellowing) and zones of poor growth
- Uproot some of the suspected plants and look for root knots
- Carry out direct controls as soon as symptoms are seen in the crop

- Rogue and destroy diseased plants at early stages of plant growth by burning
- Apply poultry manure or cow dung at a rate of 5t/ha to increase vigour of plants to resist nematode infestation

- Nematicides used in controlling nematodes are generally poisnous and expensive - not suitable for small-scale farmers. General Restrictions: Avoid recommending chemical control with nematicides. Encourage use of cultural practices and other preventive methods.
