Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), F. C. Brentu (University of Ghana), F.A. Nyarko (The Council for Scientific and Industrial Research)

Sections.Value:
- Transplant only healthy seedlings to new fields and site nurseries away from tomato fields to reduce seedling infections
- Thrips are the main vector in the transmission of TSWV, in nurseries plants can be covered with with a fine mesh (sizes smaller than 0.5mm) to prevent access to the thrips.
- Alternatively chemical pesticides can be used to control the vectors (see yellow control column)
- Control weeds on the fields (and around fields) and all volunteer crops - TSWV has many different hosts
- Mulch field with dry grass to prevent pupation of thrips

- Additional relevant crops: pepper, tobacco, irish potato
- Monitor field regularly to detect early symptoms of the disease - look for bronzing and curling of the leaves, nectrotic streaks or spots on the leaves and leaf stalks, stunting of the whole plant and ringspots on fruit
- Also monitor regularly for signs of thrips on surfaces of leaves in the nursery and field, consider chemical control if populations are high
- TSWV is one of the most economically devastating diseases of tomato therefore, action to control it should start soon after symptoms are observed
- Rogue early infected plants at very low disease incidence and destroy by burning

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana
- The virus can not be manged using pesticides but the insect vector can be controlled using insecticides:

- Spray alpha-cypermethrin at 7.5ml/15L of water to control the vector population. A contact and ingested pyrethroid insecticide, IRAC group: 3A. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). REI 24 hrs and PHI 14 days. Apply three times at 7-14 days intervals depending on vector situation. Alternate with other chemical group insecticides after three applications.
- Spray field with imidacloprid at 5-7ml/15L of water to control thrip and other insect vectors, if vector populations persist. A systemic neonicotinoid insecticide, IRAC group: 4A. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). REI 24 hrs and PHI 7-14 days. Apply three times at intervals of 7-14 days depending on vector population. Alternate with other chemical group insecticides after three applications.

Stunting and necrosis of the leaves (Don Ferrin, Louisiana State University Agricultural Center, Bugwood.org)
Nectoric spots on tomato leaves (Paul Bachi, University of Kentucky Research and Education Center, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricutural Consultants, Impact Plus Company Limited) and F.C. Brentu (University of Ghana)

Sections.Value:
- There are very few direct contol measures for this nematode. Most management practices are preventative
- Use nematode-free seed yam (tubers free from dry rot) as planting material
- Treat seed yam with wood ash (decreases nematode population because of phytotoxic nature)
- Apply hot water treatment to seed yam tubers at temperatures of 50-55oC for 40 minutes before planting (candle wax dropped into water being heated melts around 50oC)
- Pull out old plant debris soon after harvest and destroy by burning
- Control weeds and volunteer crops capable of habouring nematodes
- Plant antagonistic plants such as Crotolaria spp. on yam farms just after harvest and plough in before planting

- Monitor the field weekly for patches of poor growth
- Where poor growth is occuring check the roots and tubers for signs of cracking/flacking of the skin and a black dry rot below. It may be necessary to scrape the surface layer away to see the damage
- Farmers should rogue severely diseased plants when they are young at a disease incidence not greater than 3%

- Roguing out infested plants and burning them can reduce nematode numbers in the field but note that farmers are generally reluctant to rogue diseased yam plants
- In nutrient poor soils consider apply poultry manure or cow dung at a rate of 5t/ha to increase plant vigour which will help ro reduce damage and losses by nematodes
- Avoid moving soil from the infested zone to other parts of the field

- Nematicides used in controlling nematodes are generally very toxic and expensive and not generally suitable for use by small scale farmers. General Restrictions: Avoid recommending chemical control with nematicides. Encourage use of cultural and other preventive methods.

Images.Caption: Tubers of yam (D. rotundata) in Nigeria showing dry rot and cracking caused by S. bradys (John Bridge)
Internal discolouration and rotting of infected yam on the right (John Bridge)

Authors.Surname: A.Y. Akrofi (Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana) and E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd)

Sections.Value:
- Avoid movement of planting materials (cocoa seedlings, plantain suckers, cocoyam corms) from infected to non-infected areas
- Remove infected pods and cherelles (young pods) and control stem cankers. Infected pods and husks should be removed and burnt or sprayed fungicides (see yellow control column)
- Moist conditions favour the development of this disease so reduce humidity and improve air circulation:
Plant or thin out to the recommended spacing 3 x 3 m for COCOBOD cocoa hybrid
Prune cocoa in March/April, clear weeds 3-4 times a year and reduce shade trees to 5-8 per acre
Ensure there is good drainage and avoid stagnant water

- Monitor cocoa farms at the onset of the rains for the first signs of the disease. This disease can affect the whole plant but losses to the pods is the most important
- Look out for small brown spots on the surface of the pods which become darker and expand rapidly. After 3-5 days a white bloom of spores appears on the lession. The whole surface of the pod can become black after 7-14 days
- When there are cherelles and pods on the trees and the first symptoms of the disease are seen, start direct controls
- If applying fungicide, spot spraying can be carried out but if symptoms are widespread the whole field can be sprayed

- Remove all infected and mummified pods during harvest or preferably as soon as seen, collect the diseased pods and destroy by burning or spray with recommended fungicides
- Harvest frequently, at least monthly so diseased pods are removed from the trees
- Refer to the PMDG for management of Phytophthora stem canker of cocoa

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult MOFA's most recent list of registered pesticides

- These fungicides can be used to manage black pod. Other approved options are available on COCOBOD's list. General Restrictions: Apply using a 15L pneumatic knapsack sprayer at 4 week intervals during the rainy season when there are pods to protect
- Metalaxyl/Mefenoxam & Copper hydroxide/oxide (Fungikill 50 WP, Ridomil Gold 66 WP, Metalm 72 WP, Metacide Super, Agro Commet 72 WP) 50g/15L. Systemic & protectant. Multsite action FRAC Group 4 & M1. General Restrictions: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous). REI-24 hrs.
- Copper hydroxide (Kocide 2000 DF, Funguran-OH, Champion, Kentan) Rate 100g/15L. Protective with multsite action FRAC Group M1. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). REI-24 hrs.
- Copper oxide (Nordox Super 75 WG) Rate 75g/15L. Protective with multsite action FRAC Group M1. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). REI-24 hrs.
- Benalaxyl & Copper oxide (Fantic Plus 69WP) Rate 75ml/15L. Systemic & protectant. Multsite action FRAC 4 & M1. General Restrictions: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous). REI-24 hrs.

Cocoa pods showing later stages of infection due to P. megakarya (Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana)
Internal pod symptoms (R Bateman, www.dropdata.org)

Sections.Value:
- Select material for propagation from a reliable and disease-free source
- Use resistant cultivars if available:
Note: many of the CMD-resistant cultivars are susceptible to CBSD
- Avoid planting alternative hosts of the virus, such as castor bean (Ricinus communis), adjacent to cassava
- Avoid planting cassava if your neighbours have virus-infected cassava as the virus will be carried by whiteflies to your field
- Avoid planting alternative hosts of the virus vector whitefly, Bemisia tabaci, such as tomato in or near a cassava field
- Weed regularly, especially during the early stage of the crop. Weeds such as Geratium spp. are alternative hosts of whitefly
- Intercrop with cereals and legumes, such as maize or cowpeas, to repel whiteflies

- Additonal relevant crops: soya bean, castor oil plant, Datura spp., Nicotiana spp., Leucaena leucocephala, Jatropha multifida
- Examine crop once a week for symptoms (note: infections can be symptomless). Consider taking action when 5-10 plants per acre are infested
- The disease is carried and spread by whiteflies, Bemisia species
- Scout fields for whiteflies early morning or evenings twice per week on 20 plants. If you shake plants, flying-off whiteflies can be seen
- Take measure controls before whitefly numbers reach more than 2 adults per leaf in 50% of plants
- Trap whiteflies using yellow sticky traps
- Symptoms:
Leaves: patches of discolouration (chlorosis) which vary from light green to yellow and also vary in size. Distorted, often severely
Leaf stalks: have a characteristic S-shape

- There are no treatments for virus-infected plants
- Uproot and bury or burn diseased plants as part of an integrated management strategy. This is only effective if done early, before many plants are affected
- Follow with crop rotation with non-host plants such as sorghum or cowpeas to reduce virus levels in your area
- Vector control offers few benefits - it is difficult, costly and time-consuming

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Advanced mosaic and distortion of leaves on an infected cutting (Photo: Eric Boa, CABI)
Although chlorotic (yellow) areas are well developed the limited leaf distortion suggests infection via whiteflies after planting (Photo: Eric Boa, CABI)

Factsheets.Title: Cassava mosaic disease
ScientificNames: Cassava mosaic geminiviruses (CMGs) such as African cassava mosaic virus, East African cassava mosaic virus

Sections.Value:
- Use clean planting material only
- Remove alternative hosts, such as cocoyam, taro, ginger, cardamom, from the plantation and the surroundings
- Encourage the presence of natural enemies, such as coccinellids, hoverflies and lacewings in the plantation, by reducing the amount of chemicals used

- Monitor regularly during moderate humidity and temperature conditions (20-25C) between leaves and pseudostem, and on the base of young leaves for small red-brown to almost black, oval aphids
- During rainy periods, dense colonies are found around the bases of pseudostems near ground level (down to 7-8 cm below soil surface)
- Aphids are sometimes found on fruits
- Look for signs of aphid presence:
Feeding damage from large colonies causes stunting, honeydew build-up and growth of sooty moulds on the whole plant, and fruit blemishing
Leaves may be rolled or folded and show necrotic areas
Colonies are often protected by ants, and may be hidden in earthen structures near ground level made by ants
- Banana aphid is a vector of the Banana bunchy top virus (BBTV). If aphids are found in the plantation, look carefully for BBTV symptoms for the next 25 days.

- If available, release parasitoids such as Lysiphlebus testaceipes, L. fabarum, Ephedrus cerasicola, Aphidius spp. or Aphelinus spp.
- Note that the release of natural enemies to lower aphid populations has not been fully successful in many countries due to ants protecting the colonies.

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Banana aphids hiding in between the leaves and pseudostem (Scot Nelson)
P. nigronervosa colony (Scot Nelson)
Ants protecting a banana aphids colony (Scot Nelson)

Sections.Value:
- Use clean planting material. Take one or two slices from the planting material and look for tunnels, larvae or pupae. If infested, destroy it
- If clean planting material is not available, then trim the material to remove the parts infested with eggs and larvae and use a hot water treatment:
Remove the outer leaf sheath of suckers to get rid of weevil eggs
Submerge the clean trimmed suckers in a hot water bath (52 to 55C) for 15 to 27 minutes before planting
Neem is also effective for cleaning infected planting material. Dip suckers in a 20% neem seed solution just before planting
- Practice good crop husbandary to produce healthy plants that are tolerant to weevil damage:
Use mulch - leave a ring of about 60 cm from the base of the stool to keep roots from growing towards to surface and avoid moist conditions near the stool which attracts banana weevils
Regularly desucker and remove water suckers. Clear mats of dead leaves/debris. Regularly remove weeds. Apply fertilizers e.g. manure, particularly in the early stages of plant development

- Additional relevant crops: all varieties of bananas and plantains (Musa spp.) as well as ensete (Ensete spp.)
- Look out for:
Adults: 10-16 mm long, black or dark brown, in soil around plant base, between leaf sheaths and under plant debris/mats
Larvae: creamy-white, reddish-brown head, legless, 12 mm long
Tunnelling into the corm (up to 1.5 cm wide) causing fungal infection and reduced nutrient uptake, stem growth and stablility
Weak or dying suckers, yellow floppy leaves and smaller bunches
Plants that are heavily infested will show extensive damage to the pseudostem and may fall over
- Stunted plants and plants displaying early withering of leaves should be inspected for larvae and adult weevils:
Cut corms with a knife at or just above ground level and search for larvae or larval tunnels
- Adults are attracted to freshly cut corms and pseudostems which can be used as traps for monitoring. To make a pseudostem trap:
Cut small pieces of pseudostem in half lengthwise (about 25 cm long) and place the cut pieces on the ground near the base of the plant, with the cut surface facing down
After 5 days, check the traps and count the weevils on each trap (and kill the weevils)
If more than 2-5 weevils per trap are found, control is necessary
Traps are best used when the weather is warm and wet. About 50 traps/hectare are needed to provide good coverage. Set traps once per month

- Destroy all infected materials and crop residues after harvest to reduce populations
- Do not replant previously infested areas while old corms remain in the ground:
Remove all the corms after the final harvest, cut them into 4-8 pieces and allow them to dry to prevent larval development in harvested plants. Allow three months for the weevil population to die out, before replanting a field
- Apply 60-100 grams/mat of neem seed powder or neem cake around the base of the plant. Apply at planting and again every four months

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Damage caused by banana weevil (Scot Nelson, Flickr)
Adult banana weevil (Scot Nelson,Flickr)

Sections.Value:
- Use tolerant/resistant varieties if available
- Reduce the length of time that the leaves are wet and can be infected by spores:
For planting, choose areas that have good drainage, avoiding those with heavy clay soils where surface water remains for some time after rains
Avoid areas where there is shade from trees
If planting on hillsides, choose sites with morning sun to dry leaves rapidly and always plant so that the rows run in the direction of the prevailing wind, to allow air into the plantation to dry the leaf surface, to prevent infection
Plant at wide spacing, about 2.5 m apart (1600 plants per hectare)
- Weed frequently
- Remove suckers to avoid clustering
- Avoid transporting infected plants into disease-free regions
- Disinfect farm equipment involved in plot management

- Additional relevant crops: plantain
- Take action as soon as symptoms are seen
- Symptoms:
Leaves: Red-brown streaks, parallel to the veins, about 1-5 mm long by 0.25 mm wide. They are most noticeable on the underside of the third or fourth youngest leaf, especially along the edge of the leaf blade, which is first exposed as the leaf emerges
Leaves: The streaks expand and become noticeable on the upper surface, darkening and later developing grey, slightly sunken centres with black margins and bright yellow halos
Leaves: As the streaks join together they form bands of dead areas several centimetres wide, on either side of the midrib, and the leaves collapse and die
- Monitor crop closely when conditions are/have been wet or humid as these are optimal conditions for disease spread
- The symptoms of black Sigatoka are very similar to yellow Sigatoka but the disease management method is the same

- Rogue out young infected plants that have just shown symptoms and burn
- Collect infected leaves from the mother plant after harvest of the fruit and take them out of the plantation and burn them
The fungus spreads on old planting material and on old banana leaves
- Remove older infected leaves regularly and burn or stack them in heaps, keeping the lower leaf surface facing the ground to help prevent disease spread

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Brown streaks with yellow areas between; the spots have joined together at the leaf margin causing a blight (Grahame Jackson, CABI)
Close-up of brown elongated spots, most with yellow margins, and some with grey centres (Grahame Jackson, CABI)

Sections.Value:
- Plant resistant cultivars if available
- Plant early to avoid periods of heavy infestation
- Intercrop with sorghum or green gram to reduce populations and the need for insecticides
Do not intercrop with maize. Doing this can cause an increase in pod damage caused by pod-sucking bugs
- Clean up haulms to prevent the insects from over-seasoning in the crop residues

- Additional relevant crops: pigeon pea, chickpea, soyabean, hyacinth bean, common bean, hoary-pea
- Look for pod sucking bugs at 45 days after planting. Monitor crops regularly, particularly in the morning hours when bugs are active
- Pods shrivel and dry prematurely due to nymphs and adults feeding on the sap
- The shrivelling and drying symptoms can be confused with other stresses such as drought and disease, however, the feeding puncture wounds are a sign of pod-sucking bugs
- The insects can often be found on the pods or under the leaves of cowpeas and other host plants

- During flowering and pod formation, bugs can be collected and killed by hand in small plots
- Apply a mixture of black soap and kerosene:
Dissolve 170 g of black soap in 150 ml of water
Dissolve this in 1 L of kerosene to form a thick concentrate of soap/kerosene mixture
Dissolve 400 ml of the mixture to 5 L of water
Spray at weekly intervals after the cowpea has developed pods
- Apply plant based products, e.g. African hot peppers, cashew nut, garlic bulb, bitter leaf
- Pod-sucking bugs feed on a wide range of legumes and are very mobile, which makes them challenging to control

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Pod sucking bugs (IITA, Flickr)
Pod sucking bugs feeding on cowpea (IITA, Flickr)

Authors.Surname: Michael Kumah (MOFA  PPRSD), Daniel Ninson  (MOFA  DCS), Gifty Boakye (MOFA PPRSD). Updated by Michael Kumah (MOFA-PPRSD).

Sections.Value:
- Buy and plant certified resistant varieties such as Obaatampa and Mamaba from reputable source (registered certified seed dealers).
- Use recommended spacing of the maize (80x40cm) and recommended fertilizer rates (4bags or 200kg of NPK 15:15:15 per ha) to increase the growth vigor
- Plant maize early in the major and minor seasons and avoid staggered planting
- Rotate Maize with legumes such as beans, cowpeas and soyabean
- Weed the maize and clear the grass around the maize crop and maintain a barrier of 10m bare ground between plot and the sourrounding crop or weeds to reduce the vector (leaf hoppers) population and disease transmission

- Maize streak is a virus disease transmitted by plant hoppers and leaf hoppers
- Scout frequently for leafhoppers and disease symptoms starting 1 week after germination if the virus is known from your area
- Plants infected with maize streak virus show symptoms 10 to 14 days after infection
- Symptoms appear mostly on young growing tender leaves, which are preferred by leafhoppers for feeding
- Symptoms vary from clear narrow light green to mild chlorotic streaks centred on secondary and tertiary leaf veins. They are uniformly distributed on the leaf surface thus cannot be mistaken with other diseases.
- Parallel yellow streaks appear and the plants remain stunted, producing small ears
- Consider control when 1-3 leaf hoppers (vectors) are seen per maize plant or if early symptoms of the disease are seen

- Uproot / rogue infected maize plants when they first show signs of disease to avoid the disease from spreading to healthy plants. Put the whole plant in a sack so the leaf hoppers do not go to other plants then destroy by burning or feed to livestock
- Weed and remove grasses from the maize field to reduce vector population
- Control the vector (leaf hoppers) which transmit the virus with insecticides

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana
- There are no pesticides for the virus but insecticides can be used to reduce the insect vector that spreads the disease

- Chlopyriphos ethyl (e.g. Conpyrifos, Dusfos, Dursban). Applied at a rate of 60-70mls per 15 lts knapsack sprayer. A contact and ingested organophosphorus insecicide; IRAC mode of action 1B. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous), pre-harvest interval p.h.i. 35 days; restricted re-entry interval r.e.i. 3 days. Repeat application max twice if the pests/vectors persist and reach thresholds. Apply early morning or late afternoon.
- Apply Deltamethrin based products (check product label for the recommended dosage). It is a Pyrethroid with a contact and stomach poison or with residual activity (i.e. 3-4 weeks persistence). IRAC mode of action 3A. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous), p.h.i. 3 days, r.e.i. day. 5 High risk predators, pollinators, to fish and other aquatic organisms. Do not contaminate surface waters or ditches; do not apply to plants suffering from drought or other physical distress; do not spray within 6m of field boundary.

Images.Caption: Maize streak virus symptoms on leaves (Eric Boa, CABI)
Maize streak virus symptoms on whole plant (International Maize and Wheat Improvement, www.flickr.com)

Authors.Surname: Fridah K Chipambala, Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock, Chongwe, Zambia, Email: fchipambala@gmail.com - Zambia. Modified for Ghana by Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies), Hannah Nuamah (PPRSD, MOFA) and Harunah Braimah (CSIR-Crops Research Institute)

Sections.Value:
- Remove weeds such as Amaranthus and wild grass species that harbour armyworm larvae
- Avoid planting close to overgrazed grasslands which provide food and refuge for caterpillars
- Grow low value grain crops such as finger millet as trap crops to attract armyworms
- Remove alternate host plants such as millet, sorghum, rice, leafy vegetables etc.

- Start monitoring immediately after germination.
- Visit farm daily to inspect for defoliation (chewed leaves), feeding frass and caterpillars (which are grey-green with yellow stripes along the back). Examine soft stems, and developing shoots for hidden caterpillars
- Take direct control action when eggs are present on 2 to 5% of seedlings or when 10 to 25% of plants show signs of feeding damage
- Set pheromone traps (placed 20m apart) and examine pheromone traps weekly

- Pick egg masses when you see them on the underside of the leaves, and destroy them
- Pick and destroy colonies of widely dispersed caterpillars if possible.
- Plough deep trench around field and fill with water to stop the movemet of the armyworms from field to field

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label.
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance; always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Spray crop with Lambda-cyhalothrin product (eg.Pawa 2.5 EC at 40mls/15L of water). It is a synthetic Pyrethroid (IRAC, 3A). It is a contact insecticide. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 3 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non target arthropods.Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near water ways.
- Spray with Cymethoate (Cypermethrin (36g/l) + Dimethoate (400g/l). 1-1.5Lit/ha. Cypermethrin is a synthetic Pyrethroid (IRAC,3A). It is contact. Dimethoate is an Organophosphate (IRAC,1B). . General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 7-14 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non target arthropods.Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near water ways.

Images.Caption: Adult female armyworm (Georg Goergen/IITA Insect Museum, Cotonou, Benin)
Larva of armyworm feeding on maize leaves (Rikus Kloppers/PANNAR Seed (Pty) Ltd, Greytown, South Africa)

Authors.Surname: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies),  Antony Cudjoe (Private Consultant) and Maxwell Awuku (Chemico Ghana Ltd.)

Sections.Value:
- Tie a clear (see-through) plastic bag over the okra pods. This stops the cotton stainers from feeding on the pods.
- Uproot and burn all volunteer okra plants and stubbles after harvest
- Bury the uprooted cotton and debris at least 0.5 m deep
- Apply compost, the compost heat will kill the developing strainers in soil debris
- Do not allow alternative host plants such as cotton and pepper in and around the okra field

- Adult stainers have brown and black backs with two black spots with red and white stripes underneath the body. Young stainers have red and white stripes all over the body. These insects may feed for several days on okra plants, leaving black spots on the dry pods.
- Start monitoring for stainers at 50% flowering up to pod maturity
- Check plants in field for stainers during the flowering and fruiting period. Monitor populations by counting number of stainers per plant
- Look for stainers underneath the leaves, observe for sucking punctures and stains on leaves and fruits
- If about 5-10 stainers are observed in a sample size of 20 plants, initiate control measures.
- Additional relevant crops: pepper, tomato, cotton and akee apple

- Remove stainers on okro leaves and place into a container of water with a thin flim of kerosene to reduce late season populations
- Spray infested okro plants with extract consisting of 15g/L of dried neem seed, add 2g of potassium soap (20%), add hot pepper (1 margarine tin). Spray every 10 days from seedling until flowering.

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label.
-  Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance. Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Foliar application with Cypermethrin (250g/l) + Dimethoate (35g/l) (e.g. Cydim EC, Cydim super EC, Cypercal 50 EC). Spray at the rate of 1-1.5 Litres/ Ha . General Restrictions: WHO class II pesticide (Moderately hazardous). Spray once each at seedling, vegetative and flowering stages. PHI of 14 days, REI-1 day. Harmful to mammals and beneficial insects.
- Foliar application with Chlorpyrifos-ethyl (480g/l) product (e.g. Direx 7.5G, Dusfos 480 EC, Dursban 4 E), 1-1.25 Litres/Ha (75-100mls/15 Litres). . General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous). Spray once each at seedling, vegetative and flowering stages. PHI = 15-30 days, Harmful to mammals and beneficial insects.

Images.Caption: Adult cotton stainer (Georg Goergen/IITA Insect Museum, Cotonou, Benin)

Authors.Surname:
Paul Kiige (MOALF), Eunice Ringera (KEPHIS), Philip Wendot (UON), Benson Masinde (MOALF), Miriam Otipa
(KALRO) Kenya. Modified for Ghana by: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies),  Antony Cudjoe (Private Consultant) and Maxwell Awuku (Chemico Ghana Ltd.)

Sections.Value:
- Plant cabbage in March to June, or before September to avoid high incidences of egg laying moths
- Rotate with non-Brassicas such as onions, legumes and cereals for at least 2 years
- Remove all crop debris including weeds at least 4 weeks prior to sowing to reduce moth population
- Transplant only healthy seedlings free of eggs, caterpillars and pupae of the the moth
- Slash left-over cabbage stems after harvest to avoid regrowth which act as breeding grounds for the moths
- Establish nursery beds away from production fields to prevent cross infestation
- Use insect-proof screens to screen seedlings from adult moths that invade to lay eggs

- Start monitoring for moths when cabbage is at 4-leaf stage, scout for small light greenish, sometimes grey-greenish, thin larvae on leaves and stems
- Continue inspecting weekly especially on the underside of the leaves
- Look out for DBM larvae which when disturbed, will rapidly wriggle their bodies back and forth
- Use lure traps to monitor adult moth populations; use water/funnel/Wota T traps at 2 traps /ropani. The traps should be suspended about 2-4 feet high). Check traps twice a week early in the morning
- Use control when 5 or more adult moths are caught in a trap

- Use overhead irrigation which can reduce moth populations by dislodging the pest from the plant surface
- Plant trap crops such as mustard and rape at the edges of the field to reduce DBM attack
- Collect and destroy moth eggs and larvae by crushing or keeping in a bucket of soapy water
- Spray with NEEMROC 0.03% EC (Azadirachtin 0.03% w/w (32% neem oil) at 1L/acre. Spray every 10 days from seedling until head formation
- Spray Novaluron (Rimon 10EC) at a rate of 100g/l. A benzoylphenol urea insect growth regulator. WHO class U

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label.
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance. Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Spray Bt based insectide e.g. Bypel 1 (Perisrapae Granulosis virus + Bacillus thuringiensis), 550g/Ha, Stomach poison IRAC 11A. General Restrictions: WHO class III (Slightly hazardous) PHI-14 days; REI 1 Day, spray at 14 days interval, ensure thorough spray coverage. Causes moderate eye and skin irritation
- Spray folliage with imidacloprid + emamectin benzoate insecticide (e.g. Dean 62 EC) at a rate of 12g/l. IRAC 4A + 6 . General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous) ; PHI-7, REI -1 day
- Spray folliage with Lambda-cyhalothrin product (e.g. Clear 2.5 EC, Lambda super 2.5EC, Kombat 2.5EC) at 25g/L IRAC 3A. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous) Yellow colour band; REI- when spray dries; PHI-3 days;

Larvae of diamondback moth feeding on cabbage leaves (CABI)
Damage on cabbage plant due to diamondback moth infestation (B. K. Badii, UDS, Ghana)

Authors.Surname: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies),  Antony Cudjoe (Private Consultant) and Maxwell Awuku (Chemico Ghana Ltd.)

Sections.Value:
- Avoid growing pepper in close proximity to alternate host crops, e.g. cotton, tomatoes, okra, egg plants, pigeon pea and sweet potato
- Use trap count information to determine if the moth will be a serious pest in your area; if numbers are high, consider planting elsewhere or planting an alternative crop
- Plough before transplanting during the dry spell to expose the larvae/pupae to the natural enemies and extremes of heat
- Minimize use of pesticides to conserve natural enemies like spiders, parasitic wasps, praying mantis, ants and birds
- Gather and burn pepper sticks, stubbles and remaining fruits after harvest

- Begin monitoring for false codling moths at seedling stage, scout weekly on plants for eggs and adults of moths
- Eggs are spherical, flattened, 10-15 rows of toothed ribs, ranging from white, cream and dark brown. Larvae are green-brown with rows of dark bristled tubercles along their back
- Search for larvae at the base of developing fruits and flower buds. Look for fruits or floral buds that have fallen to the ground and rosetted flowers and check for larvae
- Use pheromone traps to attract male adults (1 trap for every 5 acres) and act if you trap more than 7 in one night
- Take action when 5-10 caterpillars are observed or when 10% of plants examined contain eggs

- Delay use of insecticides as long as possible to allow build-up of natural enemies e.g. Trichogramma, lacewing and pirate bugs
- Hand pick and crush caterpillars at initial infestation, check early in the morning or late in the evening before they return into the fruit
- Mix equal quantities of sawdust, bran and molasses with enough water to make the mixture sticky and spread around the base of the plants in the evenings
- Drench at flowering and fruiting stages with Azadirachtin 0.03% (e.g. Nimbedicine EC, Nematech WG) to reduce infestation drastically

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label.
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance. Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Spray foliage with acetamiprid product (e.g. Blast 60 EC, Golan 20% SP) at rate of 40-50g/l. Contact neonicotinoid IRAC group 4A. General Restrictions: WHO class II - (moderately hazardous), 3 applications per season, PHI 5 days. skin irritants, harmful to bees and aquatic organisms. Do not use near water ways.
- Spray foliage with imidacloprid product (e.g. Confidor Super, Condor SL, Consider super 200 SL, Dimiprid 20SL) at rate of 200g/l. Systemic neonicotinoid IRAC group 4A. General Restrictions: WHO class II - (moderately hazardous), 3 applications per season, PHI 5 days. skin irritants, toxic to non-target organisms (e.g. pollinators)
- Spray foliage with lambda cyhalothrin product (e.g. Conquer super 2.5 EC, Contihalothrin 2.5EC, Lambdaking 2.5EC) Contact and injested pyrethroid insecticide, IRAC group 3 . General Restrictions: WHO class II - (moderately hazardous), 3 applications per season, PHI 5 days. Skin irritants. Very toxic to aquatic organisms, do not use near water ways.

Images.Caption: Adult false codling moth (Marja van der Straten, NVWA Plant Protection Service, Bugwood.org)
False codling moth larvae (Marja van der Straten, NVWA Plant Protection Service, Bugwood.org)
False codling moth damage on pepper (www.altusfood.com)

Authors.Surname: Benjamin K. Badii ( University for Development Studies), Hannah Nuamah (PPRSD, MOFA),  Harunah Braimah (CSIR-Crops Research Institute) and Maxwell Awuku (Chemico Ghana Ltd.)

Sections.Value:
- Prior to planting, plough and harrow the field to destroy diapausing nymphs by exposing them to sunlight
- Plant resistant varieties such as Apagbala and Mafotuya
- Plant early to ensure the crop is well established and better able to withstand an infestation
- Avoid planting cowpea near infested fields to prevent cross-infestation
- Grow cowpea under agronets, 0.4mm mesh size to reduce infestation
- Remove alternative hosts (Centrosema, Musa spp.) from production field
- Rotate cowpea with non-leguminous crops, such as maize
- Intercrop with maize or sorghum to reduce populations of thrips

- Additional relevant crops: French beans, kidney beans, common beans, chick peas, pigeon pea
- Thrips start infesting the plant before the flowers open. This causes the flowers to die and become brown. Begin monitoring at flower bud initiation
- Look for tiny, slim, elongated, shiny black insects on racemes and flowers. Look for silvery leaf spots and silvery streaks on the racemes and pods. Also, look for excreta of thrips visible as small black dots on leaves.
- Pick and open the flower buds to assess for larvae or adult thrips. Alternatively shake the flowers unto a whitepiece of paper to determine the presence of thrips.
- Take control action when more than 2 thrips are found per plant

- Mix 500-1000 grams hot pepper powder with 3 L water and leave for 12 hours. Filter, add additional 1.5 L water to make the concentrate. Add 5g soap and spray at 80L/ha at 10 day intervals during flowering
- Spray with neem extracts Nimacol, Nimbicidine at a rate of 1 match box / L of water or pawpaw leaf extract at a rate of 12 large matured leaves/16L knapsack and spray at 80L/ha at 10 day intervals during flowering

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label.
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance, always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Spray with Deltamethrin product (e.g. Deltapaz 1.25EC, Delete 2.5 SC, Decis 2.5 EC) at 75-100mls/L. It is a pyrethroid (IRAC, 3A). It acts by contact with residual activity. General Restrictions: WHO Class II - Moderately hazardous; Maximum 2 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 14 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non target arthropods.Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near water ways.
- Lamda-cyhalothrin product (Pawa EC, Lambda-Super EC, Controller 2.5EC) 35-40mls/ 15L of water. It is a contact and ingested pyrethroid (IRAC, 3A). General Restrictions: WHO Class II - Moderately hazardous; Maximum 2 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 14 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non target arthropods.Very toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near water ways.

Adult (Georg Goergen/IITA Insect Museum, Cotonou, Benin)
Thrips adults on bean flower (Ko Ko Maung, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies) and Antony Cudjoe (Private Consultant)

Sections.Value:
- Avoid planting citrus near alternate hosts (mango, peppers, watermelons, tomatoes, egg plants) to reduce pest populations
- Harvest early when fruits are mature and green because over-ripe fruits attract fruit piercing moths
- Conserve natural enemies which feed on larvae (e.g. Trichogramma, ants, rove beetles, birds and parasitic wasps) through minimum use of insecticides, and mixed/inter-cropping for enhanced biodiversity
- Clear all bushes and weeds near and under the plantation to rob moths of their hiding places

- Start monitoring as fruits begin to mature. Moths are nocturnal and hide in vegetation around citrus plantations and come out during the night to attack the fruits
- Search twice a week for brown to dark-brown adult moths in neighbouring bushes which serve as indicators of possible infestation
- When clearing bushes and weeds nearby and under the plantation, check for adult moths flying around
- Look for larvae/pupae (which appear as maggots with varying colours and sizes) by cutting fruit open or checking in plant debris under tree canopies
- Take control action when moths are observed in the plantation

- Till the orchard top soil (5 to 10cm deep) to expose pupae to the sun, birds, poultry and parasites
- Infested fallen fruits should be collected daily in sealed polythene bags and exposed to the sun for 2 days before burying (60cm deep) to break life cycle of moths
- Bait with fresh orange fruit juice laced with insecticide killer such as Deltamethrin (see yellow control) at ratio 3:1.
-

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label.
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance, always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of EPA, Ghana

- Fruit piercing moths on citrus are difficult to control because insecticides cannot be applied near the time that fruits are ripe. The adult moths rest on weeds near the citrus plants during the day, waiting for night, making them difficult targets for insecticides . General Restrictions: There is only limited contact between moth and fruit when feeding. There are concerns, too, for human health, because applications to pesticides would be needed near the time of harvest for them to be effective
- Deltamethrin. Pyrethroid insecticide with contact and residual activity IRAC 3A . General Restrictions: WHO Class II (moderately hazardous)

Images.Caption: Achaea lienardi adult moth (Donald Hobern, CC BY, via Wikimedia)
Larva of a related fruit piercing moth (Kim Starr, Starr Environmental, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Benjamin K. Badii ( University for Development Studies), Hannah Nuamah (PPRSD, MOFA) and  Harunah Braimah (CSIR-Crops Research Institute)

Sections.Value:
- Conserve natural enemies (e.g. parasitic wasps, ladybird beetles) by minimizing the use of insecticides
- Avoid heaping of tubers to allow light and air through
- Situate yam farms away from previously infested fields to avoid carrying mealybugs into storage
- Practice crop and land rotation with cereals (e.g. maize, rice, sorghum or millet) to reduce risk of field infestation

- Mealybugs are a problem in prolonged storage of yams. Monitor mealybug populations after 3 months of storage
- Mealybugs prefer warm humid conditions and spread by crawling between tubers.They cause damage to tubers by sucking the sap from their tissues
- Mealybugs look like oval-shaped flightless bugs that have cottony white powdery appearance and sooty moulds
- Inspect twice a week by looking out for white powdery mass on the surfaces of tubers
- Take action when at least one tuber is infested

- Spray harvested tubers or yam plants with a steady stream of water (reasonably high pressure) on the host plant to knock off mealybugs
- Spray soap solution (potassium soaps e.g. "alata samina", "gardian") (add 10-15 tablespoons of liquid soap in 16 L Knapsack and spray on tubers if infested when necessary)
- Treat yam tubers with neem seed extract. Rate: 1 match box of dry seed/1litre of water
- There are no recommended insecticides to control mealybugs on yam in Ghana at this time

Mealybugs on yam tuber (Jerry-Coleby-Williams.net)

Authors.Surname: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies), Hannah Nuamah (PPRSD, MOFA) and  Harunah Braimah (CSIR-Crops Research Institute)

Sections.Value:
- Most injury to rice seedlings occurs shortly after transplanting, so replacement of lost plants will help compensate for injury
- Use the proper irrigation schedules and correct fertilizer recommendations to maintain the crop in the healthiest condition possible to allow the plants to recover from injury by mole crickets
- Encourage biological control agents (sphecid wasps, carabid beetles, nematodes, and fungus) by minimizing insecticide use

- Mole crickets are large, brownish insects. They are rather cricket-like in shape but have mole-like, digging front legs. The adults have wings and many are powerful, though clumsy, fliers. The body is covered with short, dense hairs
- Assess population density of nymphs by checking frequency of soil surface tunneling
- Estimate nymph and adult abundance by flushing with 0.5% aqueous solution of dish washing soap
- If 2 to 4 mole crickets come to the soil surface within three minutes of application of the soap solution, corrective action is justified to reduce mole cricket numbers
- Additional relevant crops: cabbage, carrot, eggplant, lettuce, onion, pepper, potato, sweet potato, tomato

- Use bund shaving and plastering of fresh wet soil to help eliminate the eggs of mole crikets
- During land preparation, search for and collect the nymphs and adults, and destroy
- Flood rice fields for 3-4 days. Level the field for better water control which can help to remove the eggs on the soil and reduce cricket populations
- Set baits by using rice bran, cotton seed meal, or some other grain product plus 2-5% toxicant. Add 5-15% water and 2-5% molasses to the grain toxicant mixture
- Spray with neem: mix 400g of dried powdered leaves to 3 litres of water and apply regularly at 80L/ha

- When using a pesticide (even a botanical home-brew), always wear protective clothing.
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, preharvest interval and max number of sprays

- Flush borrows in soil with pyrethrin based insecticide solution (Deltamethrin 250EC) at rate of 250mls to 20L of water to kill adults. Contact insecticide and stomach poison IRAC group 3A. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous). Check - pesticides might not be allowed in some local IPM schemes. Toxic to aquatic organisms and other aquatic organisms. Do not contaminate surface waters or ditches
- Spray with pyrethroid insecticides like Deltamethrin (e.g. Deltapaz 1.25EC, Delete 2.5 SC, Decis 2.5 EC) Contact insecticide and stomach poison IRAC group 3A. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class II (moderately acute hazardous); Spray only once per season. Pre-harvest interval (p.h.i) 35 days; r.e.i. 3 days.

Factsheets.Title: Mole crickets on rice
ScientificNames: Scapteriscus abbreviatus, S. borellii, S. vicinus, Gryllotalpa africana

Authors.Surname: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies), Hannah Nuamah (PPRSD, MOFA) and  Harunah Braimah (CSIR-Crops Research Institute)

Sections.Value:
- Conserve natural parasites (e.g. Trichogramma spp.) in cashew plantation by avoiding the use of broad spectrum insecticides and intercropping with legumes
- Prune off the green basal/side growths as these are succulent and attractive both as feeding and egg-laying sites for Helopeltis
- Remove alternative host plants such as coffee, kola, mango, avocado, cocoa from production site
- Before planting, ensure that the farm is cleared of weeds which may serve as harbouring sites for Helopeltis
- Apply a 20cm sticky band of grease or petroleum jelly on the tree trunks, 15 cm from the ground

- Adults are 6.5-8.5 mm long, dark brown to reddish brown but with an orange thorax. There is a dark pin-like protrusion from the centre of the thorax. The legs are long and fragile, resembling those of a mosquito.
- Helopeltis species should be monitored throughout the year especially during the months between August and April.
- Check on fruits and shoots for feeding punctures and lesions. Adults cause damage to seedlings and shoots by sucking the sap from their tissues. Feeding punctures appear as water-soaked patches that turn black after 2-3 days.
- Flaming cashew fruits and flowers with flares and kerosene lamps helps attract Helopeltis to enhance population monitoring in plantation
- Inspect cashew plants up to hand height monthly for the presence of Helopeltis and feeding lesions on fruits and shoots.
- Take control action when average numbers reach 6 mosquitoes per 10 trees

- Hand picking of adult bugs from plants may help reduce Helopeltis populations
- Prune off heavily infested portions of plants and dispose outside the plantation to help reduce populations of Helopeltis
- Spray with emulsions such as kerosene, pyrethrum lime and lime sulfer at rate of 550g/L, spray at 60L/ha

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label.
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance. Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Spray with Cypermethrin (360g/l) + Dimethoate (400g/l) product (eg Cypermethoate Super EC, Cyperdem 43.6EC, Cypasect super) at the rate of 1-1.5 litres/ Ha (75-100ml/15L of knapsack). Cypermethrin is a contact and stomach acting pyrethroid IRAC group 3. Dimethoate is a systemic organophosphate IRAC group 1B. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class II (moderately hazardous). Apply a maximum 2 sprays per season. PHI -14 days, REI-1 day. The products are toxic to aquatic organisms. Does not work well in hot weather.

Helopeltis damage on cashew leaves (J.M. Waller/CABI BioScience)
Helopeltis damage on cashew fruit (Dr Saminathan, Vamban)

Authors.Surname: Anne Kimani (UoN); Boniface N. Ndungu (MoALVF); Jacob Ndungu (MoALVF); Miriam Otipa (KALRO) Kenya. Modified for Ghana by: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies),  Antony Cudjoe (Private Consultant) and Maxwell Awuku (Chemico Ghana Ltd.)

Sections.Value:
-  Observe close season to prevent the pest outbreak
- Use early maturing varieties (e.g. AGRA rice, Jasmine 85, Digang) to avoid peak outbreak period
- Flood the field for 1 month to suffocate and kill diapausing larvae and pupae
- Use recommended dose of fertilizers (6 ton FYM, 100:30:30 NPK Kg/Ha for irrigated and 6 ton FYM, 100:20:20 NPK Kg/ha for unirrigated) for increased plant vigour
- Plant early and at the same time as other farmers in the area to reduce damage
- Destroy rice stubbles (by burning) after crop harvest because these harbour the pest

- Monitoring should begin after seedling stage (about 2 weeks after germination)
- Look out for egg masses on the underside of leaves, check for white heads at reproductive stage and dead hearts or drying of the central tiller during vegetative growth
- Check for caterpillars boring at the base of the plant during vegetative stage and on old crop boring on upper nodes feeding towards the base
- When there is more than 1 moth or 1 egg mass/m2 in the nursery, 5% dead hearts or one egg mass or one moth/m2 from planting to pre-tillering and 1 egg mass or 1 moth/m2 at panicle initiation to booting, consider direct control

- Hand pick borer larvae during transplanting or in the nursery and destroy egg masses
- Install light traps @ 5 traps/ha and kill trapped adults physically
-  Raise irrigation water level to flood the land and submerge the eggs and other developing forms of borers
- Apply ground neem powder (a pinch per plant) onto the funnel of young plants. Rate 50gm/2kg ash
- Apply hot pepper + ash at 50gm/2kg ash and apply a pinch per plant funnel onto knee-high young plants
- Consider practices that enhance natural enemy populations (e.g. habitat- flowering plants, reducing broad spectrum chemicals, releasing natural enemies, etc.).

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance. Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Spray with imidacloprid (Confidor 70WG) at a rate of 5g/20 litres water), It is a contact neonicotinoid (IRAC, 4A) . General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous). Toxic to natural enemies, bees, fish and aquatic invertebrates. Maximum of 2 application per season, PHI 14 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Avoid using near water ways. Toxic to bees.
- Spray with acetamiprid (Golan 20SP) at a rate of 8mls/20ltrs of water). Neonicotinoid (IRAC, 4A). General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum of 2 application per season; PHI 7 days. REI 24 hours. Toxic to aquatic organisms do not use near water ways

Images.Caption: Stem borer larva in rice plant (IRRI, www.flikr.com))

Factsheets.Title: Stem borers on rice
ScientificNames: Scirpophaga spp., Chilo spp., Sesamia spp., Maliarpha spp.

Authors.Surname: Rahab Magoti (KALRO), Eunice Sakong (MoALF), Samuel Mburu (MoALF), Miriam Otipa (KALRO), Peninah Munyao (MoALF), Wilson Nabakwe (MoALF) Kenya. Modified for Ghana by: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies) and  Antony Cudjoe (Private Consultant)

Sections.Value:
- Remove, dry and burn old material from the field as well as alternate host plants which includes many types of weeds (e.g. nutgrass, speargrass, Ensente and Musa spp.).
- Raise seedlings in a thrip-free region so that seedlings are not carrying the pest
- Intercrop onions with carrots which repel thrips
- Avoid planting onions near an existing infested field
- Grow onions under agronet, 0.4mm mesh size to reduce infestation
- Plant in well prepared fertile soil to boost vegetative growth and promote plant vigour

- Scout field regularly starting at the 4-5 leaf stage, check spaces between newly emerged leaves, stem and inner neck of the onions for signs of the pest
- Use yellow sticky trap (2 traps per 30cm2) or yellow trays with water as monitoring devices
- Look for silvery leaf spots and patches and excreta of thrips visible as small black dots on leaves
- Inspect seedlings when transplanting for any possible thrips infestation in leaf folds
- Treat when more than two thrips are found per plant sample about 10 plants across the plot.

- Encourage predator activities to reduce thrips population (e.g. avoid clearing all weeds to conserve spiders and predatory mites)
- Mulch with straw to provide shelter for thrip predators (e.g. lace wings) thereby reducing thrip populations
- Use sprinkler irrigation to flush off and reduce thrips population
- Remove heavily infested plant material and burn
- Dust seedlings with wood ash at the rate of 0.3kg/m2 in the morning to kill adult thrips. Apply at 10 days interval from seedling stage to maturity
- Dissolve 50g bar soap with 1ml of nimacol or nimbicidine in 10 L water. Apply on the infested plants

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label.
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance, always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of EPA, Ghana.

- Spray with Cypermethrin + Dimethoate products (eg Cydim Super EC, Cymethoate Super EC, Cypadem 43.6EC) at the rate of 60-80g/l. Cypermethrin contact and stomach pyrethroid IRAC 3; Dimethoate contact and systemic organophosphate IRAC 1B. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class II - (moderately hazardous); 3 applications per season, skin irritants, toxic to non-target organisms (e.g. pollinators), REI- 24 hrs, PHI-14days
- Lamda-cyhalothrin (Master 2.5EC; Kamotrine 2.5EC; Impact 25EC) apply at 100 ml per hectare. contact and ingested pyrethroid IRAC 3. General Restrictions: WHO class II - (moderately hazardous), Pyrethroid, Contact, 3 applications per season, skin irritants, toxic to non-target organisms (e.g. pollinators), water contaminants), REI- 24 hrs, PHI-5days
- Spray with Spirotetramat-based product (100g/L) (eg Movento100SC) at 1L/ha. Tetramic acid derivative IRAC group 23. General Restrictions: WHO class III - (slightly hazardous), 3 applications per season, skin irritants, Dangerous to the envirnment. REI- 24 hrs, PHI-14 days

Effect of thrips infestation on onion plant (Utah State University)

Authors.Surname: Benson Msinde (MOALF), Maurice Okeno (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO) Kenya. Modified for Ghana by: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies), Hannah Nuamah (PPRSD, MOFA)  and Harunah Braimah (CSIR-Crops Research Institute)

Sections.Value:
- Control weeds in the farm to reduce the presence of overwintering stages
- Conserve natural enemies such as ladybirds, lacewings, hoverflies and parasitoids by avoiding the use of broad spectrum insectidies
- Cover plants with agro nets (size 400 m) to exclude the whiteflies from the crop at the nursery stage
- Remove plant residues and alternative hosts such as tomato, cassava, peppers, cowpeas
- Plant repellent crops like marigold around edge of field to repel the whiteflies
- Plant in well prepared fertile soil to promote plant vigour and boost vegetative growth to be able to tolerate infestation
- Keep ample irrigation as water stressed plants are more prone to damage by white fly

- Monitoring for whiteflies should be done every week throughout the plant growth period
- For early detection, look out for whitish brown eggs and/or whitish adults on the underside of young leaves
- Look for a cloud of white insects that resettle soon after the plant is shaken
- Look for sooty mould and ant activity as ants feed on honeydew produced by whiteflies
- Action threshold level is 10-20 plants with symptoms and/or at least 20 whiteflies on at least 10-20 plants /acre

- Use yellow sticky traps to bait kill adults- 4 traps/300m2 at 50cm above ground
- Spray with Azadirachtin 0.03% (50ml/20L water) 20 days after planting

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label.
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance, always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana.

- Spray foliage with acetamiprid product (e.g. Blast 60 EC, Golan 20% SP) at rate 20mls/knapsack. Contact neonicotinoid IRAC group 4A. General Restrictions: WHO class II - (moderately hazardous); Maximum 2 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 14 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non target arthropods. Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near water ways
- Spray with Imidacloprid product (e.g. Confidor 70WG) at a rate of 5g/20 litres water) which is a systemic neonicotinoid (IRAC, 4A). General Restrictions: WHO class II (moderately hazardous). Toxic to natural enemies, bees, fish and aquatic invertebrates. Maximum of 2 application per season, PHI 14 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Avoid using near water ways

Authors.Surname: Benson Msinde (MOALF), Maurice Okeno (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO) Kenya. Modified for Ghana by: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies), Hannah Nuamah (PPRSD, MOFA)  and Harunah Braimah (CSIR-Crops Research Institute)

Sections.Value:
- Clear weeds in the field and its surroundings to reduce the presence of overwintering stages
- Avoid application of broad spectrum insecticides to conserve natural enemies such as ladybirds, lacewings, hoverflies and parasitoids
- Remove and destroy ratoon cassava and other residues by burning or burying deep
- Plant repellent crops such as marigold around the edge of the field to repel the white flies
- Keep ample irrigation as water stressed plants are more prone to damage by white fly

- Monitoring for whiteflies should be done every week throughout the plant growth period especially during the sprouting season
- For early detection, look out for whitish brown eggs and/or whitish adults on the underside of young leaves
- Look for a cloud of white insects that resettle soon after the plant is shaken
- Check for yellowing symptoms on lower leaves of the plant
- Look for sooty mould and ant activity as ants feed on honeydew produced by whiteflies
- Action threshold level is 10-20 plants with symptoms and/or at least 20 whiteflies on at least 10-20 plants /acre

- Use of yellow sticky traps to bait and kill adults and nymphs: 4 traps/300m2 placed at 50cm above ground
- Spray with Azadirachtin 0.03% (e.g. Nimbedicine EC, Nematech WG) 50 ml/20L water 20 days after planting

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance, always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Spray with imidacloprid product (e.g. Confidor 70WG) at a rate of 5g/20 litres water), It is a systemic neonicotinoid IRAC group 4A. General Restrictions: WHO class II (moderately hazardous). Maximum of 2 application per season, PHI 14 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Toxic to natural enemies, bees, fish and aquatic invertebrates. Avoid using near water ways.

Whiteflies on cassava leaf (Neil Palmer (CIAT))

Authors.Surname: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies) and  Antony Cudjoe (Private Consultant)

Sections.Value:
- Synchronize planting timing with other farmers in the area
- Avoid planting pepper near alternate hosts (mango, citrus, watermelons, tomatoes, eggplants, avocado) to reduce pest populations
- Remove non-harvested pepper and wild melon and pumpkins as they will host larvae. Bury 15 to 30 cm deep
- Till the field top soil (5 to 10cm deep) before planting to expose pupae to the sun, birds, poultry and parasites.
- Conserve natural enemies like ants, rove beetles, birds and parasitic wasps by practising mixed/ intercropping to enhance biodiversity, and avoid the use of broad spectrum insecticides
- Prune regularly to improve aeration

- Start monitoring as soon as fruits begin to develop. Inspect plants weekly to look for brownish or yellowish wasp-like flies on plants
- Look for signs of infestation which include dot-like scars, fruit flies laying their eggs inside the skin of the fruit and larvae (maggots) feeding inside the fruit. Check for rotten and fallen fruit. Look for adult flies on the plants.
- Use food baits e.g. waste brewers yeast 45ml/L of water or ripe fruits as bait to monitor presence of fruit flies.
- For early detection, use commercial pheromone traps with trimedlure, cue lure, or methyl eugenol (3 traps/ 50m2)
- Take action when 2-5 adult fruit flies are observed per 5m2 plants in the plantation

- Collect dropped fruits and bury them outside the field at a depth of 60+ cm with plastic bags
- Trap fruit flies using pheromone traps - Methyl Eugenol (Bactrolure liquid) and Cera lure/Capilure impregnated with an insecticide such as deltamethrin as killing agent (see yellow control), at 1 trap per 30m plot.
- Mass trap flies using 2 ml GF120-food bait with 10 ml trimed lure or methyl eugenol + 1ml insecticide filled into plastic bottles with holes, or into commercial traps. Use 3 to 5 traps across a field per 1 acre
- Spray Success Appat (food bait + spinosad (0.24 g/l)). The spray should contain cup (150 ml) of the bait mixed with 5L water. Protection lasts 8 days
- Use pheromone traps containing Methyl eugenol 1 septa per trap, with 1ml Malathion (see yellow control) on a cotton ball. Use 6 traps/ropani, evenly spaced, and use them at the time of flowering and just before fruit set

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label.
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance, always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of EPA, Ghana

- Insecticides used as killing agents in pheromone traps or added to baits
- Malathion. Organophosphate IRAC 1B. General Restrictions: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous)
- Deltamethrin. Pyrethroid insecticide with contact and residual activity IRAC 3A . General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous)

Images.Caption: Adult fruit fly (Eran Finkle, www.flikr.com)
Fruit fly larva inside a pepper fruit (Florida Division of Plant Industry , Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Michael Kumah (Ministry Of Food & Agriculture-PPRSD, Ghana),   phone no.,+233 (0) 207505618/+233(0)247845848  email: mickumah@yahoo.com Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies),  Antony Cudjoe (Private Consultant) and Maxwell Awuku (Chemico Ghana Ltd.)

Sections.Value:
- Remove infested stems and stubbles from the previous harvest and destroy by composting or shred for mulch and use in plantain farm away from maize.
- Rotate maize with cassava, root crops or legumes and come back to plant maize after 2 years.
- Remove leftover maize, sorghum, millet and/or alternate hosts (elephant grass, guinea grass) to reduce carry over of larvae from one growing season to next.
- Modify sowing periods by planting early in the major and minor rain seasons to avoid periods of heavy infestation.
- Intercrop with legumes such as cowpea, or cassava to reduce the incidence of stem borer infestation on maize.

- Monitor 3 weeks after planting.
- Larvae are creamy-white to yellowish-brown, with dark-brown spots on the back. They can grow up to 25 mm long.
- The larvae are found in the leaf funnels, causing scars and holes by feeding.
- They later feed at the growing point, which may be killed (death of the growing point of the plant = dead heart); especially seen in young plants.
- Look for older larvae burrowing into stems and into cobs, weakening the stems, which may break and lodge. Then, direct control is too late.
- Early control can be considered when 5-10% of young plants are damaged, meaning having feeding holes in leaves.

- When young larvae have not yet entered stalks consider spraying hot pepper solution (50g/L) onto young plants every 10 days until tasseling.
- Pour ash dust (half matches box) into leaf-funnel of knee-high young plant.
- Spray Neem extract 50-60ml per 15 litres of water onto young plants every 10-14 days until flowering if threshold is reached.

- Apply products onto young plants particularly onto or into leaf sheath funnels when larvae are still on leaves. When larvae are inside stems or cobs, spraying has no effect
- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, maximum number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains and water sources.
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of EPA, Ghana.

- Apply Deltamethrin-based products (check product label for dosage). It is a Pyrethroid with a contact and stomach poison (2-3 weeks persistence in field). IRAC mode of action 3A. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class II (Moderately hazardous); restricted re-entry interval r.e.i. day; pre-harvest interval p.h.i. 3 days. High risk to predators, pollinators; to fish and other aquatic organisms. Do not contaminate surface waters or ditches; do not apply to plants suffering from drought or other physical distress; do not spray within 6m of field boundary.
- Chlopyriphos ethyl-based products (e.g. Dursban 4E, Pyrinex 48EC, Conpyrifos). Usually at a rate of 60-70mls per 15L knapsack sprayer, but check labels as product differs. A contact and ingested organophosphorus insecticide; IRAC mode of action 1B. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous). Repeat application twice if the pests persist and reaches threshold. Apply early morning or late afternoon, maximum two times per planting season. p.h.i. 35 days; r.e.i. 3 days.

Images.Caption: Larvae of maize stem borer creamy-white to yellowish-brown, with dark-brown spots on back. About 25 mm long when fully grown. (NBAIR)
Bore holes by larvae on the stem near the nodes. (S. Eyres, Department of Agriculture WA)
Maize affected by the stem borer feeding inside (IITA, CC BY-NC)

Authors.Surname: Michael Kumah (Ministry Of Food & Agriculture-PPRSD, Ghana),  phone no.,+233 (0) 207505618/+233(0) 247845848  email: mickumah@yahoo.com

Sections.Value:
- Use certified weed-seed-free crop seeds to prevent the introduction of itch grass weed to new fields since it is easily dispersed via crop seeds.
- Control itch grass weeds near waterways to prevent spread during flooding and storm events.
- Clean tools and farm machinery after use outside field by removing lumps of soil and debris attached to the machine to prevent spread of weed seeds.

- Inspect the maize fields weekly after sowing for itch grass.
- Look for an erect, abundantly tillering annual grass with pale, green leaves, brace roots near the base of the plant, a cylinder-shaped seed head.
- It also has fine hairs on the leaf sheath that can irritate the skin.
- Itch grass is usually about 50 to 100cm high, but can grow up to 4m.
- Its flower-head is thin cylinder-shaped and 3-15cm long.
- Consider direct control when the weed is spotted at 10-15 different locations in the young maize field.

- Hand-pull weeds between maize plants when the weeds are young. Wear gloves to prevent irritation by the fine hairs on the weed
- If the itch grass is still not seeding, you can use it as mulch.
- Remove any individual large itch grass weeds close to the field before seed set.
- Since prevention and green direct control measures are usually efficient there is no need to use synthetic chemical herbicides.

Images.Caption: Hairs on the leaf sheath of young itch grass weed (Cirad)
Flowering heads (BT Wursten)
Dense itch grass weed. (Heike Vibrans, Weeds of Mexico)

Sections.Value:
- Plant early to avoid the period of heavy infestation
- Use resistant/tolerant varieties and/or early maturing varieties if they are available
- Deep plough and harrow to kill larvae/pupae or expose them to direct sunlight and predators
- Intercrop cowpeas with sorghum or maize to reduce the populations of the pod boring pests
- Remove weeds and alternate hosts, such as other leguminous plants, and destroy volunteer cowpea plants because they may harbor the borer
- Do not plant crop on the same piece of land for more than two seasons (rotate cowpea with maize or another non-host)

- Additional relevant crops: common beans, kudzu, lima beans, soybean, cowpeas, lablab, green gram and wild leguminous plants such as Mucuna
- Visit the field every day after flowering to look for signs of damage
- Check adult population using pheromone traps. Place about 4 weeks after sowing cowpea and check at least 3 times a week. When there is an average of two adults per trap take action
- Also, take action when 5 plants are damaged
- Cowpeas can be attacked by the legume pod borer from early budding through to harvest. Look out for:
Flowers: presence of larvae (open the flowers to see them) and round holes
Leaves: folded and stuck together
Pods: A distinct hole where larva entered. Yellowish-brown balls on the outside (larvae faeces)
Eggs: Single or in small groups. On the flowers or flower buds and on the terminal shoots of young plants. Oval, clear and light yellowish-white in colour; a single egg looks like a small drop of water
Larvae/caterpillars: 17-20 mm long. Whitish/pale green in colour with irregular brown-black spots. Head is dark brown. Feed on flowers and foliage. Older larva feed on and bore into the pods. Pupates beneath plant litter
Adult/moth: Wings are blackish-brown with white markings on the forewings and a wingspan of 20-25 mm. Active at night. During the day they rest on the undersides of leaves

- For small infestations, hand-pick eggs and larvae from the plants and crush them
- Prune leaves with white silk threads that stick together and also remove older leaves to allow more sunlight to reach the leaves and stems of the plants
- Neem products have proven to be effective against the larvae and are more cost-effective than synthetic insecticides
- Pod borers are difficult to control with insecticides because they remain hidden in the pod/bean

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: The adult moth has brown forewings with white markings (gailhampshire, Flickr)
Caterpillars are whitish to pale green in colour with irregular brown-black spots. The head is dark brown (Merle Shepard, Gerald R.Carner, and P.A.C Ooi)

Sections.Value:
- Grow crop on land without previous history of the disease, if possible. The fungus survives a long time in soil
- Never plant groundnut straight after crops of tomato, Capsicum or beans, as the fungus commonly attacks those crops and it may be present in the soil
- Add mulch to the soil, such as corn or sorghum straw. This possibly increases certain organisms in the soil that compete with the stem and pod rot fungus
- Keep the soil well fertilized as nitrogen inhibits the fungus
- Remove weeds, but take care not to wound crop plant stems as it would allow entry of the fungus
- After harvest, collect and remove plant debris. Burn it, or bury it to at least 20-30cm deep to kill the fungus
- Use a 2-3-year rotation between crops of groundnut on the same land; e.g. rotate with maize, sorghum, cassava or yam

- Additional relevant crops: legumes, solanaceous crops (tomato, potato, capsicum), cucurbits (pumpkin, squash)
- Monitor for symptoms at least once a week
Dark-brown spots on the stems just below soil level
Yellowing and wilt of a single branch and, after a few days, the wilt of the entire plant
Cottony growth of the fungus on the lower stem and, sometimes, over the soil surface (spreads from plant to plant in warm wet weather)
Rotting pods
Hardened round lumps of fungus, 0.5-2 mm diameter. White at first, becoming light brown

- If plants are beginning to wilt, remove the plants together with the soil around the roots. Burn them or bury to 20-30cm deep. Try not to drop soil or lumps of fungus on other crop plants to avoid spreading it
- Some biological agents could suppress the disease, e.g. Trichoderma harzianum, Gliocladium virens, Trichoderma viride, Bacillus subtilis, and Penicillium spp.
- After harvest, use soil solarization to kill the fungus. Cover moistened soil with a clear polyethylene sheet during hot weather. The fungus will be killed in 4-6 hours at 50C and in 3 hours at 55C

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Dense white mycelial growth and brown sclerotia of Sclerotium rolfsii, causing southern stem rot of peanut (North Carolina State University, Bugwood.org)
Sclerotia of the fungus Athelia rolfsii on groundnut stem  at first white, later light brown (Source: Grahame Jackson, CABI, CC BY 4.0)

Factsheets.Title: Stem and pod rot of groundnut

Authors.Surname:
Nancy Murage (Ministry of Agriculture), Miriam Otipa (KARI), Dora Kilalo Dr. (Nairobi University), Alfayo
Ombuya (KEPHIS), Willis Ochilo (CABI), Kenya. Modified for Ghana by: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies), Hannah Serwah-Nuamah (PPRSD, MOFA), Harunah Braimah (CSIR-CRI), Antony Cudjoe (Private Consultant), Maxwell Awuku (Chemico Ltd)

Sections.Value:
- Grow repellent plants like onions, garlic and marigold with the crop in alternating rows to prevent aphids
- Avoid too much nitrogen (N) fertiliser which makes plants to be very succulent and attractive to aphids
- Conserve natural enemies (e.g. ladybird beetles, hoverflies and Aphidius spp.) by avoiding spraying broad spectrum insecticides
- Keep the fields free of weeds and alternative hosts such as peppers, citrus, cashew and wild mustards
- Mulch with transparent polyethylene sheet as reflectors of UV light to discourage aphids from landing on crop

- Additional relevant crops: Okro (okra), peppers, eggplants
- Start monitoring from seedling stage, look at lower leaves, stems or growing points for soft bodied insects, found in clusters
- Look for brownish nymphs on the underside of leaves or stems. Sometimes aphids have wings
- Monitor at least 3 times in a week for aphids early in the morning or later in the day especially during dry spells
- Scout for attendant ants around the crop which indicate presence of aphids. Check for wilting or yellowing of plants and presence of sooty mould
- Start control measures when infestation is 10-20% (1-2 infested plants/10-20 plants in a plot)

- Remove and bury (50 cm deep) heavily infested crops to help reduce aphid populations
- Apply overhead irrigation on the crop to wash off aphids from the leaves
- Spray soap solution (potassium soaps) (add 10-15 tablespoons of liquid soap in 16 L Knapsack and spray on foliage).
- Spray with botanical extracts, e.g. garlic, neem, red chilli pepper or soap (take 50 g mix in 2 L of water, boil for 15 minutes, allow to cool and spray)

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label.
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance; always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Spray crop with Imidacloprid based product. E.g. Confidor Super (at 10 ml/20 L of water), Consider super 200 SL (at 12 ml/20 L of water). Both are Neonicotinoids (IRAC, 4A), act by contact. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 14 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non-target arthropods.Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near waterways.
- Spray crop with Deltamethrin product e.g. Deltapaz 12.5 EC, Deltamost ULV (each at the rate of 10 ml/ 20 L of water), Miricon EC, Decis 2.5 EC (each at the rate of 15 ml/20 L of water) Pyrethroid IRAC group 3A. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 14 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non-target arthropods.Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near waterways.
- Spray crop with Dimethoate (400g/L) + Cypermethrin 36 g/L) product e.g. Cydim EC or Cypasect 43.6 EC (each at rate of 100 ml/15 L of water), Cydim super EC or Cymethoate super EC (each at rate of 75 ml per 15 L water). These are IRAC 4A group, contact insecticides . General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 14 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non-target arthropods.Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near waterways.
