Colony of aphids feeding on cabbage (Peter Scott)
Aphid damage on cabbage plant (Daniel Kepha, Kenya)

Authors.Surname: Nancy Murage (Ministry of Agriculture ), Miriam Otipa (KARI), Dora Kilalo Dr. (Nairobi University), Alfayo Ombuya (KEPHIS), Willis Ochilo (CABI), Kenya. Modified for Ghana by: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies), Hannah Serwah-Nuamah (PPRSD, MOFA) , Harunah Braimah (CSIR-CRI), Antony Cudjoe (Private consultant), Maxwell Awuku (Chemico Ltd)

Sections.Value:
- Avoid too much nitrogen (N) which makes plants to be very succulent and attractive to aphids
- Grow repellent plants like onions, garlic and marigold with the crop in alternating rows to prevent aphids
- Cover plants with agro nets (size 400 m) to exclude the pest from crop
- Remove and burn crop remnants (residues) immediately after harvest
- Conserve natural enemies (e.g. ladybird beetles, hoverflies and Aphidius sp.) by avoiding spraying broad spectrum insecticides

- Additional relevant crops: tomato, eggplant
- Start monitoring from seedling stage, look at lower leaves, stems or growing points for soft bodied insects, found in clusters
- Keenly check underside of leaves, shoots and stems for immobile aphids
- Look for curled, wrinkled or cupped leaves, and honeydew on infested crops
- Monitor (at least three times in a week) for aphids early in the morning or later in the day especially during dry spells
- Start control measures when there is 10-20 % infestation (i.e. 1-2 infested plants/10-20 plants in a plot)

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label.
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance; always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Spray crop with Imidacloprid product (e.g. Confidor super (20%), Consider super 200SL) at 10 ml/2 L of water. Systemic neonicotinoid (IRAC 4A). General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 14 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non-target arthropods. Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near waterways.
- Spray crop with Deltamethrin-based products (e.g. Deltacan, Delete 2.5 SC, Decis 2.5 EC) each at 10-15 ml/2 L of water. Contact pyrethroid (IRAC 3A). General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 5 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non-target arthropods. Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near waterways.
- Spray with Emamectin benzoate (12 g/L) + Imidacloprid (50 g/L) insecticide (e.g. Dean 62 EC at 20 ml/L of water). Emamectin is an avermectin, IRAC 6 + Imidacloprid, systemic neonicotinoid IRAC 4A. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous), Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 5 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non-target arthropods. Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near waterways.

Factsheets.Title: Aphids on chilli and green pepper

Authors.Surname: Nancy Murage (Ministry of Agriculture), Miriam Otipa (KARI), Dora Kilalo Dr. (Nairobi University), Alfayo Ombuya (KEPHIS), Willis Ochilo (CABI), Kenya. Modified for Ghana by: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies), Hannah Serwah-Nuamah (PPRSD, MOFA), Harunah Braimah (CSIR-CRI), Antony Cudjoe (Private Consultant), Maxwell Awuku (Chemico Ltd)

Sections.Value:
- Conserve natural enemies e.g. by avoiding broad spectrum insecticides
- Cover plants with agro nets (size 400 m mesh) to exclude the pest from crop
- Grow plants with repellent effects on aphids (e.g. marigold, onions) as border/barrier crops
- Use dry cow dung and green herb/ shrub leaves to make smoke, during early morning or late evening hours, which should be on the direction of wind to prevent pest from colonizing the crop
- Apply well decomposed poultry manure (850 kg/ha) to ensure high plant vigour

- Additional relevant crops: maize, cotton, okra
- Begin monitoring at seedling stage, scout for attendant ants climbing up and down egg plant
- Check keenly on plants for slow moving grey to blackish insects that are normally in colonies on underside of leaves as well as on soft new shoot tips or buds
- Look for sticky, honeydew that is covered in a black sooty mould on lower foliage
- Threshold: If 2-3 out of 20-30 plants have at least two aphid colonies, institute control measures

- Spray the infested areas of a plant with a strong jet of water to wash aphids from plants
- Spray both sides of the leaf with soapy water (1 ml/1 L water). Spray early in the morning or evening so that the spray does not dry quickly
- Collect and release biocontrol products such as Aphidius spp., ladybirds, lacewings and parasitic wasps. Contact PPRSD for direction and assistance
- Spray with botanical extracts e.g. mixture of garlic, neem, red chilli pepper and soap. Take 50 g mixture of equal quantities of each in 2 L of water, boil for 15 minutes, allow to cool, then spray during evening hours.

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label.
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance; always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Spray crop with Imidacloprid product (e.g. Confidor super, Consider super 200 SL) each at 10 ml/20 L of water. Systemic neonicotinoid (IRAC 4A) . General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum number of treatments: twice per one season. PHI is 10 days; REI 24 hours. Highly toxic to bees and other non-target arthropods. Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near water ways.
- Spray crop with Deltamethrin product (e.g. Deltacan, Decis 2.5 EC) each at 10-15 ml/20 L of water. Contact pyrethroid (IRAC 3A). General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning or later in the day. PHI 5 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near water ways; High risk to bees and other non-target arthropods. Dont spray when plants are flowering
- Spray with Emamectin benzoate (12 g/L) + Imidacloprid (50 g/L) insecticide (e.g. Dean 62 EC) at 15 ml/L of water. Emamectin is an avermectin, IRAC 6 + Imidacloprid, systemic neonicotinoid IRAC 4A . General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum number of treatments: one per season. PHI is 10 days; REI 24 hours

Authors.Surname: Nancy Murage (Ministry of Agriculture), Miriam Otipa (KARI), Dora Kilalo Dr. (Nairobi University), Alfayo Ombuya (KEPHIS), Willis Ochilo (CABI), Kenya. Modified for Ghana by: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies), Hannah Serwah-Nuamah (PPRSD, MOFA), Harunah Braimah (CSIR-CRI), Antony Cudjoe (Private Consultant), Maxwell Awuku (Chemico Ltd)

Sections.Value:
- Conserve natural enemies e.g. by avoiding spraying broad spectrum insecticides
- Cover plants at vegetative stage with agro nets (size 400 m mesh) from seedling stage to exclude alate aphids from migrating into farm.
- Grow plants with repellent effects (e.g. marigold, onions, garlic) in alternating rows with okro to repel aphids.
- Use dry cow dung and green manure herb/shrub leaves to make smoke, during early morning or late evening hours, which should be on the direction of wind to prevent aphids landing on field
- Apply poultry manure (after 1 week decomposition at 850 kg/ha to ensure high plant vigour

- Additional relevant crops: maize, sorghum, tomato, groundnut, cotton, eggplant
- Begin monitoring at seedling stage, twice a week early in the morning or later in the day especially during dry spells
- Scout for slow moving grey to blackish aphids that are normally in colonies on underside of leaves as well as on soft new shoot tips or buds
- Scout for attendant ants climbing up and down on okro plant which are indicators of presence of aphids
- Look for sticky honeydew that is covered in a black sooty mould on lower foliage
- Randomly examine 20 to 30 plants, if 2 or 3 plants have at least two aphid colonies, implement control measures

- Spray infested foliage with a strong jet of water to wash off and reduce aphid numbers
- Spray soap solution (potassium soaps) (add 10-15 tablespoons of liquid soap in 16 L Knapsack and spray on foliage)
- Release biocontrol products such as Aphidius spp. (which can be purchased locally in biontrol companies in Ghana)
- Spray plants with botanical pesticides such as neem seed extract 3 weeks interval at rate of 2 kg/15 L of water

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label.
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance. Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Spray crop with Imidacloprid product (e.g. Confidor super (20%), Consider super 200 SL) at 10 ml/2 L of water. Systemic neonicotinoid (IRAC 4A). General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning or later in the day. PHI 14 days, REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non-target arthropods. Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near waterways.
- Spray crop with Deltamethrin-based product (Deltacan, Delete 2.5 SC, Decis 2.5 EC), each at 10-15 ml/2 L of water. Contact pyrethroid (IRAC 3A). General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning or later in the day. PHI 5 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non-target arthropods.Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near waterways.
- Spray with Emamectin benzoate (12 g/L) + Imidacloprid (50 g/L) insecticide (e.g. Dean 62 EC) at 15 ml/L of water. Emamectin is an avermectin, IRAC 6 + Imidacloprid, systemic neonicotinoid IRAC 4A. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous), Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 5 day, REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non-target arthropods.Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near waterways.

Authors.Surname: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies), Hannah Serwah-Nuamah (PPRSD, MOFA), Harunah Braimah (CSIR-CRI), Antony Cudjoe (CSIR-CRIG), Maxwell Awuku (Chemico Ltd)

Sections.Value:
- Conserve natural enemy populations (ladybugs, parasitic wasps, hoverflies, lacewings and entomopathogenic fungi) by reducing use of pesticides, and encourage vegetative growth by growing cover crops such as Talinum triangulari (Bokoboko)
- Do not use cashew cultivars that continuously produce new shoots (e.g. Hybrid cashew)
- Keep the plantation free of weeds and alternative hosts such as avocado, mango, indian almond and wild mustards
- Maintain good soil fertility to ensure high seedling vigour

- Additional relevant crops: avocado, mango
- Start monitoring from seedling stage and check plants weekly for adults and nymphs of aphids
- Randomly select 5 trees in the field and count the number of shoots/plant attacked by aphids and note the level of natural enemies in a circle of 28 cm
- Inspect plants for honeydew and sooty mould on leaves and watch out for ants movements up and down the tree
- Consider control measures in cases of severe infestation (i.e. 30% of infested shoots) and a very low level of natural enemies

- Prune branches of severely attacked plants with active growth over an extended period
- Spray the infested areas of seedlings with a strong jet of water to wash off aphids and reduce their numbers
- Spray soap solution (potassium soaps, e.g. alata samina) (add 10-15 tablespoons of liquid soap in 16 L Knapsack and spray on foliage).

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear PPE and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance, always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MoFA, Ghana

- Spray crop with Imidacloprid-based product (e.g. Confidor Super, Consider super 200 SL) at 10ml/20L of water. These are Neonicotinoids (IRAC, 4A) with systemic action. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 14 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non-target arthropods.Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near waterways.
- Spray crop with Deltamethrin product e.g. Deltacan (at 10ml/20L of water), Decis 2.5 EC (at 15ml/20L of water). Sysnthetic pyrethroid (IRAC, 3A) with contact action. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 14 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non target arthropods. Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near waterways.
- Spray crop with Dimethoate + Cypermethrin product (e.g. Cydim EC, Cydim super EC, Cypasect 43.6 EC, Cymethoate super EC) at 250g/l. Dimethoate is an oganophosphate (IRAC 1B) Cypermethrin is a pyrethroid with contact action (IRAC, 3A). General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 14 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non-target arthropods.Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near waterways.

Factsheets.Title: Aphids on cashew and citrus
ScientificNames: Toxoptera aurantii, T. citricidus, Aphis spiraecola, Myzus persicae

Authors.Surname: Sheku Max Kanteh (Njala University), Fatmata Kaiwa (University of Sierra Leone), Amadou Alami-Bangura (MAFFS) and Wusu Kamara (MAFFS), Sierra Leone. Modified for Ghana by: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies), Hannah Serwah-Nuamah (PPRSD, MOFA), Harunah Braimah (CSIR-CRI), Antony Cudjoe (Private Consultant), Maxwell Awuku (Chemico Ltd)

Sections.Value:
- Harvest grains early or promptly to avoid field infestation transfer into storage
- Clean the storage facility thoroughly and burn all sweepings, stored cowpea should not be kept on a bare floor
- Paint the storage facility or fill up all cracks and crevices to make insect pests easy to detect
- Avoid the use of old storage bags and containers. Otherwise clean bags and storage containers before filling grain
- Ensure that grains are clean and dried to a safe moisture level of 8- 10 % before storage
- Use airtight containers, e.g. Purdue tripple plastic bags for storage

- Additional relevant crops: groundnuts, french beans, pigeon pea, mung beans
- Monitor 2-3 weeks after storage of grains. Adults are small brown beetles. Larvae (which are responsible for major damage) are small, white, C-shaped worms
- Look in grains for adult beetles or cream coloured eggs or exit holes on grains
- Look for powder or dust in the bag. This is the crumbs created by the larvae feeding on the grains
- If inspection reveals at least 3 infested grains or 1 adult beetles per 2kg of sample, initiate direct control

- Remove grains from store and sun dry for at least 3 days to kill adults and developing larvae
- Mix 5 ml of groundnut oil to 1 kg of cowpea grains and store in air-tight containers (for short-time storage and small quantities of grains)
- Add 1500 g of dried chilli to one bag of dried cowpea grains (for long-time storage)
- Mix seeds with non-toxic chemicals such as vegetable oils or neem (Azadirachta indica) seed extracts (e.g. 0.03 % Nimbedicine EC), Nematech WG. Mix at 2 L to 1 kg seed and sun dry before storage

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance, always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Disinfect storage facility and bags with pirimiphos-methyl product (e.g. Antuka EC, Ateco super 25 EC) at 250g/L. Organophosphate, IRAC group 1B . General Restrictions: Moderately hazardous (WHO Class II); Following disinfection wait 6 hours before entry; Maximum 2 applications per 6 months.
- Fumigate grains with aluminium phosphide (e.g. Temephos or phostoxin tablet). Use one tablet per 25 kg storage bag. Phosphide, IRAC group 24A. General Restrictions: WHO - Fumigant, Very toxic if swallowed or inhaled; Following fumigation, wait 6 months before consumption or sale. Tablets are recommended to be used in air-tight containers

Authors.Surname: Cyrus Njoroge, Peninah Munyao (Ministry Of Agriculture, Livestock and Fisheries), Maureen Kuboka (Koppert Biological Systems), Kenya. Modified for Ghana by: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies), Hannah Serwah-Nuamah (PPRSD, MOFA), Harunah Braimah (CSIR-CRI), Antony Cudjoe (Private Consultant), Maxwell Awuku (Chemico Ltd)

Sections.Value:
- Keep the nursery and field free of weeds that may act as alternate hosts to cutworms
- Plough the field before transplanting during the dry spells to expose the cutworm to natural enemies and extreme heat
- Remove and burn crop debris before planting
- Intercrop cabbage with mustard at every 15 rows of cabbage as a trap crop
- Conserve natural enemies like, spiders, parasitic wasps, praying mantis, ants, and birds by avoiding the use of chemical pesticides

- Additional relevant crops: okro, peppers, eggplants, cowpeas, cereal crops
- Start monitoring for cutworms at seedling stage i.e. soon after germination
- Look for dry wilted lettuce, discoloured plants, or cut or fallen seedlings in a small zone
- Regularly for larvae - for soft bodied, green to dark brown caterpillars at the base of the plant and on the underside of leaves and look for whitening or chlorotic lesions on leaves and dried leaves
- Consider direct control when there are more than 5 larvae/10 plants in the farm

- Check and remove egg masses and caterpillars from plants and crush them
- Dig around the damaged plant to get the cutworms and mechanically kill them
- Flood the area to suffocate the larvae in the soil if you are growing lettuce in deep soils
- Mix equal quantities of sawdust, bran and molasses with enough water to make mixture sticky and spread around base of plants to attract and kill caterpillars
- Drench at seedling stage with Azadrachtin 0.03% (e.g. Nimbedicine EC, Nematech WG) at a rate of 35ml/L of water to reduce infestation drastically

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label.
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance. Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana.

- Spray plants with Alpha-cypermethrin based product e.g. Fastrack 10 SC at 10ml/L of water. Synthetic contact pyrethroid (FRAC group 3A) . General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning or later in the day. PHI 14 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non target arthropods. Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near water =ways.

Authors.Surname: Cyrus Njoroge, Peninah Munyao (Ministry Of Agriculture, Livestock and Fisheries), Maureen Kuboka (Koppert Biological Systems), Kenya. Modified for Ghana by: Benjamin K. Badii (University for Development Studies), Hannah Serwah-Nuamah (PPRSD, MOFA), Harunah Braimah (CSIR-CRI), Antony Cudjoe (Private Consultant), Maxwell Awuku (Chemico Ltd)

Sections.Value:
- Plough fields 14 days before transplanting during the dry spell to expose the cutworm to the natural enemies and the heat of sun
- Place sticks next to or in contact with stems of seedlings. Sticks confuse the arriving larvae so that they rarely find the okra plants
- Conserve natural enemies like, spiders, parasitic wasps, praying mantis, ants, and birds by minimizing insecticide use; do not spray when natural enemy numbers are high.
- Delay transplanting until the stems are too wide for the cutworms to encircle and/or too hard for it to cut to prevent cutworm damage
- Remove and burn crop debris before planting

- Use flashlight to hand pick caterpillars at night or very early morning before they return into the soil
- Flood field for 3 days before sowing and transplanting to suffocate and kill cutworm caterpillars in the soil
- Drench at seedling stage with crude neem extract to reduce infestation drastically. Apply at 35 ml/L of water during morning hours
- Mix equal quantities of sawdust, bran and molasses with enough water to make mixture sticky and spread around the base of the plants in the evenings

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label.
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance, always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Spray Bt based product (e.g Bypel) at Rate of 55-550 g/Ha (IRAC, 11A). General Restrictions: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous); Apply as soon as the larvae appear in the field. Repeat application every 7-10 days. Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 7-14 days. REI 24 hours. Apply mixture as soon as possible after preperation. Do not apply if rain is expected in the next 6 hrs and store this product away from direct sunlight
- Lamda-cyhalothrin based product (e.g. Pawa, controller, lambda super) each at 35-40 ml/15 L of water. These are sysnthetic pyrethroids (IRAC, 3A), with contact activity. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum 2 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 14 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non-target arthropods.Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near water ways.

Authors.Surname: Cyrus Njoroge, Peninah Munyao (Ministry Of Agriculture, Livestock and Fisheries), Maureen Kuboka (Koppert Biological Systems), Kenya. Modified for Ghana by: Benjamin K. Sections.Value:
- Practice farm sanitation. Keep the nursery and field free of weeds and ratoon crops that may act as alternate host and reservoirs to the cutworm
- Deep plough and harrow fields before transplanting to expose the cutworm to natural enemies and sun heat
- Remove and burn all crop residues before planting
- Intercrop onion with mustard at every 15 rows of onion as a trap crop
- Conserve natural enemies like, spiders, parasitic wasps, praying mantis, ants, and birds by minimizing the use of insecticides; do not spray insecticides when natural enemy numbers are high in the field

- Additional relevant crops: peppers, eggplants, beans, cereal crops
- Begin monitoring at seedling stage, look for dry wilted and discoloured onion plants. Infestation may show in small restricted areas. If the moths are present, scout for presence of larvae
- Check daily for caterpillars at base of the plants and inside the leaves. Look for stout soft bodied green to dark-brown caterpillars (5-10 mm) with stripped margins at the back
- Early in the morning flush larvae using a mixture of lemon scenting dishwashing liquid at 2 tablespoon/2 gal of water
- Ensure crop is washed after flushing to minimise risk of phytoxicity to the crop
- If 5-10 caterpillars are observed, initiate control measures

- Remove and destroy egg masses and caterpillars from plants and crush them
- Dig around the damaged plant to unearth and mechanically kill the caterpillars
- Flood the area to suffocate the larvae in the soil if you are growing onion in deep soils
- Drench at seedling stage with crude neem extract at 35 ml/L of water to reduce infestation drastically. Apply in mornings or evenings
- Mix equal quantities of sawdust, bran and molasses with enough water to make mixture sticky and spread around the base of the plants in the evenings

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label.
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance. Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana.

- Spray Bt based products (e.g. Bypel) at a rate of 55-550 g/Ha (IRAC, 11A). General Restrictions: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous); Apply as soon as the larvae appear in the field. Repeat application every 7-10 days. Maximum 3 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 7-14 days. REI 24 hours. Apply mixture as soon as possible after preperation. Do not apply if rain is expected in the next 6 hrs and store this product away from direct sunlight
- Lamda-cyhalothrin based products (e.g. Pawa, Controller, Lambda supper) each at 35-40 ml/15 L of water. These are synthetic pyrethroids (IRAC, 3A), with contact activity. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum 2 applications per season in the morning and later in the day. PHI 14 days. REI 24 hours. Eye and skin irritant. Highly toxic to bees and other non-target arthropods. Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near waterways.

Authors.Surname: John Lovelace Kpodoviah (DAES, MOFA),  Birgitta Oppong-Mensah (CABI), Claud Kwadwo Mintah (PPRSD, MOFA), Benjamin K. Badii, University for Development Studies, Ghana

Sections.Value:
- Avoid planting citrus near alternative host plants (eg, guava, sheanut, mango etc.) or subject them to the same treatments
- Collect dropped fruits regularly and bury least 50 cm below the soil surface outside of the field. Alternatively put fruits in a thick black plastic bag, seal and expose to sunshine for 7 days
- Harvest early (at physiological maturity) to prevent flies attacking fruits
- Move harvested fruits out of field as early as possible as fruit flies will attack fruits even after harvest
- Keep weeds reasonably low by slashing and weeding around the basins just before flowering
- Conserve natural enemies such as ants, rove beetles, birds and parasitic wasps by avoiding use of pesticides

- Start monitoring as soon as fruits begin to mature, search twice a week on fruits for adult fruit flies
- Check fruits for signs of insect. Look for small punctures or 'sting' marks on the skin where the fly lays its eggs, these are very small but some sticky gum may be present. On mature citrus the sting mark might be a brown depressed spot and on immature citrus the green skin may colour prematurely round the sting
- Cut open dropped fruits and check for the presence of maggots in them
- For early detection and monitoring use: i) food baits e.g. waste brewers yeast 45ml/L of water or ripe fruits ii) pheromone traps with trimedlure, cuelure, or methyl eugenol (2 traps/ 50m2)
- Take action as soon as fruit fly damage is observed or when flies are detected in the traps

- Regularly collect drop/fallen fruits and dispose off properly. Dig and bury collected fruits to about 50 cm deep (length of one cutlass)
- Collect fruits into thick, black plastic bags, tie bag firmly and expose to the sun for 7-10 days (duration may be longer during the rainy season). Do not heap the bags
- Till the orchard top soil (5-10cm) to expose pupae to the sun, birds, poultry and parasites
- Use lure and kill pheromone traps containing a mixture of 10ml methyl eugenol + 1ml insectide (see yellow list). Set 4-6 traps per acre evenly spaced. Set the traps at flowering and refill after every 8 weeks if locally made and 4 weeks if a commercial trap

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Spray with spinosad (GF120-bait/Success Appat) Success Appat (0.24 g/l)) at a ratio of 1 part product to 3 parts water. General Restrictions: Spray trees fully and repeat after 1 week. Monitor for fruit flies before further applications. Spinosad is highly toxic to aquatic invertebrates, do not use near waterways
- Insecticides used as killing agents in pheromone traps: Malathion, Organophosphate, IRAC 1B; Deltamethrin, pyrethroid with contact and residual activity, IRAC 3A; Acetamiprid, systemic neonicotinoid, IRAC 4A; lambda-cyhalothrin, pyrethroid contact and ingested, IRAC 3A. General Restrictions: Malathion - WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous) All others WHO toxicity class lI (Moderately hazardous).

Fruit damaged by fruit fly and secondry fungal infection (Eric Boa, CABI)
Fruit fly larvae inside a fruit (Eric Boa, CABI)

Sections.Value:
- Use resistant varieties if available
- Use clean planting material
- Plant early, at the start of the rainy season, to encourage growth of healthy plants that are able to survive an attack. Cassava plants between 2 and 9 months old are the most vulnerable
- Do not plant downwind from an infested field as the mite can travel via wind
- Limit the movement of people within an infested field as this can spread the mite
- Intercrop with pigeon pea, in double or triple rows, to reduce the damage and also increase yields
- Encourage the presence of predators that feed on mites by reducing chemical use and keeping wild plants that attract the predators (e.g. Euphorbia heterophylla)
- Rotate crop with non-host plants

- Start monitoring regularly after 4-6 weeks after planting:
- Mites:
Green to yellowish in colour and can barely be seen by the naked eye (they look like tiny greenish-yellowish spots)
They feed on young leaves and may also be on fresh sprouts of stem cuttings
- Symptoms:
Leaves: chlorotic spots (yellow spotting). Leaves become mottled and then die. Leaves may fall off leaving the shoot tip to look like a 'candle stick' if infestation is severe
Roots: stunted bulking, lack of fresh root growth
- Use a hand lens to look for cassava green mites on the underside of leaves, along the veins and close to the base of the leaf. Mite populations increase on the young leaves in the early part of the dry season
- Symptoms can look similar to that of cassava mosaic virus (CMV), but CMV causes larger greenish-yellowish patches and leaf distortion

- During the growing period and after harvest, destroy the infested stems outside of the field (the mite can survive on cassava cuttings for up to 60 days)
- Release natural enemies available in your country such as predatory mites Typhlodromalus manihoti and T. aripo or predatory insects such as Stethorus and Holobus (=Oligota) spp.
- Remove infested tips with hand pruners and destroy outside of the field
- Control the mites by spraying a solution of:
3 garlic plants crushed in 10L of water, with 7gm of powder soap
500 g of onion crushed in 10L of water, with 2 teaspoons of vegetable oil and 7gm of soap powder

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Symptoms on cassava leaves (CABI)
Cassava leaves with chlorotic (pale) spots caused by cassava mites (IITA)

Sections.Value:
- The coffee berry borer causes most damage in established and large scale coffee plantations where cultural practices are scarce or non-existent. The following cultural practices are important to reduce the damages:
- Use the same variety
- Highly shaded coffee plantations favour the proliferation of the borer. Prune and thin shading trees and coffee trees to avoid excessive shade conditions
- Avoid movement of infested fruits in areas free of the coffee berry borer
- Place mulch such as straw on the soil
- Balanced fertilization
- Control weeds
- Timely harvest (as soon as possible)
- After harvest, rigorously collect by hand all of the remaining fruits attached to the branches (especially the lower branches) or on the soil. Bury the fruits at 50 cm or boil if infestation level is high
- Elimination of decaying or abandoned coffee plantations

- Monitor developing fruits each week for infestation, from the eighth week after flowering. Divide the cropland into plots of 5 ha. From 20 plants/plot, collect 100 random fruits/plant. Cut the fruits in 2 parts and check for eggs, larvae, nymphs and adults. Sample and monitor the fallen fruits too
- To monitor adult population levels, set 20 baited traps/ha for 3 months at the onset of the rains. See the description of the technique in the direct control section
- Adults are black beetles. The female is 1.4-1.6 mm long X 1 mm wide, and the male is much smaller. Larvae are white, with a black head and legless
- The female perforates around the apex and the perforations deepen towards the centre of the seeds forming galleries. If the perforations are crusts, brown or rotten, it means that the larvae are inside the seeds and protected
- Take control measures when infestation level reaches 5 %

- Use baited traps (16/hectare) to catch adults flying after the first rains or in inter-harvest period (when the coffee berry borer is emerging and a few fruits are available). Fill in half the handmade traps (plastic bottles with two openings) with bait (1:1 ethanol: methanol) and place in the middle of the trees (1.5 m). Check every 5 days
- Fumigation in the morning with the fungus Beauveria bassiana 1 kg/ha when the coffee berry borer begins to attack the fruit (8 weeks after flowering)
- Collect ripe and dry fruits every two weeks to remove reproductive sites of the coffee berry borer
- Release of parasitoids if available in your country such as Cephalonomia stephanoderis or Prorops nasuta

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), S. Akrofi (CSIR-PGRRI) & P. Beseh (PPRSD, MOFA)

Sections.Value:
- This is a seed borne disease plant certified disease free seeds
- Transplant only healthy seedlings.
- Mulch plants with straw soon after transplanting to reduce spread of spores already in the soil through rain splash
- Control weeds of all kinds including volunteer crops to reduce sources of inoculum
- Practise crop rotation after two seasons of lettuce with crops such as sorghum, millet or cassava
- Bury old plant debris shortly after harvest to reduce inoculum level available in the next season.
- Seeds can be treated with a fungicides before sowing to prevent the disease (see details of fungicides in the yellow column)

- Monitor fields weekly looking for dark brown to black lessions with yellow halos on leaf surfaces
- Look for wilting and leaf drop
- Spots affect quality of leaves, therefore early control action is required when first observed
- Apply direct control as soon as first symptons are observed to reduce spread of the disease OR use a protectant fungicide as a preventative measure

- When the disease is at a low incidence, rogue out all infected plants as they are seen and destroy by burning
- Collect fallen leaves regulary in the season and destroy by burning to reduce availabilty of spores

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Apply Mancozeb (e.g. Agrithane 80WP, Benco 80WP, Damazeb 80WP Dizcozeb 80WP) at a rate of 75g/15L of water. Multi-site broad spectrum fungicide, FRAC group: M3. General Restrictions: WHO Class U - Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use. Apply 3 times at 7-10 day intervals. REI-24hrs; PHI-14 days. Very toxic to aquatic organisms - do not apply near waterways
- Apply Captan (Merpan 50WP) at 75-120g/15L of water. Multi-site broad spectrum fungicide, FRAC group:M 4. General Restrictions: WHO Class U - Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use. Apply 3 times in a season at 7-10 day intervals. REI-24hrs; PHI-14 days. Very toxic to aquatic organisms - do not apply near waterways
- Treat seeds with Mancozeb at 3-4g/kg of seed before sowing. FRAC code: M3. General Restrictions: WHO Class U (Unlikely to present any hazard under normal use)
- Treat seeds with Folpet (Folpan 50 WP) at 3-4g/kg of seed. FRAC code: M4 . General Restrictions: WHO Class U (Unlikely to present any hazard under normal use)

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), S. Akrofi (CSIR-PGRRI) & P. Beseh (PPRSD, MOFA)

Sections.Value:
- Use certified seeds and do not use seeds frominfected fields. Extract seeds from healthy pepper plants (obtain seeds from healthy fruits)
- Effectively destroy old plant debris through burning immediately afer harvest
- Transplant only healthy seedlings from nursery
- Chilli and peppers should be rotated every 2 years with other non-host crops (e.g. maize, sorghum or groundnuts)
- Ensure good drainage on the fields
- Control weeds effectively because of wide host range of pathogen.

- Monitor field after transplanting looking for early leaf spot lesions (dark brown to black spots). Anthracnose can appear at any stage of development.
- As plant grows, look for dieback in stem branches
- Look also for black sunken lesions on matured fruits and fruit drop
- Check for circular or angular sunken lesions with concentric rings on fruits
- Use direct control measures at the first signs of disease. Fungicides can be applied at first symptoms to reduce spread but preventative applications can also be used
- Rogue and destroy early plants that show disease symptoms and burn to destroy

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Apply mancozeb (80%) (e.g. Agrithane 80WP, Benco 80WP, Damazeb 80WP Dizcozeb 80WP) at a rate of 75g/15L of water. Multi-site broad spectrum fungicide. FRAC group: M3 . General Restrictions: WHO Class U - Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use. Apply 3 times in a season at 7-10 day intervals based on field situation. REI-24hrs; PHI-14 days. Very toxic to aquatic organisms - do not apply near waterways
- Apply fosetyl-Al (e.g. Chemoliete) at 35-40g/15L when symptoms persist. Systemic fungicide, FRAC group: 33. General Restrictions: WHO Class U - Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use. REI-24hrs; PHI-14 days. Apply 3 times in a season at 7-10 day intervals based on field situation. Harmful to aquatic organisms
- Apply Folpet (Folpan 50WP) at 45g/15L of water. Broad spectrum, contact. FRAC group: M4. General Restrictions: WHO Class U - Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use. REI-24hrs; PHI-14 days. Apply 3 times in a season at 7-10 day intervals based on field situation.
- Apply Maneb (e.g. Trimangol 80WP, Kenmaneb etc) at a rate of 30-45g/15L. Multi-site contact fungicide. FRAC group: M3. General Restrictions: WHO Class U - Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use. Start application as soon as symptoms are observed. Spray at 7-10 day intervals. Observe PHI of 7days and REI of 24hrs

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), S. Akrofi (CSIR-PGRRI) & P. Beseh (PPRSD, MOFA)

Sections.Value:
- Use disease-free planting materials. Tag healthy plants at harvest to obtain healthy seed yams. There are no known resistant varieties in Ghana
- Destroy crop debris after harvest by burning or ploughing in
- Use larger planting distances in areas which have the disease to reduce plant to plant trasmissions through rain splash
- Treat sett with broad spectrum fungicides before planting (see yellow control)
- Practise early staking to reduce field incidence and severity
- Water yam (D. alata) is highly susceptible to anthracnose. Avoid planting it in a field with white yam (D. rotundata)
- Practise 3 year crop rotations with maize
- Plant barrier crops such as maize in between mounds to reduce plant to plant transmission
- Control weeds and all other crops that are of no interest because of the wide host range of pathogen

- Monitor plants weekly in the field:
- Check for small, dark brown spots or black lesions on leaves with or without a chlorotic halo
- On older plants look for black lesions on vines and dieback
- Anthracnose outbreaks on yam occur in seasons with continuous heavy rains or drought. Be ready to take effective actions when these conditions are forcasted
- Look for leaf necrosis; dieback of stem; withered leaves and scorched appearance

- Remove early infected leaves with leaf spot symptoms and destroy by burning at early stages of development
- Note that yam farmers hardly rogue their plants unless the plants are heavily diseased

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Dip seed yams in a solution of fungicide before planting. Spraying the vines to prevent anthracnose is not economical
- Prepare a solution of mancozeb (80%) at a rate of 5g/1L of water . Multi-site broad spectrum fungicide. FRAC group: M3. General Restrictions: WHO Class U (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use). Dip seed yams in fungicidal solution before planting
- Prepare a solution of Fosetyl-Al at 2.5g/1L of water before planting. Systemic fungicide. FRAC group: 33. General Restrictions: WHO Class U (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use) Dip seed yams in fungicidal solution before planting
