Leaves with necrotic areas caused by anthracnose (Sarah Simons)

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), S. Akrofi (CSIR-PGRRI) & P. Beseh (PPRSD, MOFA)

Sections.Value:
- Use good quality certified seed
- Transplant only seedlings that are healthy (free from brown spot symptoms)
- Destroy volunteer rice crop and infected rice debris by burning soon after harvest
- Control weeds in season and out of season
- Amend soil with calcium silicate to boost resistance to the disease
- Seed treatment: pre-soak seeds in cold water for 8 hours and treat with hot water(5354C) for 1012 minutes before planting OR treat with fungicide for prevention before sowing (see yellow control column for details)

- Monitor crop weekly through the season as disease can set in at all stages of growth. On the leaves and leaf sheaths look for small circular lesions, dark brown to purple in colour. Older lesions are more oval with a light brown to grey center surrounded by a reddish brown margin
- Check glumes and panicle raches for dark brown to black oval spots or discoloration on the surface
- Brown spot lesions can be mistaken forblast lesions. Lesions caused by brown spot are oval while blast lesions are diamond or spindle shape
- As soon as symptoms appear start control measures. Fungicides can also be applied as a preventative measure before the disease is seen

- Rogue infected plants from the nursery to avoid disease spread and burn to destroy
- Rogue plants with brown spot symptoms at low disease incidence in the field after transplanting

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Apply Mancozeb (e.g. Agrithane 80WP, Benco 80WP, Damazeb 80WP, Dizcozeb 80WP etc) at a rate of 75g/15L. Multi-site broad spectrum contact fungicide. FRAC group: M3 . General Restrictions: WHO Class U (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use). When symptoms persist or there are signs of spreading apply 3 times in a season at 7-14 day intervals. REI-24hrs; PHI-14 days.
- Apply Fosetyl-Al (e.g. Folpan) at 35-40g/15L. Systemic fungicide, FRAC group: 33. General Restrictions: WHO Class U ( Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use). When symptoms persist or there are signs of disease spreading Apply 3 times in a season at 7-10 day intervals. REI-24hrs; PHI-14 days.
- Apply Carbendazim (e.g. Carbendazim 50WP, Goldazim 500SC) at a rate of 25ml/15L. Broad spectrum systemic fungicide, FRAC group: B1. General Restrictions: WHO Class U ( Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use). When symptoms persist and there are signs of disease spreading Apply 2 times at 14 day intervals. REI-24hrs; PHI-14 days.
- Seed treatment: Folpet (Folpan 50 WP) at 3-4g/kg of seed. FRAC code: M4 . General Restrictions: WHO Class U ( Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use)

Images.Caption: Oval spots with brown/light brown grey centres (Donald Groth, Louisiana State University AgCenter, Bugwood.org )
Brown lesions on raches (Chin Khoon Min)
Milled rice grains showing symptoms of infection (Donald Groth, Louisiana State University AgCenter, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Andrews Y. Akrofi, Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana, P.O. Box 8, Akim Tafo, Ghana

Sections.Value:
- Remove forest trees (alternative hosts) at least 4 years before planting cocoa in the same soil
- It is important to remove as many roots as possible from the soil as they can harbour the disease.
- Establish good ground cover on cleared land to speed up the decay of infected root parts
- Ensure that soil and root fragments from affected areas are not transported to uninfected farms

- Look out for the hard brittle encrustation of soil around the root and trunk from the base to 1m up from the ground
- Soil encrustation at base of diseased plant incorporates brown mycelium of the fungus which may be seen under a hand lens
- Look out also for foliar symptoms of yellowing of leaves followed by drying up of leaves, defoliation and dieback. Infected trees with highly decayed root systems lose support and may be blown over in strong winds. Disease is often discontinuous in distribution on farms
- Routine inspection and early detection aids in green control
- Remove and burn infected trees and contact trees and their roots as soon as the disease is detected
- There are currently no recommended chemical controls for this disease in Ghana

Images.Caption: Cocoa stem showing brown encrustation on trunk (A. Y. Akrofi, Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana)

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), S. Akrofi (CSIR-PGRRI) & P. Beseh (PPRSD, MOFA)

Sections.Value:
- Select land that will not be flooded throughout the year for cassava production and avoid water logged soils
- Avoid using planting materials from farms with reported cases of root rot diseases
- Select healthy growing plants for the production of planting materials (avoid plants that have wilted leaves)
- Destroy plant debris (e.g. rotten roots, stems or roots carrying fruitng bodies) soon after harvest by burning or deep burying
- Avoid delaying the harvesting of early maturing varieties
- Avoid continous cropping on the same piece of land. In root rot zones, practise crop rotaions of at least 3 seasons with maize, millet or sorghum
- Clean farm tools (cutlasses, hoes and ploughs) after work on farms with history of rots with a 10% soultion of household bleach
- Avoid planting cassava as first crop after clearing woodlands or forests to avoid attacks by root rot causing fungi

- Monitor fields regularly for appearance of yellow mushrooms growing from the soil or white fruiting bodies at the base of cassava stems - these are the organisms which cause the rot.
- Also look for wilting of leaves, defoliation, stem dieback and death of infected plants
- In root rot endemic areas, monitor farms for single or few wilted plants growing among healthy plants
- Storage roots of affected plants are swollen with internal soft brown rot
- Uproot any affected plants when seen and examine the roots to establish the cause of the wilt
- Carry out control measures at the first signs of the disease

- Carefully remove fruiting bodies of the rot causing fungus, and destroy them by burning immediately they are seen
- Rogue isolated plants with wilt symptoms and destroy them by burning if they carry rotten roots
- There are currently no recommended chemical fungicides for treatment of this disease

Images.Caption: Cassava roots with rotten internal tissue (E. Moses, CSIR-Crops Research Institute, Kumasi Ghana)
Rot caused by Polyporus sulphureus producing yellow muchrooms (E. Moses, CSIR-Crops Research Institute, Kumasi Ghana)
Dislodged infected stem with white fruiting bodies (E. Moses, CSIR-Crops Research Institute, Kumasi Ghana)

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), S. Akrofi (CSIR-PGRRI) and P. Beseh (PPRSD, MOFA)

Sections.Value:
- Use certified seed and pre-treasted (where available) for sowing
- Solarize the soil of nursery beds before planting using clear plastic to sterilise. If the problem persists consider changing nursery sites
- Clean or disinfect tools (tillers, cutlasses and hoes) using 10% bleach solution or fire to heat
- Sow seeds thinly to ensure good aeration. Plant in raised beds to maintain good drainage and avoid over watering
- Water in the morning so the seedlings can dry during the day
- Avoid excessive fertilization at nursery to reduce damping off
- If pre-treated seed is unavailable use fungicidal seed treatments before sowing (see yellow direct control)

- Monitor nursery daily for symptoms such as wilting, collapse and death of seedlings
- Look for seedlings with dark shrivelled stems around the base and brown rotten roots
- Take action as soon as the first symptoms are seen
- Remove infected plants as soon as symptoms appear and destroy away from nursery

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Drench nursery bed with Captan (Merpan 50WP) at 8-10g/L of water immediately as symptoms are observed. Broad spectrum fungicide. FRAC code: M4. . General Restrictions: WHO Class U (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use) Apply twice at 7-14 days intervals. Shorten intervals during frequent rains. Observe REI of 4 days. Very toxic to aquatic organisms
- Seed treatment: Mancozeb 800g/kg (i.e. Agrithane 80 WP; Benco 80 WP; Dithane M45 WP; Dizcozeb 80 WP) at 3-4g/kg of seed before sowing. FRAC code: M3. General Restrictions: WHO Class U (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use). Mix seeds with fungicide powder. Wear a protective equipment so not to come into contact or breath the powder in. Very toxic to aquatic organisms
- Seed treatment: Folpet 500g/l (Folpan 50 WP) at 3-4g/kg of seed. FRAC code: M4 . General Restrictions: WHO Class U (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use). Mix seeds with fungicide powder. Wear a protective equipment so not to come into contact or breath the powder in.

Images.Caption: Colapsed seedlings suffering from damping off (CABI)
Seeding with discoloured and rooting stem (Gerald Holmes, California Polytechnic State University at San Luis Obispo, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), S. Akrofi (CSIR-PGRRI) & P. Beseh (PPRSD, MOFA)

Sections.Value:
- Plant resistant varieties (e.g. CRI-Azivivi and CRI-Genkaa) if available
- Collect old plant debris from the field immediately after harvest and burn or bury to reduce inoculum levels for the next season crop
- Plant early when disease pressure is low
- Remove volunteer infected groundnut plants
- Crop rotation with any other crop for at least 2 years to reduce inoculum levels of early and late leaf spot pathogens
- Intercrop with millet, maize, cotton, sorghum and soy bean to reduce spread of spores
- Regularly weed the fields to reduce humidity within groundnut crops, thus preventing infection

- Early and late leaf spot are caused by different fungi and can be difficult to tell apart and a single plant can have both diseases at the same time
- Inspect field at least once a week looking for symptoms:
- Early leaf spot: light brown spots with a yellow margin and rough silvery, hair-like spores can be seen on the upper surface of infected leaf
- Late leaf spot: look for dark brown/black circular spots (darker than early leaf spot). Spores are formed on the lower side of the leaves. The spores are arranged in circular rings and have a rough appearance
- Lesions may develop on stem petioles and pegs. In severe infections, the leaves or pods may fall off
- Apply direct control as soon as leaf spots are seen. Usually start 30-40 days after sowing.
- Remove infected plants when disease incidence is low, then bury or burn to reduce the spread or reinfection of healthy plants

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Apply Carbendazim (e.g. Carbendazim 50WP, Goldazim 500SC) at 1.5-2.0ml/L of water 30 days after sowing if signs of leaf spot outbreak persist. Broad spectrum systemic fungicide. FRAC group:1. General Restrictions: WHO Class U (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use). Maximum of 2 applications at 14 day intervals. REI-24 hrs. PHI-14 days. Do not use the same chemical group continuously on the same farm. Very toxic to aquatic organisms - do not apply near waterways
- Apply Mancozeb (e.g. Agrithane 80WP, Benco 80WP, Damazeb 80WP, Dizcozeb 80WP etc.) at a rate of 5g/L of water 30 days after sowing if signs of leaf spot outbreak persist. Multi-site broad spectrum contact fungicide. FRAC group: M3. General Restrictions: WHO Class U (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use). Apply 3 times at 10-14 day intervals based on field situation. REI-24hrs; PHI-14 days. Very toxic to aquatic organisms - do not apply near waterways

Images.Caption: Early leaf spot showing much lighter spots than late leaf spot (Jill M. Lenn/ICRISAT)
Late leaf spot showing dark nearly black leaf spots on the underside of the leaves (Jill M. Lenn/ICRISAT)

Values.Value: Early and late leaf spot disease

Factsheets.Title: Early and late leaf spot of groundnut

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), S. Akrofi (CSIR-PGRRI) & P. Beseh (PPRSD, MOFA)

Sections.Value:
- Extract seeds from healthy fruits - Certified seeds for these crops are generally unavailable in Ghana
- Plant local varieties (e.g. 'Mesiwa for chilli') are tolerant to wilt in high relative humidity areas
- Avoid planting on land with history of wilt disease
- Rotate nursery site each season and maintain good drainage
- Destroy plant debris immediately after harvest by burning
- Solarise soil using plastic sheets 6-8 weeks before planting
- Practise long crop rotation - 6 years with non-solanaceous plants (e.g. cereals and grains- maize, millet) after every 3 seasons
- Reduce injury to crop roots as wounds are entry points of wilt pathogen
- Disinfect farm tools with 10% bleach solution after working in infected soils
- There is an interaction between nematodes (especially root knot nematodes) and Fusarium wilt so avoid planting in sites where nematode damage has occurred

- Monitor field weekly for symptoms of wilt soon after transplanting. Look for yellowing and wilting of leaves and stems, often only affecting one side of the plant
- Look for wilted leaves which dry up and turn brown
- Uproot and cut the stem lengthwise, internal dark-brown to dark-red discolouration can been seen when the fungus is present
- There may also be damage to the root system
- Take action as soon as the first symptoms are seen

- Rogue out and destroy plants that show early symptoms of the disease and destroy by burning
- Prevention is main method of controlling this disease (see prevention column)
- There are no chemicals effective or economic for small scale farmers for the the management of fusarium wilt

Images.Caption: Wilted chilli plant caused by Fusarium wilt (A.A. Seif & B. Nyambo, icipe)
Tomato wilting with browning of the stem (Dr G M McPherson, Stockbridge Technology Centre)
Internal disease symptoms in a tomato stam (left) compared with healthy stem (right) (Clemson University - USDA Cooperative Extension Slide Series, Bugwood.org)

Factsheets.Title: Fusarium wilt of tomato, eggplant, chilli & pepper
ScientificNames: Fusarium oxysporum (Tomato: f.sp. lycopersici; Eggplant: f.sp. melongenae; Chili & Pepper: f.sp. capsici)

Authors.Surname: Andrews Y. Akrofi, Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana, P.O. Box 8, Akim Tafo, Ghana

Sections.Value:
- This disease is caused by an organism which enters wounds on cocoa pods. On its own it causes little economic damage but to reduce losses:
- Avoid wounding of cherelles (young pods) and pods during farm operations such as weeding and harvesting
- The disease is worse in the wet season so ensure correct spacing is used (3m x 3m) and prune cocoa in March/April, clear weeds 3-4 times a year
- Avoid transporting infected pods to uninfected areas
- Use improved planting materials from COCOBOD Seed Production Division
- Ensure proper nutrition of cacao trees through fertilization (Conact COCOBOD for list of approved fertlizers)

- Monitor field all year round, but the disease is more prevalent during the rainy season between July and November
- The disease only affects the pods and symptoms can look similar to those caused by Phytophthora (black pod)
- Look out for pods with a thick mass of fungal growth on the surface that is white at first but becomes pinkish-brown
- The texture of the growth feels rough giving it its mealy appearance
- Apply green direct controls as soon as diseased pods are seen.
- If the disease is severe, copper fungicides can be applied (see yellow direct control column)

- Avoid wounding of pods and cherelles when pruning and harvesting to reduce infection
- When the fungal growth is white, spores can be transferred from pod to pod by wind and insects so remove or harvest infected pods as soon as they are seen to reduce spread of the disease
- Bury or burn infected pods or pod husks

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- This disease is generally of no economic importance and no chemical control measures are currently advised

Images.Caption: Cocoa pod showing dense white to pinkish/brown spore mass (A. Y. Akrofi, Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana)

Factsheets.Title: Mealy pod of cocoa (Trachysphaera pod rot)

Authors.Surname: Andrews Y. Akrofi, Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana, P.O. Box 8, Akim Tafo, Ghana

Sections.Value:
- Plant at or thin out cocoa trees to the recommended spacing of 3m x 3m. High humidity favours the disease, using correct spacing can reduce this
- Shade reduction reduces the chance of the disease - ensure the correct level of shade is used on the farm (5-8 trees/ac) and prune cocoa in March/April, clear weeds 3-4 times a year
- Avoid planting susceptible shade trees (rubber, citrus, mango, Gliricidia) which act as a host to the disease
- Ensure proper nutrition of cocoa trees through fertilization - see COCOBOD list for recommended fertilisers and rates of application
- Use improved hybrid planting materials from COCOBOD Seed Production Division

- If untreated this disease can kill cocoa trees but the disease is difficult to detect in the early stages
- Look out for dieback (sudden death) of infected branches and twigs, the leaves on these branches will turn brown and die. The dead leaves remain to the trees for several weeks before falling
- The fungus grows on the bark and can take several forms: pink/salmon encrusted growth coating the branch, white fungal growth which looks like a cobweb, orange fruiting bodies or cream coloured pustules
- Other symptoms can include lengthwise cracks in the bark, brown dried flowers and mummified pods
- Take action when the first symptoms are seen in the field

- Prune out the infected branches at least 30cm below any sign of the disease
- If the fungus has infected several branches, consider coppicing and allow re-growth from the stump
- Do not leave the pruned branches with pink disease on the farm, otherwise spores will continue to develop and infect the remaining trees, bury or burn to destroy
- Remove alternative host shade trees (rubber, citrus, mango, Gliricidia)

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Apply any copper-based fungicide approved by COCOBOD - the mixture can be sprayed or applied as a paste (if multiple branches on the same tree are infected)
- Copper hydroxide (Kocide 2000 DF, Funguran-OH, Champion, Kentan). Apply at 100g/15 L of water. A protectant with multisite action, FRAC Group M1. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately harzardous). REI-24 hrs. Spray affected branches every 3-4 weeks
- Copper oxide (Copper Nordox Super 75). Apply at 75 g/15 L of water. A protectant with multisite action, FRAC Group M1. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately harzardous). REI-24 hrs. Spray affected branches every 3-4 weeks

Images.Caption: Infected cocoa branch showing typical pink encrusted fungal growth on the surface (A. Y. Akrofi, Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana)
Infected cocoa branch showing orange pustules (A. Y. Akrofi, Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana)

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), S. Akrofi (CSIR-PGRRI) & P. Beseh (PPRSD, MOFA)

Sections.Value:
- Use certified, disease free seeds for planting
- Remove plant debris from the soil or plough into the soil after harvest to hasten decomposition
- Control weeds, volunteer crops and wild lettuce crops
- Avoid using the same location for the nursery year after year
- Avoid high density seedings on nursery beds
- Select healthy plants from nursery for transplanting, remove any seedlings showing symptoms
- Avoid overhead irrigation. Irrigatin in the morning to minimize periods of leaf wetness
- Mulch with straw or other available materials after transplanting to reduce rain splash
- Avoid working in fields when plants are wet
- Rotate with non-host crops for 3 years such as maize, millet, sorghum cowpea and cassava

- Monitor fields weekly after transplanting
- Symptoms start mostly on the lower leaves. Look for small irregular yellow spots which turn brown and dry. The centre of the spots may split and fall out. Old lesions turn necrotic and sunken. The lower leaves progressively die and drop off.
- The leaf spots contain brown/black dots which are fungal reproductive structures (pycnidia)
- In severe cases symptoms occur on stems and petioles of the plant as well
- Apply direct control immediately when first spots are observed, or apply a protectant fungicide

- Rogue out infected plants immediately when they are observed at very low disease density and destroy by burying
- Disinfect farm implements/tools with fire or household bleach (1 part bleach to 1 part water) to avoid spreading the disease

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Apply Mancozeb (e.g Agrithane 80WP, Benco 80WP, Damazeb 80WP Dizcozeb 80WP) at a rate of 75g/15L of water. Multi-site broad spectrum fungicide, FRAC group M3. General Restrictions: WHO Class U - Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use. Apply 3 times at 7-10 day intervals. REI-24hrs; PHI-14 days. Very toxic to aquatic organisms - do not apply near waterways
- Apply Fosetyl-Al (e.g Chemoliete) at a rate of 75g/15L of water. Systemic fungicide, FRAC group: 33. General Restrictions: WHO Class U - Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use. Apply 3 times at 7-10 day intervals. REI-24hrs; PHI-14 days. Harmful to aquatic organisms
- Apply Folpet (e.g. Folpan and shavit F) at 45-60g/15L of water. multi-site contact activity. FRAC group: M4. General Restrictions: WHO Class U - Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use). Apply at on set of disease up to 3 times at 7-10 day intervals. REI-24hrs; PHI-14 days.
- Apply Top Cop (Sulphur 50% +Copper 8%) at the rate of 150-300mls/15L. FRAC group: M2. General Restrictions: WHO Class III - Slightly Harzadous. Apply every 10-14 days. Observe REI of 24hrs and PHI of 7days

Images.Caption: Leaf spot with small dark pycnidia (reproductive structures) froming inside the spots (Bruce Watt, University of Maine, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Andrews Y. Akrofi, Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana, P.O. Box 8, Akim Tafo, Ghana

Sections.Value:
- This disease is common in areas with high rainfall and where farm management is poor
- Ensure the following are carried out to improve management practices on the farm:
- To increase air circulation, reduce shade levels - the correct number of shade trees to use on the farm is 5-8 trees/acre
- Prune cocoa in March/April and clear weeds 3-4 times a year. Also remove chupons, mistletoes and epiphytes to improve air circulation and reduce humidity
- Improve drainage and drain away stagnant water
- Plant or thin out to recommended spacing of 3 x 3m for hybrid cacao from COCOBOD
- Use improved planting materials from COCOBOD Seed Production Division
- Farm implements/tools used for pruning should be sterilized using fire or household bleach (1 in 5 solution) after pruning each branch

- Monitor cocoa fields throughout the year. Look for white or black strands of the fungus which grow along the branches and on the underside of green leaves
- Look out for sudden death of a branch with dead brown leaves hanging down but still attached by either the white or black mycelial strands (threads) of the fungi
- The leaves remain attached to the branch when dead and this creates a humid environment in which the fungus can thrive
- Take action when these symptoms are seen and continue to remove thread blight infected materials at regular intervals such as when pruning and weeding

- Prune out the infected leaves and branches at least 30 cm below any sign of the thread.
- Pruning should be done as soon as symptoms are observed
- Do not leave the pruned branches with threads on the farm, otherwise spores will continue to develop and infect the remaining trees
- Burn infected leaves and branches on the farm
- Thread blight is difficult and uneconomical in many cases to manage with fungicides

Images.Caption: Strands of white thread fungus on cocoa branch (A. Y. Akrofi, Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana)
Strands of black thread fungus growing on a branch (A. Y. Akrofi, Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana)
Dead leaves held in position by the thread fungus (A. Y. Akrofi, Cocoa Research Institute of Ghana)

Factsheets.Title: Thread blight of cocoa (white and black)

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), S. Akrofi (CSIR-PGRRI) & P. Beseh (PPRSD, MOFA)

Sections.Value:
- Use healthy disease-free seedlings in establishment of new plantations
- Prune trees regularly after harvest by removing dead twigs and branches to allows good light penetration and air circulation
- Ensure proper spacing depending on the type of cultivar to ensure adequate aeration
- Collect and burn plant debris, including old twigs, rotten fruits and infected nuts regularly to reduce sources of inoculum
- Weed fields and surroundings because as pathogen has a wide host range
- Spray trees after pruning to control cashew mosquitoes and other sucking insects to reduce or prevent transmission through mechanical injuries (see yellow control column)

- Additional relevant crops: mango, citrus, eggplant, tomato, cassava, chilli, pepper and yam
- Monitor main stalk and branches for reddish brown coloured sunken oval shaped lesions
- Check immature fruits for black lesions
- Monitor field regularly for irregular growth and crinkling of flower buds and young flowers
- Apply direct control as soon as symptoms are observed. Carry out preventative spraying at the seedling, budding and early flowering stages
- Note: Helopeltis is an important insect pest of cashew and can cause symptoms very similar to anthracnose (see PMDG on Cashew Mosquitoes)

- Prune diseased and dead twigs and branches to reduce the disease inoculum
- Remove rotten fruits and infected nuts from the ochard and burn to reduce the source of inoculum

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Apply mancozeb (800g/kg) (e.g Agrithane 80WP, Benco 80WP, Damazeb 80WP Dizcozeb 80WP) at 5g/L of water. Multi-site broad spectrum fungicide. FRAC group: M3. General Restrictions: WHO Class U (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use). Apply at 7-10 days interval and stop when small fruits are well developed. REI-24hrs; PHI-14 days.
- Apply folpet (Folpan 50WP) at a rate of 3g/L of water. Broad spectrum contact fungicide, FRAC group: M4. General Restrictions: WHO Class U (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use). Spray at 7-10 days intervals until young fruits form. REI-24 hrs. PHI-14.
- The following insecticides can be used to control sucking insects at the flowering and early fruiting stages
- Apply alpha cypermethrin (100g/l) (Alphacep 10 SC, Siricon10EC) at a rate of 4ml/10L. Contact pyrethroid, IRAC group: 3A. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). Apply at 7-10 days intervals, PHI-14 days.
- Apply Acetamiprid (400g/l) (Buffalo Supa 40EW) at 4-5g/10L. Systemic neonicotinoid, IRAC group: 4A. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). Apply at 7-10 days intervals. PHI-14 days.

Images.Caption: Cashew fruits showing symptoms of anthracnose (J.M. Waller/CABI BioScience)

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), S. Akrofi (CSIR-PGRRI) & P. Beseh (PPRSD, MOFA)

Sections.Value:
- Collect debris and burn or remove from field - do not plough back into the soil
- Solarise soil with plastic sheets for 4-6 weeks before planting
- Plant lettuce on raised beds with wider spacing (15cm x15cm) to give good aeration
- Ensure good drainage and avoid using spinkler irrigation and water each plant individually to avoid disease spread
- Ensure good farm sanitation. Keep fields free of weeds
- Practice long crop rotations (5 years+) with sweet potato and maize between each planting of lettuce
- Treat seeds with a fungicide before sowing to prevent early infections (see yellow control for details)

- Monitor young transplants as they grow, particularly at the collar region for signs of rot
- Check for brown lesions followed by cottony growth with hard black irregularly shaped structures (sclerotia) on the collar region close to the soil
- Look for wilting or death of foliage beyond the lesion
- Carry out direct control methods as soon as symptoms are seen
- At early stage, rogue out infected plants before sclerotia are formed to prevent further soil contamination

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- No fungicide has given reliable economic control during disease outbreaks but seeds can be treated before sowing
- Treat seeds with Mancozeb at 3-4g/kg of seed before sowing. FRAC code: M3. General Restrictions: WHO Class U (Unlikely to present any hazard under normal use)
- Treat seeds with Folpet (Folpan 50 WP) at 3-4g/kg of seed before sowing. FRAC code: M4. General Restrictions: WHO Class U (Unlikely to present any hazard under normal use)

Images.Caption: Damaged to lower leaves and stem (Nicole Sanchez, Oregon State University, Bugwood.org)
Visible black sclerotia and cottony white fungal growth (Nicole Sanchez, Oregon State University, Bugwood.org)
Severe symptoms of collar rot in the field (Gerald Holmes, California Polytechnic State University at San Luis Obispo, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: E. Moses (Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.), S. Akrofi (CSIR-PGRRI) & P. Beseh (PPRSD, MOFA)

Sections.Value:
- Collect old plant debris including rotten yam tubers immediately after harvest and destroy by burning to reduce inoculum levels
- Avoid continuous yam planting on the same piece of land for more than 3 seasons (rotate yam with maize, sorghum, millet or cowpea in 3 year rotations)
- Sterilise farm equipment/tools with 10% household bleach
- Minimize physical damage to developing tubers during weeding or remounding.
- At harvest select wound-free tubers for storage in barns (wounded tubers should be sold or eaten but not stored among healthy tubers)
- Do not pack tubers closely together in barns to ensure good aeration
- Construct barns to avoid entry of rain water or soil particles through splash
- Cover stands of barn with metal shields from the ground to about 2m in height to avoid entry by rodents which may introduce pathogens
- Treat barn with fungicide before storage (see yellow control)

- Monitor barns regularly (at 3 day intervals) looking at the surface of stored tubers or seed yams for signs of discolouration, the tissue becomes dry and brittle and growth of fungal spores may occur on the surface
- Also examine stored tubers or seeds for insect or rodent damage as disease can be spread to damaged tubers
- Take action when first signs are noticed

- Remove rotten and damaged tubers when seen from barns and destroy by burning
- Remove soil from surfaces of yam tubers after harvest and store in the disinfected barn
- Do not delay storage of tubers after harvest and minimze injuries to tubers during handling

- When using a pesticide or botanical, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label
- Do not use chemicals with the same mode of action year after year as this can lead to resistance
- Always consult the most recent list of registered pesticides of MOFA, Ghana

- Spray storage barns for seed yam with Mancozeb (e.g. Agrithane 80WP,Benco 80WP, Damazeb 80WP, Dizcozeb 80WP etc) at a rate of 75g/15L of water 4-5 days before storage. Multi-site fungicide. FRAC code: M3. . General Restrictions: WHO ClassU (Unlikely to present any hazard under normal use). Apply once before storage. Other dithocarbamates can be used in place of Mancozeb
- Spray barn after cleaning with Lambda-cyhalothrin (e.g. Contihalothrin, Conquer Super, Impact 25EC, kamotrine etc). Apply at 50ml/15L of water 4-5 days before storage to prevent insects and rodents which may introduce pathogens. A pyrethroid. IRAC code: 3A. . General Restrictions: WHO Class II (moderately hazardous). Apply once before storage. Other pyrethroids could be used for the same purpose.
- Dip seed yam into a mixture of Mancozeb and Lambda cyhalothrin prepared at rates above but mixed in equal volumes. General Restrictions: Dry seed yam in shade after treatment before storage.

Images.Caption: Yam tubers with necrotic rot tissues (E. Moses, Scientific and Agricultural Consultants, Impact Plus Co. Ltd.)

Factsheets.Title: Tuber and seed rot of yam

Sections.Value:
- Maintaining balanced fertilization helps to minimize the impact of the pest
- Prune trees to avoid contact between trees and between branches and the ground, and to maintain good air circulation around the trees
- Avoid the presence of suckers or sprouts with excess vigour
- Mealybugs are often effectively controlled by a wide range of natural enemies (parasitoids, lacewings, ladybirds, hoverflies, etc.) and do not cause economic damage: avoid disturbing the natural balance by applying pesticides and control ants that protect the mealybugs against natural enemies
- Disinfect equipment and tools to prevent the propagation of mealybugs

- Once a week, monitor 1% of the orchard
- Check the protected areas of the trees where the mealybugs are grouped; fruits, cracks, shoots, under the sepals and at the base of the pedicel of the fruits, inside the dry rolled leaves and at the base of the trunks
Cochinilla: The female has an oval body (3 mm long) covered with fine particles of white wax
Leaves: the production of fumagina caused by the honeydew results in decreased rates of photosynthesis which can weaken young trees and cause defoliation
Twigs: reduced tree vigor caused by mealybugs feeding on the sap
Fruits: decrease in quality caused by spots and development of fumagina; discoloration caused by insects feeding; fruits dropping
- To monitor the presence and activity of the natural enemies, tie around the trunk an aggregation trap made of corrugated cardboard (10/2-4 ha orchard). In this artificial refuge, female mealybugs, parasitized mealybugs, parasitoids and predators are protected.
- Use pheromone traps for monitoring
- Monitor the presence and abundance of ants in the trees that protect the mealybugs

- Apply organic mineral oil or frequent washes with soaps at high pressure. This removes the honey and wax that prevents control by natural enemies
- Release parasitoids and predators that are commercially available in your country (e.g. Anagyrus pseudococci, Pauridia peregrina, Leptomastix dactylopii, and the predator Cryptolaemus montrouzieri)
- After harvesting, remove branches where a high number of ants are protecting the mealybugs. Otherwise these could serve as an inoculum for the next season

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Mealybugs P. citri (United States National Collection of Scale Insects Photographs Archive, USDA Agricultural Research Service, Bugwood.org)
Predator, C. montrouzieri(Sonya Broughton, Department of Agriculture & Food Western Australia, Bugwood.org)

Sections.Value:
- Before building the stores, plan to build them well isolated, ventilated and with the least possible windows and cracks
- Early harvesting reduces the attack in the field
- Good store hygiene is essential for controlling this pest :
- Before storing new grain, remove infested residues from the previous harvest. Clean the store, bags and containers
- Dry grains until they are very dry (7-10%). Dry 2 times/week for 3 hours for at least 1-2 weeks
- Store grains in sealed plastic bags or metallic silos
- Make sure that the bags are stored on pallets at a sufficient distance from the ground, away from the walls and avoid touching the roof
- Separate new grains from the old grain store
- Maintain the store at a temperature below 10C by ventilating and cooling
- Apply a thin layer of ash to cover the grain in store

- Every two weeks, inspect the store and sample 100 grains in bags to look for symptoms or insects
Normally, no eggs, larvae or pupae developing inside the intact grains are observed
Adults are dark brown in colour and 3-3.5 mm in length, with a head prolonged into a rostrum
- The females lay eggs on the stored grain and the larvae develop within these
- Grain infestation can start in the field: monitor random cobs in the field (look for adults and irregular perforations made when they feed or lay eggs)
- In the stores, use interception, pheromone, adhesive or light traps or bags with baits to monitor adults
- Take action when damage or insects are observed
- Sieve infested grains and dry again in the sun to kill the remaining eggs and adults

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Adult S. zeamais (USDA-ARS)
Damage to cobs (Frank Peairs, Colorado State University, Bugwood.org)

Sections.Value:
- Use resistant or tolerant varieties if available
- Apply nitrogen, either as a mineral fertilizer, or as manure or compost, to enhance the crop's ability to sustain an attack
- A push-pull system can be implemented in which Desmodium, a repellent plant, and Napier grass, a trap crop, are intercropped with maize to push and pull the insect away from the maize (see Plantwise Factsheet for Farmers):
An additional benefit of this system is that Desmodium is a legume that fixes nitrogen into the soil; it also acts as a ground cover that supresses Striga, a parasitic weed
Disadvantages of this system include the space taken up by the Napier grass; the cost and lack of availability of Desmodium seed; and the difficulty in establishing the Desmodium crop
- Intercrop with non-host plants, such as cowpeas or cassava. Adult moths will lay eggs on the non-host plants, but the larvae are unable to feed on them and will die
- Rotate maize with a non-host plant, such as a legume (e.g. groundnut), to increase the nitrogen in the soil. This will make the next maize crop hardier and less susceptible to an attack and break the cycle of the stalk borer

- Additional relevant crops: sorghum, bulrush millet, sugarcane and rice
- Immediately after emergence, start monitoring and continue at weekly intervals until maize reaches physiological maturity
- Consider control if you see one or two infested plants
Stems: Feeding damage resulting in reduction of grain production. Stems are weakened and break
Leaves: An early sign is small holes in straight lines or small dark larvae in the leaf funnel of young leaves
Central leaves become dry and withered when larvae attacks growing points, forming 'dead heart' (drying of the central shoot). The top of the plant wilts, turns yellow, and eventually dries out and dies
Larvae droppings (frass) are often visible on the leaves and in the stems
Eggs: Round, flat on top, creamy-yellow in colour. May get darker as they develop. About 1 mm in diameter
Larvae: Creamy-white. Might have a grey or sometimes pink colour and the head may be dark brown. Might have dark conspicuous spots and four purple stripes lengthwise across the back. Grow up to 40 mm long
Pupae: up to 25 mm long and shiny yellow-brown to dark brown/red-brown in colour
Adults/moths: Wing-span is about 20-33 mm. The forewings are light to dark brown or yellow-brown, possibly with dark patterns, and the hindwings are white to greyish-brown
- If plants show symptoms, cut open the stem and look for larvae, pupae and frass

- Dispose of crop residues after harvest to reduce stalk borer populations and limit the pest the following season:
The crop residues can be burned, used as feed for livestock, or left on the ground exposed to the suns heat for one month to kill the larvae and pupae
- Apply ash or dry soil, by putting one teaspoon of ash or soil into the leaf funnel of young plants. Too much soil or ash can damage the leaf. Ash or soil should be used before the appearance of any symptoms. This means when stalk borers are known from the area or the last cropping season
- Apply 25-50 g of neem cake powder diluted per litre water every 10 days until maize flowers. The spray should be applied into the leaf funnel every 10-14 days until flowering
- Spray with neem seed liquid (2 handfulls of neem powder put in 10 litres of water left overnight and sieved before spraying)

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Maize stalk borer larvae and frass inside a young maize tassel (Photo: CIMMYT, Flickr)
Larva feeding on maize stem (Photo: International Institute of Tropical Agriculture, Flickr)
Busseola fusca (Francis Nduati, Kenya)

Sections.Value:
- Avoid the use of infested plant materials. Before planting, cuttings can be treated using a warm water treatment. See the 'Warm water treatment of cassava mealybug' factsheet.
- If available, plant varieties that are less susceptible to the pest
- Plant healthy cuttings
- Plant early in the rainy season to allow the cassava plant to grow well, before the dry season, as strong plants are more likely to withstand pest attack
- Use soil amendments and mulch to avoid moisture stress in sandy or poor soils. Mealybug numbers are higher on cassava grown on poor soil, and may cause damage in spite of the presence of natural enemies
- Restrict movement of infested planting materials across borders or mealybug-free areas
- Avoid planting cassava for more than 3 years on the same piece of land. Rotate with maize and legumes

- Check crop weekly for mealybugs on shoots, stems and leaves
- The adult females and larvae will be visible on the stem and leaves. They are oval in shape, pinkish in colour and covered in a white, powdery wax
- Symptoms on the plant include stunting, wilting, leaf distortion, leaf fall, rosetting of the stem, bunchy top and dieback
- Ants may also be present as they protect the mealybugs and feed on the honeydew they produce
- Black sooty mould may grow on the leaves and stem in the presence of honeydew
- Take action when you notice white waxy material on shoot tips, leaves and stems or any signs of mealybugs

- Remove and destroy infested plants or plant parts at early stages of infestation. Burn cuttings if this practice allowed in your area.
- Prune stems or leaves with high infestation and burn or bury more than 50 cm deep
- Mix 5 g of soap (alata samina) + 5 g of powdered pepper in 1 litre of water and leave it for about 30 minutes. Pour the mixture into knapsack and apply in 15 litres of water
- Apply neem oil e.g. Grow-safe. Add 10 ml soap to 1 litre of water and stir to mix. Add 50 ml neem oil to the 1 litre water-soap solution and mix thouroughly. Add the oil-water-soap solution to 14 litres water in the knapsack and apply within 8 hrs. Ensure thorough coverage
- If possible, use natural enemies such as the parasitic wasp Apoanagyrus lopezi and ladybirds
- Control ants as these will reduce the amount of natural predators

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Cassava mealybugs (Georg Goergen/International Institute of Tropical Agriculture (IITA)/ Insect Museum, Cotonou, Benin)
Mealybug damage to leaves and stem (R Reeder, CABI)
Mealybug infestation on a cassava stem (R Reeder, CABI)

Sections.Value:
- Rotate cabbage, rape, broccoli or cauliflower with any of the following crops: tomato, onion, maize, or sweet potato
- Plant early in the season to avoid the period of diamond back moth build-up
- Remove and bury/burn crop debris including weeds at least 4 weeks prior to sowing to reduce DBM population
- Plant seedling beds away from production fields
- Transplant only healthy seedlings free of eggs, caterpillars and pupae of the DBM and other pests
- Intercrop with tomato, chilies, marigolds or mustard. Mustard acts as a trap crop for adult moths. Plant two rows of mustard for every 25 of cabbage
- Slash left-over cabbage stems after harvest to avoid regrowth which can act as a diamond back moth breeding area
- After harvest, plough the field to expose any pests harbouring in the soil

- Additional relevant crops: Crucifer family (rape, broccoli, cauliflower, chinese cabbage)
- Inspect crop weekly, especially the underside of leaves
- Look for small, grey moths, which have a diamond pattern on their wings when at rest
- Look for caterpillars which are yellowish green to green and around 1 cm long when fully grown. They hang from a web when disturbed and tend to appear at the four leaf stage of cabbage growth
- Look for damage on leaves: irregular holes, windowing and skeletonised underside
- Detect DBM adults using pheromone traps, placing 2-4 traps/Ha. Check traps twice a week early in the morning. Use control when 5 + adult moths are caught in a trap
- Alternatively, you may consider direct control when you notice 2 to 3 young larvae per plant

- Uproot and bury or burn cabbage debris, if burning is permitted in your country
- Crush larvae by hand if noticed when numbers are few
- Apply aqueous solution of botanical pesticide neem or tephrosia (40g/L soak over night and seive)
- Alternatively spray chilli mixed with water and few chopped pieces of bar soap or drops of liquid soap
- Plant trap crops such as mustard and rape at the edges of the the field to reduce DBM attack
- Parasitic wasps such as Diadegma and Cotesia vestalis spp. can reduce DBM populations. See if these biological controls are available in your country
- Use overhead irrigation which dislodges the pest from the plant surface

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Newly hatched larvae (CABI)
The pupa of a diamond back moth (David Cappaert, Michigan State University, Bugwood.org)

Sections.Value:
- Use clean pasture seed to reduce the chance of contamination
- Remove all existing hedges by cutting and digging out the roots (15cm depth)
- Move livestock out of previously infested fields. Sow land with pasture and/or native vegetation. Growth of new vegetation can outcompete the weed.

- Perennial woody shrub, 2-5m high, erect or scrambling.
- Branches with small thorns
- Leaves: yellow-green to green, rough, 2-12 cm in length
- Flowers: multicolored (yellow, orange, white, pale violet, pink or red), in dense clusters ca. 4 cm across.
- Fruits: round, fleshy, 2-seeded, each 5 mm wide, green turning purple then blue-black. Arranged in dense, round clusters
- Look out for this weed on disturbed land, plantations, forest edges/gaps, gassland, water courses, lowlands and gullies

- Do not control with grazing as the weed is poisonous to livestock
- Removal of small infestations may be possible by cutting and digging out the roots (15 cm depth)
- Remove flower heads prior to seed set to prevent further spread
- Slashing and burning can stimulate regrowth of the weed. Combine with other control methods
- Control will need to be repeated, potentially over many years as the weed is difficult to get rid of

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Largeleaf lantana (Lantana camara) (Forest and Kim Starr, Starr Environmental, Bugwood.org)
Largeleaf lantana (Lantana camara) (Forest and Kim Starr, Starr Environmental, Bugwood.org)
Largeleaf lantana (Lantana camara) (Rebekah D. Wallace, University of Georgia, Bugwood.org)

Sections.Value:
- Use clean pasture seed to reduce the chance of contamination
- Avoid movement of livestock though infested areas to prevent spread of seed
- Prevent water runoff from infested land to non-infested land
- Maintain a regular weeding regime before the plants grow big in order to facilitate uprooting
- Remove Prosopis from roadsides, wastelands, field boundaries and other areas that serve as source of infestation

- Perennial, woody shrub 3-5m or tree growing up to 15 m height
- Bark: ough grey-green, becomes scaly with age
- Branches: often multi-stemmed, especially following cutbacks, with abundant large and very sharp thorns (up to 5 cm)
- Leaves: doubly-divided composed (6-8cm long), 12-25 pairs of oblong leaflets per leaf
- Flowers: fragrant golden-yellow, dense spikes about 5-10 cm long
- Fruit: cylindrical or slightly irregularly curved green pods which turns yellow upon ripening (10-20 cm long) containing 10-20 hard oval or elliptic, brown seeds
- Regularly check edges of waterbodies, grazing areas and animal gathering areas and consider direct control if present
- Check for growth of trees where there are animal dropping/dungs since seed passes through animal dungs and germinate
- Consider direct control as soon as the weed observed in the field

- Seedlings up to 20 cm in height can be hand pulled
- Cut the weed before seed production to prevent spread
- Uproot trees or cut below ground to remove crown in order to prevent coppices
- Follow up weeding consistently to achieve longer term control

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Coppicing Prosopis (Eschen/CABI)
Dense infestation of Prosopis (Eschen/CABI)

Sections.Value:
- Minimise the level of nutrients in water by limiting fertilizer use
- Use of containment fences across the waterways to prevent introduction of weeds to paddy fields
- Use water from tanks free form Salvinia

- Evergreen, mat-forming, free-floating fern, branching horizontal stems (up to 625 cm long and 1.2 cm thick), submerged feathery roots
- Leaves: Green or yellowish-green fronds, in pairs, oval (26 cm long and 1015 mm wide); almost impossible to wet due to a covering of fine egg-beater-shaped hairs (13 mm long) on upper surface; undersides covered in matted brown hairs.
- Flowers: none
- Fruits: None, reproduces from detached fragments
- Look out for weed in drainage ditches, irrigation channels, dams, ponds, swamps, wetlands, lakes and slow-moving rivers

- Manually remove weed if infestation is small
- Biological control options include the salvina weevil, Cyrtobagus salviniae. See if they are available in your country

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Salvinia molesta (kariba weed) mat (S. S. Bir)
Salvinia molesta (kariba weed) plant with roots (Colin Wilson)
Salvinia molesta (kariba weed) plant (Colin Wilson)

Sections.Value:
- Purchase certified crop seed and animal feed to reduce the chance of contamination
- As seeds can travel on animals and machinery, do not allow animals into an affected area, limit machinery use in the area and keep machinery clean to prevent spread
- Keep crop healthy to maximize competitiveness - use optimal water and fertilizer levels
- Plant competitive species such as Leucaena leucocephala, Tephrosia purpurea and Brachiaria decumbens to surpress the weed
- Plant cover crops such as Pueraria phaseoloides, Calopogonium mucunoides, Centrosema pubescens or Vigna unguiculata to prevent weed establishment and spread

- Herbaceous to woody perennial herb; forms dense bushes on the ground about 2 m high; climber; becomes woody when mature
- Leaves: Soft, green, hairy, roughly triangular; margins have 1-5 teeth when mature (younger leaves have none); numerous small dots on underside; 5-14 cm long, 2.5-8 cm broad
- Roots: Fibrous; shallow do not penetrate beyond 20-30 cm in most soils
- Flowerheads: White or pale blue-ish-lilac; appear fluffy; many
- Leaf shape, flower colour and structure are similar to that of Mikania species.
- Look along waterways and transport routes. Seeds disperse via water, wind animals and vehicles

- Use a combination of methods to control the weed. Carry these out before the weed flowers or sets seed to prevent spread.
- Hand-pull seedlings and young plants. Repeat every 2-3 months afterwards due to rapid regrowth
- Completely dig out root system by hand or by using machinery this will be easier if soil is wet. Repeat twice during the growing season.
- Cutting is only a short-term solution as weed will grow back from the roots
- Burn weeds that have been pulled up or cut (if permitted in your country). If not destroyed, they can take root and grow
- Biological controls that have shown effectiveness include, Pareuchaetes pseudoinsulata, Cecidochares connexa, Actinote thalia pyrrha, Actinote anteas, Acalitus adoratus, Calycomyza eupatorivora, Pareuchaetes insulata and Lixus aemulus. See if these are available in your country.
- It is difficult to kill this weed with chemicals because of its many tubers and roots from which it can regenerate, and its waxy leaves

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Siam weed seed heads (Colin Wilson)
Siam weed leaves (Colin Wilson)

Sections.Value:
- Keep density of crop high in order to shade out the weed (it grows poorly in low light):
Plant crop before weed germinates in late summer
- As seeds can travel on animals and machinery, do not allow animals into an affected area, limit machinery use in the area and keep machinery clean to prevent spread

- Annual or perennial creeping herb; produces seed above and below ground.
- Leaves: oval to lanceolate; short hairs when young; 3-7 cm long, 1-2.5 cm wide (length up to twice width only)
- Flowers: three lilac blue petals; 3-4 mm long - lower is smaller than other two and sometimes white
- Fruit: pear-shaped capsule; five seeds (sometimes appear sugar-coated; grey-brown)
- Stems: short hairs when young
- Distinguished from other species in its genus by: all three petals blue; leaves broadly elliptical (length up to twice width only); rough, ribbed seeds; presence of stolons; leaf sheaths with reddish-brown tipped hairs
- Keep a close eye on row cropping systems such as peanuts, soybeans and corn - these types of crops are favoured by the weed
- Prefers wet soils but can survive for long periods without moisture. Particularly likes disturbed land.
- Take action as soon as weed is seen

- Uproot by hoeing or hand-pulling. When removed, shake off soil, spread out and dry for more than a week
Cut stems can resprout. Stem fragements must dessicate to a moisture content of 50% for a period of 30 days to prevent resprouting
- Moldboard plough more than 1 inch below surface
- Use conventional tillage as supposed to strip tillage (do not use minimum tillage systems)
- Note: emphasis should be given on preventive and mechanical measures as extreme tolerance to glyphosate has been documented.

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Leaves of C. benghalensis (S.D. Sawant)
Large infestation C. benghalensis (Stanley Culpepper, University of Georgia, Bugwood.org)

Sections.Value:
- Prevention measures are particularly important as this weed is difficult to control. Tubers are the main means of spread;
Clean tools and farm machinery to prevent introduction to new fields
Do not accept potentially contaminated materials, e.g. soil on planting stock
- Plant highly competitive cover or cash crops such as jack bean, velvet bean, bush bean, soybean, cotton, chayote and cucumber.
- Narrow crop row spacing can help prevent the establishment of the weed by shading it
- Control established populations near waterways to prevent spread during flooding and storm events

- Erect, perennial sedge (30-60 cm high), with extensive underground network composed of tubers
- Tubers dark brown/black, irregular shaped, 1-2 cm long at maturity, with several buds
- Leaves linear with distinct midrib, 7 mm wide
- Flowering stems 3-sided, erect. Inflorescence with several unequal 'branches', each 2-6 cm long, emerging from the tip of the stem; each with 3-8 purplish-brown flowerheads

- Destroy tubers and rhizomes in the soil via dessication (most effective in dry soil) or exhausting food reserves
- Cultivate every 2-3 weeks until crop canopy forms: the weed is shade intolerant
- Plough and cover an infested area with a polyethylene sheet to destroy tubers and rhizomes in the dry season (soil solarization). This can be very effective but not always 100%.
- Place organic mulch over areas where weed is expect to grow to provide temporary weed suppression
- Tillage must be deep (> 12cm) in order to disturb as many of the rhizomes as possible. Do this every three weeks and under dry conditions so the exposed rhizomes dessicate.

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Inflorescence (S.D. Sawant)
Whole plants (S.D. Sawant)

Sections.Value:
- Purchase certified crop seed and animal feed to reduce the chance of contamination
- As seeds can travel on animals and machinery, do not allow animals into an affected area, limit machinery use in the area and keep machinery clean to prevent spread
- Keep crop healthy to maximize competitiveness - use optimal water and fertilizer levels
- Limit the amount the tillage where D. stramonium is present. Post-harvest tillage may promote survival since seeds become buried
- Do not allow livestock to graze on sparse pasture where weed is present. Livestock otherwise may eat the poisonous weed

- Bushy annual herb; 0.5-2 m tall
- Seedling leaves: oval-shaped, pointed tips, few or no lobes
- Mature leaves: oval to broadly triangular-shaped, unevenly toothed
- Stems: green to purplish, stout
- Flowers: trumpet-shaped, white to creamy or violet, rarely completely open
- Seed capsules/cases: egg-shaped, walnut-sized, spiny or bald
- May be confused with other species within the Datura genus:
D. stramonium: 100 or more capsule spines; long flower (up to 10 cm) D. ferox: up to 60 capsule spines; shorter flower (4-6 cm)
D. stramonium (and D. ferox): straight capsule stalks; black or grey seeds. D. leichhardtii, D. metel, D. inoxia and D. wrightii: curved capsule stalks; brown or yellow seeds
- Monitor open and disturbed areas particularly closely. D. stramonium can be found on roadsides, agricultural land and riverbanks.
- Take action as soon as weed is seen

- Dig, pull or hoe out before seed sets in order to prevent it spreading. Wear gloves when handling it since it is poisonous, particularly its leaves and seeds. Be thorough since it can regenerate from root fragments if not removed effectively
- To dispose of pulled weed, if seed has not set, add to a compost heap. If seed has set, ensure pulled weed is buried to least 60 cm/2 ft, or burn it to prevent spread (if permitted in your country)
- Till the soil when weeds are seedlings. When mature, stems become woody and difficult to remove
- Grow winter annual crops and forage crops and cut them several times during the year to control the weed
- Remove weed before making hay, silage, grain or other animal feed to prevent spread
- Seedlings emerge over a long period of time so repeated removal may be necessary

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Flowering D. stramonium plant with flowers and fruit (Chris Parker, Bristol, UK)
D. stramonium seedling (Chris Parker, Bristol, UK)
Jimsonweed (Datura stramonium) (Chris Evans, University of Illinois, Bugwood.org)

Sections.Value:
- Purchase certified crop seed and animal feed to reduce the chance of contamination
- As seeds can travel on animals and machinery, do not allow animals into an affected area, limit machinery use in the area and keep machinery clean to prevent spread
- Keep crop healthy to maximize competitiveness - use optimal water and fertilizer levels
- For pasture, encourage good grass coverage since grass can outcompete the weed. Limit the amount of grazing in a particular area:
Supply multiple watering points to prevent livestock congregating
Rotate livestock between paddocks

- Tufted annual grass, spreading or stands straight, up to 60 cm tall
- Seedlings: first leaf is about 1 cm long, pointed, may lie flat on soil
- Leaves: bright green; smooth; flat to V-shaped; up to 8 mm wide, 15 cm long. Tends to form a long-growing rosette with white-coloured leaf sheath at the base
- Flowers: arranged in clusters of 3-5
- Does not root at nodes of growing stems.
- Seeds: reddish-brown to black; oblong; ridged; about 1 mm long
- Roots: centralized system; very strong when mature
- Spreads along disturbed habitats such as roads and powerline corridors. Look for it along marshes, stream banks and coasts
- Can be confused with weeds such as Digitaria, Dactyloctenium, Cynodon, Chloris or Paspalum spp. E. indica is distinguished by the combination of its flattened stem, bright green leaves, size and many-flowered character of spikelets, lack of awns.

- Remove by hand if the weed is smaller than 5-8 cm in diameter. Use a hoe if removal is difficult. Removal gets harder as weed grows (root system is stronger)
- Till the land. The weed grows best in compact, poorly drained soils so make sure it is aerated and drained
- Use solarization to kill weed seeds down to 5 cm. This requires watering (light irrigation) of the soil area after mulching and before covering the area with the transparent polyethylene sheet
- Use shredded newspaper as a mulch on tomato fields
- Use a rye cover crop its residues should supress the weed

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Sections.Value:
- Clean tillage equipment and other farm machinery to prevent rhizomes being spread
- For maize: weed infested fields at least five times to minimise yield reduction
- After eradication of I. cylindrica, it is necessary to establish useful species which suppress regrowth of weeds and conserve soil fertility
Use legume cover crops to smother the weeds, stabilize the soil and fix nitrogen. Calopogonium caeruleum, C. mucunoides, Desmodium intortum, Centrosema pubescens, Mucuna spp., Pueraria phaseoloides, P. triloba and Stylosanthes guianensis are examples of legumes that are used to rehabilitate grassland or provide ground cover in plantation crops.
Or gradually change your cropping system to include agroforestry by planting trees in the field to increase shade e.g. plant mahogany (Swietenia mahogani), sungkai (Peronema canescens) or candle nut (Aleurites moluccanus.
Use alley cropping to shade and surpress weeds e.g. plant Gliricidia sepium and Leucaena leucocephala

- Perennial grass; can be up to 3 m tall
- Rhizomes (underground stems): tough; white; around 1 m deep; concentrated in upper 15-20 cm of soil; produced from seedlings after 4 weeks:
Remain dormant but viable for a long time. Can reshoot from fragments shorter fragments are less likely to survive
- Leaves: can be green or red; stiff; finely toothed edges; hairy upper surface near plant base; 120 cm long, 4-18 mm wide
- Flowers: white; two stamens; fluffy; 5-20 cm long, 2.5 cm wide
Flowers after exposure to stress such as burning, overgrazing and repeated slashing
- Seeds: dispersed by wind; one plant can produce 3000; have little or no dormancy period; remain viable for over a year
- Check for presence of weed every 2 months in cassava fields, and every 2 weeks in other crops
- Take control measures if present

- Any management strategy should aim to destroy the grass rhizomes. Control strategies should be based on an integrated approach
- Extract using a hoe or hand-pull weed
- Dispose of fragments by burial or burning. Do not only burn as this enhances seed production
- Cultivate soil during the dry season when most of the weed's biomass is in the rhizomes and when dessication is most effective. If done in the wet season there is not enough sun to kill the exposed rhizomes
- To expose the rhizomes, execute deep mechanical tillage (30-40 cm) with tractor during field preparation. Leave for at least 2 weeks to desiccate rhizomes in the sun and plough again at right angles to the previous direction to expose fragmented rhizomes. After, harrow field twice at an interval of about 2 weeks
- Execute grass pressing to decomposes and dry up weeds within 1 month and to enable the establishment of legume ground covers:
Ensure grass shoots are only bent, not broken, otherwise it will send up new shoots
Do this when weed is about 1 m high to ensure stems remain bent
Roll logs or stand on planks

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Sections.Value:
- As seeds can travel on animals and machinery, do not allow animals into an affected area, limit machinery use in the area and keep machinery clean to prevent spread
- Control established populations near waterways to prevent spread during flooding and storm events
- For pasture: Do not allow pasture to be overgrazed or undergrazed
Supply multiple watering points to prevent livestock congregating
Rotate livestock between paddocks
Fence-off areas becoming overgrazed

- Scrambling, strongly-branched, annual shrub, 1-2 m tall
- Stems: green or purple tinge; abundant, sharp, yellowish prickles; fine white hairs; angled cross-section; about 6 m long
- Leaves: bright green; 4-9 pairs of pinnae, consisting of small leaflets which fold together when disturbed and at nightfall; 10-20 cm long
- Flower heads: pinkish-violet; round, fluffy; found in leaf joints; about 1.2 cm wide
- Check pastures and crops fields every two to four weeks, consider direct control if present
- Check monthly for presence of the weed in wetlands and along waterways.

- Wearing gloves, hand pull or hoe, or till the land, when weed is young/easier to remove:
Uproot at least twice a year (1. before flowering and seed setting. 2. Just after the first showers when seedlings emerge)
- For cassava: Remove weed using hand-held hoe to a depth of 3-5 cm, at 4, 7, and 11 weeks after planting
- Cut branches regularly, before seeding, alongside other methods. Just slashing can leave fragments that regenerate
- Heteropsylla spinulosa and Corynespora cassiicola, are effective biological controls. Check to see if these are available in your country

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Sections.Value:
- As seeds can travel on animals and machinery, do not allow animals into an affected area, limit machinery use in the area and keep machinery clean to prevent spread
- Do not allow livestock to graze in infested pasture seeds can pass through digestive tract unharmed
- Clean shoes, clothing and hair after being in a potentially infested area. The bristly one-seeded pod segments are sticky
- Ensure uncontaminated water is used when flooding rice paddys as pod segments float and can be transported by water

- Regularly check sites such as machinery tracks, grazing places, previously flooded areas fallen dry for seeds and any seedling establishment
- Check for any seed germination at the start and end of the wet season
- Spreading, multi-stemmed, thorny shrub usually up to 2 m tall,
- The inflorescences, containing up to 100 flowers, flowers are pale pink and arranged in fluffy, globular clusters (10-20 mm across)
- The fruit is an elongated and flattened pod covered in bristly hairs and up to 15 cm long and clustered at the stem tips
- The plant is evergreen and bears bipinnate (twice-compound), sensitive leaves, up to 18 cm in length. When touched they fold together and also during the night
- Recurved spines (to 7 mm long) are located on the undersides of the petioles, petioules and stems

- Uproot plants by hand-pulling or using machinery, and destroy roots
- Collect seeds and burn before weeding
- Cut plants off at 10 cm below ground level to kill the weed. Use long handled cutters, axe or machete:
Blade ploughing is effective since it cuts below ground level. Slashing and chaining alone is not (requires herbicide application afterwards)
- Burning is not recommended does not prevent resprouting and kills only surface seeds. It may stimulate germination. Also reduces the numbers of the stem-mining moth Carmenta mimosa
- Check which biocontrols are available in your country. Examples of biological controls include:
Beetle species such as Acanthoscelides puniceus or A. quadridentatus
The green twig-mining moth Neurostrota gunniella attacks mature plants and seedlings greater than 15 cm (should not be used in Thailand or Vietnam). You can use this after weed removal to reduce herbicide use
- Fragment infestations to increase numbers of control agents such as N. gunniella since it increases weed stand edges

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Sections.Value:
- Clean tillage equipment and other farm machinery to prevent weed rhizomes being spread
- Do not accept potentially contaminated materials, e.g. fill dirt, hay, and clean vegetation off boat trailers and machinery
- Limit the presence of open and disturbed areas by preventing overgrazing
- Use legumes as cover crops to smother weed in plantation crops in sufficiently humid climatic conditions
- Control established populations near waterways to prevent weed spreading to fields
- For pasture, encourage a healthy and diverse ecosystem to deter infestation

- Perennial grass, clusters of flowers up to 50-100 cm high
- Look out for it in wetlands and along waterways. Water and storm events can spread it
- Leaves: bright green; stiff; sparsely hairy on upper surface; edges of leaf coverings have long white hairs; 15-20 cm long, 1 cm wide
- Rhizomes: grow horizontally; up to 20 cm deep; several metres long
- Flowers: spikelets (flower clusters) 2-flowered; pale green, sometimes tinged with purple; 2.5-3 mm long
- Similar to Panicum repentellum, distinguished by its nerveless lower glume (a small modified leaf surrounding the spikelet)
- Rhizomes can be spread via soil transport

- Use a combination of continuous tillage, hand weeding, cutting and burning. Using only one of these methods can result in rapid regrowth from rhizomes.
- Tillage must be deep in order to disturb as many of the rhizomes as possible. Do this under dry conditions so the exposed rhizomes dessicate
- Use legumes as cover crops to smother weed in plantation crops in sufficiently humid climatic conditions

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Sections.Value:
- Purchase and sow certified crop and pasture seed to reduce the chance of contamination
- Seeds are spread by animals - do not allow livestock into an affected area to avoid spread
- Seeds travel on machinery - clean equipment and vehicules after work in infested areas
- Prevent spread of Sida by slashing or mowing before it flowers
- Avoid overgrazing to prevent establishment of the weed in disturbed patches

- Small shrub (0.5-1.5m) with lanceolate leaves with dented egde.
- The flowers are yellow, solitary, 1-2 cm in diameter and on a short stalk 0.3-0.8 cm long. Each flower has six petals and produces seeds with two awns, thus attaching easily to animal fur
- The fruit is a hard, brown capsule, 3-5 mm in diameter, breaking into 5-8 triangular segments
- Regularly check waste and other ruderal sites, because these are usually the first invaded by Sida
- Check for flowering and seed development to prevent seed set, spread and build up of seed bank

- Dig up single plants prior to onset of flowering, ensuring the taproot is severed well below the crown to prevent regrowth
- Plow or hand-weed after the first rains have induced germination, followed by sowing of dense pasture or cover crop
- Larger areas can be controlled by repeated cultivation until the soil seed bank is depleted
- Competitive grasses may be effective in suppressing Sida, when combined with other control measures

Sections.Value:
- As seeds can travel on animals and machinery, do not allow animals into an affected area, limit machinery use in the area and keep machinery clean to prevent spread
- In pasture, encourage the health and abundance of desirable plant species to make the ecosystem more resilient against invasion

- Upright, branching, annual herb; shallow rooted; up to 1.5 m tall
- Stems: become woody with age; young parts have short white hairs
- Leaves: Egg-shaped, toothed, sparsly hairy, rough, 2-10 cm long, 0.5-5 cm wide
- Flowers: Purple, blue, pinkish or white; less than 0.6 cm across; clusters of flower heads at top of stems; few hairs on bracts surrounding flower heads; projections (styles) of 0.5 cm (gives fluffly appearance); flower head base 0.5-0.8 mm across
- Seeds: Germinate in response to light; viable for 12 months.
- Similar to Ageratum houstonianum which has: numerous sticky hairs on bracts surrounding flower heads; shorter flower projections (styles) of 0.1-0.2 cm; smaller flower head base (0.3-0.6 cm)
- Look along waterways. Seeds are mainly spread via wind, water, on the hair of animals and attached to clothes and agricultural machinery
- Take action as soon as weeds are identified

- Short periods of flooding (water stagnation), for at least 10 days, can reduce weed density and mass
- Use minimum tillage systems such as strip tillage as this reduces weed density
- Can be easily uprooted mechanically as roots are shallow. Do this before weed flowers
- Increase fallow length in slash-and-burn rice production systems to reduce weed mass
- Spread infested ground with thick mulch and leave undisturbed in order to smother the weed

Sections.Value:
- Purchase and sow certified crop and pasture seed to reduce the chance of contamination
- Seeds are spread by animals - do not allow livestock into an affected area to avoid spread
- Seeds are spread on clothes and shoes - remove seeds when leaving an infested area
- Species is spread by water - use only water from sources free of the weed and avoid runoff from surrounding infested fields
- Avoid overgrazing to prevent establishment of the weed in disturbed patches
- Prevent spread of the weed by slashing or mowing wfhen they are still small
- A maize-bean intercropping system can effectively suppress the weed
- Use thick mulch with dry non-weedy plant materials to prevent germination of the weed

- Annual erect broadleaved weed (up to 1 m high) with green composed leaves and a strong taproot
- White flowers with yellow centre and 1 cm long black seeds with 2-4 yellowish awns at one end
- Check fields and surroundings for presence of weed once a week during early crop establishment, and once a month later
- Check for flowering and seed development to prevent seed set, spread and build up of seed bank

- Dig up or hand pull plants prior to onset of flowering, ensuring the taproot is severed well below the crown to prevent regrowth
- Mow or slash the species prior to flowering and seed set
- A no-seed threshold is important as it prevents further spread of the weed
